PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dunn) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to remove sexist and discriminatory language from Commonwealth legislation and to declare the intention of the Parliament that language used in future legislation should be non-sexist.
Motion (by Senator Dunn) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Senators, my purpose in introducing the Legislation (Non-Sexist Language) Bill is to advance beyond the Government's half-hearted attempt in 1984 to address the problem of sexist and discriminatory language in Commonwealth legislation.

In 1984 the Government amended section 23 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. That Act had provided since it was first enacted that words importing the masculine gender were taken to include the female gender, unless a contrary intention appeared. In 1984 an amendment was made that unless the contrary intention appeared, words importing one gender should be taken to include the other.

This was a very small step-a token response to the problem of sexist and discriminatory language. A lot of older legislation on the statute books, by the use of masculine references, gives the impression that those with power, the decision-makers, will almost always be men. Only rarely are words used in legislation which refer to the female gender and which, as a result of the amendment, would now be required to be taken to include the male.

A more substantial response was the Government's adoption of a legislative drafting policy to no longer limit references only to the male gender where both males and females were contemplated. Since the adoption of this drafting policy we have seen expressions such as ``he or she'' appearing in Federal Bills.
The Government also began amending legislation to change references which are sexist and discriminatory and amended its Style Manual to prevent their use in Government publications.
I acknowledge that in administration and policy the Government has made some practical reforms.

Today we can be reasonably confident that, with the ``purposive approach'' under the Acts Interpretation Act and, with changing social attitudes to gender roles, that Act will be construed to to avoid gender discrimination.

However, I am strongly in favour of a statutory commitment to the removal and prohibition of sexist language in Federal legislation. Such a policy is important enough to enshrine in an Act of Parliament. A reversal of the policy by a future government would be made that much more difficult to achieve.

My bill, although it is short, has substantial philosophical underpinnings. The works of Derrida, Foucault and Barthes with their semiotic and post structuralist approaches argue that words are not mere words with meanings attached, such as that ``he'' will be taken to include ``she'', but rather that words have a ``meaning potential'' within their social context and within a particular discourse. Semiotics tells us that language is a system of signs, not reflecting on a reality external to the words, but part of that external reality. They shape behaviour, environment and attitude. The exclusion of the word ``she'' has the effect of making women invisible, of making them subordinate within a patriarchal discourse. My Bill aims to challenge that discourse, to charge the reality in an important area of human affairs, by requiring Federal legislation to adopt non-sexist language.

If I can illustrate my point in a quite different context, the use of the term ``Conservation Zone'' to define the area excluded from Kakadu National Park, in order to preserve the area's potential for mining and at the same time appear to answer environmental needs, is a use of language to create a reality suited to the requirements of a particular interest.

Foucault has argued that modern practices of domination may not necessarily be overtly coercive. They are internalised with the effect that the will and the soul and the mind of a group within society are susceptible to domination. One form of domination sexism is supported by the willing use of language which renders women subordinate, dependent or invisible. The language itself embodies male domination and contributes to a social order that is patriarchal and discriminatory.

Women now comprise a large part of the paid labour force but discrimination still affects them. Vocational titles still tend to derive from male titles: author/authoress, poet/poetess, waiter/waitress are some examples and the Commonwealth Style Manual details many others. Other titles are inapplicable to women, suggesting that they could never aspire to such roles; spokesman, statesman and chairman are examples of these. This terminology has to be reformed and this Bill would help in the process.

I feel it is appropriate to pay tribute here to the women (and a few men) who are actively challenging the use of sexist language. Senator Crowley in particular has taken an interest in the propensity of language to influence the position of women in society.

I reserve some less complimentary remarks for those, on both sides of the chamber, who I suspect might deride this Bill and snigger at the thinking behind it. I suggest that is an attitude derived from ignorance rather than awareness and fear rather than reason.
I commend the Bill to this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when I was speaking on the Training Guarantee Bill, I was explaining to the Senate why I believe that it is important that what may be perceived as a good idea should be referred to a Senate committee to ensure that the detail in this Bill matches the rhetoric of the second reading speech and the expectations of those who believe it is a good idea. SPEECH.PARA: Small businesses join trade and/or professional organisations to obtain information and improve the level of skill and knowledge of their employees.

I was reading that with a view to suggesting that it should be appropriate for small businesses to be able to claim as part of their tax the money that they spend for this training purpose on investment courses, magazines and journals that relate to their specific area of expertise and to improving their skills and those of their employees. The letter goes on to indicate that the employers are therefore disadvantaged in two ways. To save the time of the Senate, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the letter from the Real Estate Institute dated 25 May 1990.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follow-
Senator Margaret Reid
1st Floor, 4 Mort Street
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Dear Margaret
Training Guarantee Bill
I am writing in regard to the Training Guarantee Bill proposed to be introduced this year and wish to provide the Institute's comments on this matter.
The Institute is committed to increasing professional services of its members and therefore supports legislation which encourages a higher level of skill in the industry.

We do, however, have some concerns with provisions of the Bill and the effect on small business in Canberra. In particular, we are concerned with the administration of the system. The Bill intends to be linked to the taxation system, thus creating a negative image in those affected by it (ie employers), rather than a positive response. It will be perceived by employers as another taxation measure, rather than an endeavour to improve the level of skill of employees.

The administration involved with the Bill will adversely affect real estate agents in the ACT; in fact all small businesses in Canberra. It will add to the already considerable workload involved in Government paperwork of these businesses. Moreover, the Standing Committee on Industry, Services &Technology presented a report on small businesses and identified Government paperwork as a major handicap of small businesses. The Bill therefore ignores the recommendations from that Committee and will only compound the problem.
However, if this legislation intends to remain as it stands, we must ensure that it works effectively to minimise the administrative workload of employers.

One particular concern that we have is the eligibility of expenditure under this Bill. The Bill does not include membership subscriptions to trade or industry related organisations, like ourselves, as eligible expenditure. Small businesses join trade and/or professional organisations to obtain information and improve the level of skill and knowledge of their employees.

Our own Institute provides seminars and newsletters for our members' benefit free of charge. This form of training is just as important as formal structured training, as required under the Bill, yet is not recognised in any way. We also provide training courses for members at reduced rates. For example, we are currently running an Investment Analysis course which costs members $150 and non members $280.

Employers are therefore disadvantaged in two ways. Not only are their subscription fees to professional organisations not acceptable, but they also receive free or reduced rate training which will penalise them under the Bill, as the Bill requires a certain amount of expenditure for their employees. They spend the time and money to acquire the increased level of skill but are penalised due to not spending the required amount.

We therefore recommend very strongly that subscriptions to trade or other professional organisations be recognised as eligible under the Bill. As an example of what real estate offices in Canberra pay in membership fees per annum, the average real estate office with say six employees (1 Director, 1 Registered Agent &4 Affiliates) would pay $695 per annum.

These subscription fees should be acknowledged under the legislation. I again emphasise that trade and professional organisations are committed to increasing the level of skill of its members, thus achieving the requirements of the Bill.
We would appreciate your support in this.
Yours sincerely
BRUNO YVANOVICH
EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

TALK.START.PARA: —Another area of small business that warrants investigation is that relating to those in the activity of offering personnel services. A personnel firm of this kind has on its books a large number of people-maybe 50, 70 or more-for whom they obtain work. The person for whom the employees work pays the salary to the personnel service firm, which then pays the worker. As a consequence, the personnel firm has a huge payroll, but a very small margin of profit for itself. Such firms assist qualified people into employment; the system works very well. It is a particularly useful form of activity for many women who wish to work part-time and intermittently. If such firms are required to pay this additional tax, it will just about wipe them out because their margins are so small. They offer training programs from time to time. But the fact is that the people who register with the personnel service firm have qualifications; that is what they are offering. There needs to be a wider range of exceptions in the Bill to enable people to proceed with the business that they are already in. I hope that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), will deal with this and that we can pursue it in the committee stage of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder also whether the fringe benefits tax is to be specifically excluded from operation in the area where an employer has paid for a training program for an employee which significantly advantages that employee. Is it certain and beyond doubt that, having paid for that, the employer will not also be liable for the fringe benefits tax, having advantaged the employee to that extent? One could go on for a long time and talk about areas in this Bill that are not sufficiently clear and which I believe warrant the Bill's detail being looked at to ensure that it is putting into effect what the Government says that it wants it to do. As I said last night, Senator Childs was saying that, by our suggesting a committee investigation, we were merely attempting to get rid of the Bill. That is not the case.

In a number of cases people are employed by an organisation for virtually a charitable purpose. Clause 17 of the Bill deals with the exemptions for particular employers and it states that a training guarantee charge-which is, of course, a training guarantee tax-is not payable by an employer that is a public benevolent institution other than a public hospital. If one goes to the Income Tax Assessment Act to find out what are classed as public benevolent institutions, it seems to me that they are only organisations for which gifts of $2 or more are tax deductable. There are quite a number of them. But what about all those other organisations doing charitable work in the community which get small sums of money, or perhaps a grant from government, and are paying people to go out and do charity work but just do not have vast resources? Surely, they too should be exempt.

As I speak, many examples spring to mind. I am sure that I and others will go through them when we get to the committee stage. Why is it that only those public benevolent institutions as defined by the Australian Taxation Office will be exempt from the operation of this Act? Surely it is possible to find a definition that takes into account other charitable groups in the community that are not in the business of gathering huge public donations in the way that these are.

It also exempts a religious institution in relation to those of its employees whose duties are solely or principally pastoral duties or duties directly related to the practice, study, teaching or propagation of religious beliefs. Does that then mean that all the stenographers employed by the religious organisations will be included in the payroll for which religious institutions will have to pay the training tax? If it does, I think there will be a pretty swift response from the religious institutions when they find out the extent to which their bill to government will rise dramatically. This legislation is not clearly worded so as to totally exclude all of the staff of religious institutions. Their cleaning staff and secretariat staff are presumably attracting wages on which the institutions will then have to pay the training tax. That is not in the best interests of those institutions and the work they do.

It is quite clear that a number of journalists who have written in adoring terms about this Bill have read only the second reading speech and heard the rhetoric of government; they have not read this legislation. They praise it but they have not read it and analysed it. They certainly have never run a business with 10 or 12 employees and have never seen the amount of paperwork involved in running a small business. As I said last night, anybody who has written in that fashion does not understand the Bill. Clause 27 will attract an enormous amount of paperwork as a result of having to keep the necessary information to withstand the Commissioner of Taxation's audit. For that reason I repeat that the Bill must go to a committee and the problems must be clarified and ironed out. It is important that we get it right now so that it does not become a festering sore in the community.

Finally, can an employer who has a staff member who is a member of the Army Reserve claim that fee which he pays by way of wages as a benefit under this Act when his employee is off in the Army Reserve? I suggest that he could and should, because an enormous number of skills would be acquired during that process. While he allows his employee to go to an Army Reserve training course he ought to be able to debit against his training tax the amount of wages he pays during the time his employee is not with him.

I urge the Senate most strongly to send this Bill to a committee to make sure that its detail matches what the Government says it is trying to do and to make sure that it is not merely a tax to get more money out of the private sector and businesses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990 and the Training Guarantee Bill 1990 currently before the Senate are inefficient. They are heavy-handed and they will not be an effective means of improving industry training programs. They are merely another tax, another impost on industry; another overhead that will make industry more and more uncompetitive as we seek to overcome the problems of recessionary conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Government: under what head of power is it introducing these Bills into the Senate today? As I see it, the head of power it is using is section 51 of the Constitution. I draw attention to the fact the it is highly likely that these Bills will be challenged on constitutional grounds. They are an exercise in taxation adventurism-normal taxation, levies, rates of tax on certain groups or classes of people at graduated rates. We saw a slight departure in superannuation in that we had complying funds and non-complying funds. The complying funds attracted a concessional rate of taxation; the non-complying funds attracted a penalty rate of taxation.

This legislation does not fit the norm or ordinary taxation legislation as perceived by the founders of the Constitution when drawing up section 51. It discriminates even within the same groups of people. It lays down regulations as to the code of conduct. It has inclusions and exclusions for particular types of activities. This is quite discriminatory. If our Tax Act discriminates in such a way I wonder where we will finish up. So much for simplicity, so much for the need to make it relatively easily understood. It is a serious departure from the norm of ordinary taxation legislation because essentially it does not seek to tax; it seeks to use this mechanism to regulate. Many of the people closely involved in the administration of this tax perceive that, at best, it will be revenue neutral.

The Australian Labor Party view is that Australian management has a poor attitude to training. This is a very poor way-I submit even a very unconstitutional way-of trying to coerce companies into increasing their investment in training, to make the most of the opportunities to improve efficiency and productivity through award restructuring. It will fail because our award restructuring, particularly that which is designed to improve re-skilling, training and retraining, has not advanced as quickly as the Government had hoped; there are a number of problems in this area. It is unfortunate that we are seeing the completely inappropriate implementation of some European socialistic ideas in Australia, which has a different training structure from that of the Europeans. Time and time again, ideas are plucked from overseas and imposed on inappropriate structures here. This is another example. It will not improve the quality of training.

My background is in the textile industry. Last night I thought through the various processes of a vertically integrated textile mill and how I would have had to apply these particular provisions. We start off with wool handling. We were highly involved in training. This was done for our own interests. Training is undertaken because one cannot afford to have employees making mistakes with wool of this quality, nature and, in some cases, fragility. Training is a highly essential component in which everybody is involved at present. It provides the opportunities for what the Government has in mind. We then had the willowing process. This was predetermined by chemists and was regulated according to type and batch. This was done apart from training in work practices, training to eliminate repetitive strain injury and such things, which was applied throughout the following processes.

The facility of applying particular training, as outlined in this Bill, is not there because the training will be one-to-one training-for example, the carding, the spinning, the weaving, even the burling or the mending. It will be a one-to-one training hands-on experience. We should not take these ladies out into a classroom environment and show them how to mend a piece of cloth. It should be done with a training officer on the job, for which there is no recognition in this Bill. Apart from that first entity we come to the wet finishing and the dry finishing. Again, there should be one-to-one training.

The only other possible exception would be in the dye-house operations where we use the training facilities that are available. In this case people would actually be sent away to the mainland specialist institutions. We find that these sorts of expenses do not fall within the ambit of the Bill. The practical application in a manufacturing situation, as I have described it in a typical wool mill, or the office situation involving training and retraining has possibilities. For the great bulk of these processes and the great bulk of the people involved in a typical wool mill the application of this Bill is way out. The Government is approaching it from the wrong direction, has given it the wrong recognition and has the wrong sort of goals to fit a manufacturing operation of a vertically integrated nature.

We find that the proposed legislation will apply to employers with an annual payroll of $200,000 or more, indexed to the average weekly earnings. It is to take effect from 1 July 1990. The minimum training requirement expenditure on training is equal to one per cent of the payroll for the financial year from July 1990, increasing to 1.5 per cent in later years. The review of the scheme will be conducted after four years. Already the scheme has been virtually damned before it begins. Affected employers will have to pay a levy equal to the percentage of their payroll, less their own training expenditure. This is an unusual way to raise revenue. The non-deductability for income tax purposes of levy payments will be a significant additional cost. This is another imposition. It is not surprising because it is not usual for us to be able to deduct Federal income tax charges against another income tax charge in an almost equivalent revenue-raising Bill.

A close reading of the draft Bill reviews a significant number of sections which will greatly add to the administrative load and the personal liability of public officers and employer personnel. For example, let us look at some comments from people around Australia who really know, people who represent small business and others. Let me take the words of Peter Boyle, the Director of the Australian Small Business Association. He said:
It will be a wonderful make-work program for public servants and create another tide of red tape and paper work for small business.
That is a relevant comment. David Edwards, the Executive Director of the Victorian Employers Federation, went so far as to say in a letter to the editor of the Australian Financial Review:
The Federal Government's training levy is unlikely to raise the $600 to $800m that the Government has forecast. Indeed it may not cover the administration costs of the scheme.

If enacted in its present form the legislation will be expensive for those employers that it affects. Qualifying employers will need to ensure that their training expenditure complies with this tight statutory definition which is quite inappropriate for a whole host of manufacturing operations because of the one-to-one and special training operations that they have in place at present. It would be difficult for them to comply with the statutory definitions. They will have additional accounting systems to put in place to detail the eligible-this is the crunch word-expenditure programs. Where training expenditure exceeds the training requirement companies will not be able to carry forward the amount or claim a refund. It is quite inequitable. It might be high in one year but one cannot carry forward the excess to another year, contrary to normally taxation principles and income tax law.

The coalition has already indicated in the House of Representatives that it is opposed to this legislation because of its very arbitrary nature, both in terms of who has to pay and the threshold figure of $200,000. It is bad legislation. We believe that as a coalition, as a responsible alternative government, we cannot support a levy which is applied carte blanche, irrespective of what the company does, irrespective of whether it provides any one-to-one training-this is the message we have to get across-and irrespective of whether the nature of its business requires it to recruit and employ untrained staff and to then train them. There is a whole range of ramifications.

As a coalition we cannot accept the Government's definition of eligible training. I suppose we should at least be grateful that the Government has attempted to define it. In the first round of the draft this was totally lacking. It was only from intense pressure that we had even a definition. That shows that the scheme is hastily thought out and ill-conceived and will be a patchwork program of improvement.

I point out to the Senate that training programs are really only eligible if the program is structured-that is the first prerequisite-that is, if the objective of the program, the means of achieving the objective, is clearly identified before the start of the program. In a sense that is going to take a lot of bookwork and a lot of unnecessary paperwork. In theory, it is desirable. One almost wonders whether the whole program has been based on the job skills program around Australia. While a number of the programs are very good and identifiable their application across this whole spectrum of industry and manufacturing is not always applicable.

The program must also be designed or approved by a person appropriately qualified to do so. Again, this creates some problems. An appropriate qualification, as per the explanatory notes, means a person with a working knowledge of the area who has undertaken at least a short course on program training design or has been approved by a person with such qualifications.

The details of the person appropriately qualified should be spelt out in the Bill, not just in the explanatory memorandum. The explanatory memorandum has very little force of law. We should be looking for an appropriately worded Bill which includes this concept. We should not have to go back to the speeches in the Parliament or to the explanatory memorandum. The whole content should be in the Bill for employers to understand if they are going to implement it justly without penalty and without consequence.

The sole or principal object of the program must be to develop, maintain and improve the employment-related skills of employees or other persons. Recreation should not form a significant part of the program. If it does it does not qualify. If the program consists of or includes on-the- job training it must include periods of instruction and periods of closely supervised practice. That will be very hard to detail in a program that may be necessary to raise skills or satisfactory standards. If a program does not include such things it will be ineligible. In the whole raft of apprenticeship training, on-the-job training supervisors may have to take a couple of minutes off to explain intricate wiring networks. They then go on with a job, complete it and move to another one. Will they have to stop and document all these sorts of operations, instructions and special training to their apprentice? Imagine the paperwork involved! I do not really think the Government realises what an elephant it has created here.

My colleagues have drawn to the Senate's attention the invaluable nature of work experience in terms of training and the fact that to preclude it from the legislation is almost laughable. That sort of experience is vitally necessary in some areas.

Other defects in the draft legislation, as highlighted by an international firm of accountants, include there being no provision under which employers can apply for exemption where their circumstances justify it. It is usual to have an opting out clause in special circumstances but there is no such provision in this Bill. In support of the raising of this defect, there are employers who hire out to other employers temporary staff such as relief secretaries or locums for professional practices. That is a major deficiency because, as explained by my colleagues, those companies may have 50 or 100 people on their books and the charge-out fees are quite nominal. There is no provision in the Bill for companies with substituted accounting periods. These companies will be inconvenienced, extracting information on a financial year basis when their records are maintained for a different year end. I find it extraordinary that here we have tax legislation with a tax head which has obviously not been put to the Commissioner of Taxation. If it had, those sorts of features would be recognised and written into this Act.

The record retention obligations are onerous and some exemption should be available from record keeping retention obligations where employers are able to establish that their training expenditure is well in excess of the minimum required under this Act. One can draw the analogy, of course, of the keeping of motor vehicle logbooks for 13 weeks to determine the percentage of costs which will be applied for work purposes. In other words, once a standard has been established it then applies, unless there is a major change, for quite a number of years. Why cannot these sorts of principles be applied to the legislation before us.

We are giving the Government plenty of ideas on how to improve the quality of this legislation. We are not happy with it. We have pointed out the defects and the problems to the Government. I believe that, as a minimum, the Bill should be withdrawn and redrafted, and have a different starting date, at least until we can get some more award restructuring programs under way with appropriate recognition for retraining and reskilling.

The concept of an appropriately qualified person, as set out in the explanatory note, is far too narrow for ordinary day to day manufacturing purposes and it has to be broadened if it is going to have any practical application. The proposed section with regard to apprentices and trainees is inadequately drafted and it will cause confusion. It is apparent from the explanatory memorandum that the full amount of $1,000 should be allowed as eligible expenditure per apprentice or trainee employed for a full year without a deduction for any reimbursement in relation to such an employee. However, this interpretation is not reflected in the legislation.

The Bill requires eligible expenditure to be directly attributable solely or principally to eligible training programs. This is another problem of definition. Where rent is paid for premises, and less than half of those premises are set apart solely for eligible training purposes, this may not qualify as there is only one amount of rent paid and this does not relate principally to eligible training programs. The legislation should be clarified to ensure that items of mixed expenditure must be apportioned between eligible and ineligible activities.

Capital expenditure is another area of major defect. Capital expenditure is to be directly attributable to the acquisition or construction of premises intended solely for training for eligible training purposes and eligible training expenditure but this could mean that if a company spent $5m on setting up or erecting an eligible training operation or building, in one year that employer would obviously have an excess but in subsequent years he might fall below the training mechanism, having devoted so much money in one year. He would want to make sure he could amortise that over a number of years. But, according to the Bill, that is not possible. I believe that that is a major impediment to the Bill.
I am concerned that this Bill should pass through the Senate when it contains such defects. Additionally, according to the Australian Financial Review:
The Federal Government has caved in to a string of Australian Democrat amendments to its industry training levy legislation which will drastically alter its administration.

I must admit that some of those changes have some merit, particularly monitoring by peak industry bodies. I believe that up until now they have been left out of the arrangements. As far as I am aware the Bill before us is the original one where the onus for deciding program eligibility seems ultimately to rest with the Australian Taxation Office, and I think that needs to be clarified as a result of some of the amendments that have been introduced.

With all these sorts of changes which will be incorporated now, and later on, the starting date of 1 July is quite inappropriate. It should at least be delayed until January, or even for 12 months; preferably, the Bill should be scrapped.

I think these two Bills are already receiving enough general criticism without attracting further condemnation by our making changes in the next sitting. I will outline the reaction to this legislation of some of the people that the Bills will affect. The National Farmers Federation spokesman, Mr John Allwright, said:
We view industry training as a matter for industry and the workforce to determine, and not a field for further government intervention.
The Director of the Australian Small Business Association, Mr Boyle, said:

At a time when the economy is looking sick, when sales are slowing rapidly, when interest rates remain punishingly high, it is a gross act of irresponsibility for the Federal Government to be even contemplating imposing yet another tax and cost upon small business.

That sort of opinion is also supported by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, which wants safeguards put in place so that the viability of small business is not put at risk by the enactment of these Bills.

Rather than build up business, this training levy could lead to many deliberate decisions against expansion, because expansion of small businesses to over the $200,000 threshold could involve them in additional overheads and additional costs.

Surely this is the area that the Government would want to see increased. We want to see small business expand. Yet many people will see this as an impediment to putting on additional staff which would take their payroll above the $200,000 threshold. The Director of Access Economics, Dr Ed Shann, said in an article which appeared in the Business Review Weekly on 20 October:
. . . training levies are a mistake. They are an attack on the symptom rather than the cause of training . . .

I think that is significant. Dr Shann argues that the Government's aim should be to create competitive markets because if companies have to compete they will then recognise that human capital gives them a competitive advantage. We are looking at it from the wrong angle. He says companies will focus on how to give training a priority at the enterprise level and on restructuring work organisation and occupational structures to maximise their human capital. Training levies will never achieve that.

Dr Shann cites other training schemes around the world which he also claims fail to meet their objective. France has a training levy; in fact, I think the Government probably copies it from France virtually carte blanche. According to Dr Shann it bears a striking resemblance to what the Government is proposing for Australia. Let us look at the outcomes of the scheme in France. Companies with more than 10 employees have to spend 1.1 per cent of their payroll on training or pay the equivalent, as a tax, to the government. Virtually everybody in France claims to have spent the 1.1 per cent of payroll and the scheme is regarded as a bureaucratic joke. This is almost the identical scheme with the same percentages. It is a bureaucratic joke there and will become a bureaucratic joke in Australia. What do employers do over there? They indulge in training that fits the scheme's requirements, but the scheme actually achieves very little whatsoever. Companies spend their money on in-house training that is of very little use to people outside the companies, or they simply make up fictitious training expenses. And that is a sad indictment.

Whilst it is the Australian Government's intention to do itself out of a job by imposing a tax wing, are we sure that companies will undertake the necessary training and that the Government will not be collecting a levy or imposing any fines in the long run? I am sure it really wishes to achieve a constructive training scheme and not just have training for the sake of training to meet some particular rhetoric.

If we go back to Shann, he points out that the best enterprises in the world emphasise human resources development as a key weapon in their survival and prosperity. They do not need training levies to encourage them to invest in their employee's skills, just as they do not need levies to make them invest in the latest capital equipment. Will this be the next levy down the track for Australian manufacturers, a tax on their failure to invest on appropriate new capital expenditure? We have already seen in the latest capital expenditure details that it is substantially down.

Shann then goes on to suggest that the Government's aim should be to remove obstacles to training and using labour more efficiently. The age limit on apprenticeships, the non-recognition of migrant qualifications, the high payment of apprentices and a lack of career paths for skilled tradesmen-these are all cited as problems to be overcome. Other areas we could well consider include the shortening of the four-year apprenticeship scheme-something I advocated in industry for many years before I came into this place-the problem of demarcation issues, and tradesmen-apprentice ratios, all archaic systems from a bygone era.

Employers are taking the attitude that, if the Government wants to run their businesses by telling them how to spend their money, it can buy a share in the businesses. The Government is trying to run Australian businesses. What I fail to understand really is why the Government wants to impose this training levy on an industry when what we need is an effective system of industry training councils. This worries me. Through the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) system we have set up in Tasmania a comprehensive training council, which has worked very well. For example, we have training councils in the areas of building and construction, food processing, local government, retailing, automotive, textiles and clothing, forestry, tourism, road transport, and furniture. Here we have examples of industry and government working together on these training councils, and they have been able to assess industry training requirements and then go about arranging the training programs. Industry is happily contributing to these schemes, whether the annual payroll bill exceeds $200,000 or not.

If the Federal Government is going to make use of the funds raised through the training levy to fund existing training schemes and to establishment other training councils for industries which currently have none, then we might find major problems. But we are uncertain at this stage whether company contributions to training councils are deemed eligible expenditure under the training legislation. It would be a tragedy and a travesty if they were not. May I suggest that the Government look into this to make sure that they are eligible because such a scheme would run against current DEET operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990 and the Training Guarantee Bill 1990. These two Bills impose a requirement on employers resident in Australia to spend a minimum amount on structured training every financial year, starting on 1 July 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is not a move towards a better trained work force, important though such an objective is. It is the latest of a whole string of anti-business measures of this Hawke Labor Government that taxes large and small business to pay for a bureaucratic form of training and tells management what kind of training it should have. Only last week we in the Senate here were debating the problems of small business and the unprecedented rate of bankruptcies. Yet here we have another piece of legislation today that is going to impose further commitments on business, both of a financial nature and of a practical nature in terms of the paper work that is attached to it. We have heard from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) that this Bill is focused on structured training-that key word `structured'-carefully thus eliminating a great deal of practical work-based training. The Minister has also told us that a Bill that applies to any business with a payroll exceeding $200,000 will bring within its scope small businesses with more than eight to 10 employees. I would concede that a business with eight to 10 employees is not necessarily an excessively large business, but it is a very sad state of affairs that such a Bill comes hot on the heels at a time when only last Friday the Australian Financial Review reported forecasts that one in eight current small businesses-that is about 100,000 enterprises-are going to fail. It is good to note that the Government intends to help them along their way!

The business community has also been warned that 60 per cent of enterprises with payrolls above $200,000 spend nothing on formal training. This statement pays no heed to what practical training is being supplied or whether a particular business employee has only fully qualified staff. Clearly, this Bill has a punitive element to it. Later on I will go through some of the areas of business that are currently providing a very good basis of training at their own cost, for which they are not given any credit in this Bill.

Business people will know all too well what is meant when the Minister blandly tells us that they need `to keep appropriate records' for self-assessment under the scheme. That really is purely and simply Keating-speak for business taking on the administrative expense and carrying the can for any errors.

We have seen on so many occasions before that businesses have been penalised. Once again, there was another debate in the Senate only a couple of weeks ago about this. My colleague who spoke just before me, Senator Watson, led a matter of public importance a couple of weeks ago, talking about how businesses had been very seriously affected by very innocent errors made on their tax returns. Of course, business people across Australia will smile grimly when the Minister tells them that `the Government's purpose is not to collect revenue'. It really is a very sick joke.

The coalition opposes this legislation for two basic reasons. Firstly, if Australians want, as a national good, a better trained work force, it is inequitable to expect the cost to be paid by one category of taxpayers-businesses with payrolls exceeding $200,000. Secondly, the bureaucratic and restrictive nature of these Bills will have an unfair effect on so many enterprises, businesses being lumbered with yet another tax because it is politically expedient to do so.

In Western Australia the State Government has lost billions of dollars. Somehow or other it has to recoup some money. The Premier says, `We will not increase this, we will not increase that, we will not increase something else, but we will increase the taxes on businesses'. That is at a State level. Here we have the Federal Government, at this level, doing exactly the same. I suppose that, if one were to be a cynic, one could say that company directors are considered not to be reliable Labor voters and there are not so many of them. Such is the cheap brutal logic of this Hawke Labor Government. I think it is very sad that we have that attitude coming across in so many pieces of legislation.

The same thing applies to the farmers. The farmers are given very little consideration by this Government because it views the farming community as a community that largely does not vote Labor. It is the same with doctors, with dentists, with any of the specialists in medicine, and with the pharmacists. They are not viewed to vote Labor, therefore they are hit for six.

But, unlike the payroll tax, the training levy will not be deductable against company tax, as Senator Watson detailed very succinctly just moments ago. It applies to the total payroll including payments to subcontractors and casual staff. Where is the equity in requiring employers to foot the bill for their supposed training? There is simply no equity in that at all.

It must be emphasised that the application of the levy shows very little discrimination. It applies as much to those enterprises that by their very nature recruit only skilled workers as it does to those who need to train their employees. Public benevolent organisations and religious personnel may be exempt, but schools-hardly profit-making organisations-will be liable for the training levy; so too will nursing homes and local government.

Superficially, a levy of one per cent of a payroll may not seem a large amount-it can be an overworked phrase when debating the actions of the Hawke Labor Government-but, once more, we see the thin end of the wedge. In only two years time the levy will increase to 1.5 per cent of the payroll and there is no guarantee that it will not rise higher in the future. While raising the levy by 0.5 per cent may seem a very minor adjustment, in cold, hard terms it means a 50 per cent increase at the expense of fragile profitability. If the Government needs to know how fragile profitability is with small business these days, I suggest the a few Ministers go out and talk to small business people, because they are suffering.

But the problem is still the same, as I pointed out in a debate last week on small business bankruptcies, and that is, there are too few Government members who really know and understand what business is all about. There are too few members of the Australian Democrats-who are in fact supporting this Bill-who know and understand what business is all about. I think that, almost exclusively, the Democrats are made up of teachers who have never had to go out and fight to pay staff at the end of the week, fight to pay the rent, the telephone bill, the insurance and the other on-costs. They have never had to do that and, therefore, they do not understand what they are doing by supporting this legislation.

I have already noted the Minister's admission that the levy applies to smaller business. Many such smaller businesses operate on slim profit margins, with payrolls exceeding profit levels by only 5 per cent. Thus the one per cent training levy will be a 5 per cent tax on profits and a strong disincentive to employ more staff. I would have hoped, at this stage of the game, that we would be trying to enact legislation in the Senate that would give business more positive reason to employ more staff. We have a current environment where unemployment is going up and yet we have legislation before the Senate today that will ensure that more staff will not be put on.

It is a farce when the Labor Government sends its Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) to make encouraging noises to our beleaguered smaller enterprises and then hits them with this clumsy imposition. How can one, on the one hand, start encouraging businesses and then, on the other hand, slap another tax on them? The Government's real attitude to business emerges in statements such as the one made by one of its backbenchers who said:
No group in Australian society has accepted featherbedding as a right as has the business community in Australia.

Once again, that is clear evidence that the Government does not understand what business is all about. Thus are concerns of business treated with total and utter contempt. I suppose `featherbedding' is Labor's definition of what the rest of us would call simply a chance to survive.

This Government, in fixing an arbitrary figure of $200,000 payrolls for application of the levy, has ignored the fact that State governments exempt smaller business from payroll tax at figures at about this level. In Western Australia, payroll tax is imposed on payrolls exceeding $300,000, but many firms which are exempt from that tax will find themselves paying the new levy. We have already been warned by the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry that business in that State will face a bill of $60m because of the training levy. Worst hit will be service industries with fewer than 100 employees, already faced with taxation, interest and wages costs-all of them courtesy of the Hawke Labor Government.

The reason why so many enterprises will have to pay the levy lies in the blind bureaucratic definition of training that this Bill specifies. As I said before, the bureaucratic nature of this Bill is something that small business is very worried about. Small business is already, by demand, another arm of the Australian Taxation Office and now it will have more paperwork to fill out and more paperwork with which it could make an innocent error for which it will be penalised. Only Ministers devoid of practical business experience would insist upon a definition of structured training that excludes as much as three-quarters of all workplace training. A more honest definition of training would show that average overall training expenditure would reach between 3 and 9 per cent of total payroll. But we are not talking about honesty with this Bill; we are talking about imposts.

The legislation places a strong emphasis upon, in effect, paying employees when they are not working and deliberately excludes the work experience that, in the real world, is so essential to employers and employees alike. I think it is very sad when even the explanatory memorandum to this Bill states on page 4:
When a training program includes on the job training, it may include a period of related, closely supervised practice-
I emphasise that it `may' include it-
However, further periods of generally supervised practice and work experience are not included in an eligible training program.

If that is not absurd, what is? It is getting away from the real world of what business really needs. In taking away the right of management to decide what kind of training best meets the needs of its work force and business, this Labor Government is really putting credentials ahead of competence. Of course, when business does this, it simply goes broke. But, once again, this Government does not seem to mind that. But let there be no suggestion that hands-on training represents training on the cheap-far from it. Supervising an inexperienced employee to carry out productive work involves some loss to the firm in terms of immediate efficiency. Businesses are prepared to do that at the moment, but they are not being given any credit for it in this Bill.

The Chamber of Mines in Western Australia, which represents 120 companies that produce half the State's export income and directly or indirectly account for one job in six, has expressed strong practical concerns as to the restrictive nature of the Bill. On-line training is essential in the real world but, unfortunately, in this Bill we are not really talking about the real world. On-line training is particularly important in the real world of mining with isolated locations and the inability to teach the operation of heavy equipment other than in the field. What would this Government have us do-set up simulators, such as aircraft simulators, in order to try to teach people how to operate equipment out in the minefields? It is absurd. Once again, there is no provision for this practical training to take place.

Last year one major mining company, Hamersley Iron, would have devoted 40,000 hours to on-line training and this Labor Government will give no credit for such an effort. Another major enterprise, Worsley Alumina, bases employee accreditation through on-line skills acquisition. Does this Bill give it credit for that? Not at all. There is a similar situation in the real estate industry. The real estate industry in Western Australia has a statutory responsibility to provide on-the-job training and, accordingly, receives public funding on a State level.

Over 1,000 people were so trained in 1989 with no input from the Federal Government. Now we have this Bill that will put a levy on those businesses. Such training, along with seminars funded by the membership fees of individual firms to the Real Estate Institute of Australia, falls outside the bureaucratic definition of training in this Bill. The cyclical nature of the real estate business also means that training can take place on the basis of 18 months rather than the 12 months requirement of this Bill. But is there any latitude within this Bill to be able to cope with those practicalities? The answer is no. It almost goes without saying that as small businesses, real estate firms will suffer through the administrative burdens alone that the Bill imposes.

One would hope, in these tough economic times, that the Government would be doing everything it could to encourage people to do what they do best in business: get out and make some money. But no, the Government would prefer to have small businesses tied into an office where they have to fill out all the paperwork for such a ridiculous piece of legislation. Not so long ago the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was telling us that we had to become `the clever country'. Yet no recognition is given to the fact that in high technology industries and in such professions as accounting, seminars are the essential means for qualified employees to refine their skills and acquire continued essential knowledge. It makes a mockery of Labor's supposed commitment to technological and professional excellence, that expenditure upon such seminars will not be recognised under this legislation.

Only last week in the Senate, as I said before, the Opposition drew attention to the fact that the Hawke Labor Government had failed the small business sector through its mismanagement of the economy. With these Bills the Government again proves us right, demonstrating once more an uncaring ignorance of the practical needs of businesses, large and small alike. Again I say it is very sad that so few people on the Government side have ever had to experience the pain necessary to stay afloat in business. Many of us on this side have done that. We know what it is all about. We know what these additional levies and so forth mean in real practical terms. So long as the Labor Government, with the support of the Democrats, presumes to levy another tax on business on the basis of a dishonest definition of training, Australia will undoubtedly lack both economic growth and a truly competent work force. I certainly encourage the Democrats to have a rethink about this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not here, as usual.

—That is right. But I hope that before this Bill goes to a vote they will see the light; they will understand and comprehend what they are really doing to business, and they will try to talk to some business people who will be affected by this legislation. We need a competent work force and we need businesses to have the ability to get on and make some money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my Liberal colleague Senator Knowles said a few moments ago, the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990 and the Training Guarantee Bill 1990 clearly demonstrate that the present Government is out of touch with the real world, largely because it lacks people with practical business experience, particularly in the small business sector. That is not surprising.
—You make the same speech every week.

—It needs to be reinforced. Perhaps some of the Government people, when it is reinforced often enough, might get the message and engage in some practical legislation and government that is of some benefit to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Those criticisms that Senator Knowles made are not surprising because this legislation clearly demonstrates the extent of trade union control over this Government and its clear commitment to the corporate state of big government, big unions and big business. This particular proposal for a training guarantee levy, which is introduced by the legislation, is lifted straight from the document Australia Reconstructed, which was published about three years ago. The Australia Reconstructed document published by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Trade Development Council sought to further entrench the unions' privileged position under this Hawke Labor Government. Among the recommendations in that document was the establishment of a national employment training fund to be financed by a tax on companies.

The Senate should be reminded that a major part of the work on Australian Reconstructed was undertaken by Mr Ted Wilshire, of the Trade Development Council. Ted Wilshire has been closely associated with Ted Wheelwright, one of the founders of the Marxist political economy course at the University of Sydney. If we look at the membership of the group that put the document together, we see that Wilshire would have received much support for his views from the old guard left wing of other members of the joint ACTU-Trade Development mission that visited Europe when preparing this document. These include Tom McDonald of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia-the successor to Pat Clancy of the pro-Soviet Communist Party; Laurie Carmichael of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union-an ex-communist and born again socialist; and Colin Cooper of the left wing Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. Let us be in no doubt as to the source of this legislation.

It is sad to see the Government succumb to this left wing pressure for centralisation at a time when decentralised decision making is becoming more and more essential. For our part, the Opposition is not opposed, in principle, either to the concept of enhanced training in the workplace or to a more highly skilled and multiskilled work force. If the reshaping of Australian industry is to succeed, innovative ways of training, retraining and assessment will have to be introduced. Technical and further education in no small way has led with its large off campus enrolments. The Liberal and National parties have led the debate that improvements in both the efficiency and international competitiveness of Australian industry must take place. However, we are vigorously opposed to this legislation and the detrimental effects it will have if it passes through this place. Those effects will be detrimental to all businesses, large and small.

After only a few days into what will surely be the Government's last term in office, already it is setting itself up for its first, but certainly not its last, confrontation with the business sector. The business community which this proposed legislation targets totally rejects the statistics and other purported evidence which the Government is using to justify this legislation. The Government has based much of its argument for the need for this training levy on a survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) late last year. While this survey found that less than one in four Australian companies spent any money on formal training, its definition of training was as narrow as that used in this legislation. In other words, as Senator Knowles said a few moments ago, no recognition of on-the-job training and other informal training arrangements was taken account of in this survey. Indeed, the ABS survey specifically excluded on-the-job training such as, as is stated in the concise guide to the ABS 1990 training expenditure survey:
Exclude unstructured on-the-job training such as being shown how to do things as the need arises, learning by doing a job, for example an apprentice mechanic who is shown a task on the job.

The ABS survey and the legislation which we are debating today which is based on it, therefore specifically exclude the type of training that is most widely used in the small business sector and which is generally accepted as being the most efficient. The Government's intended measure, relating to both large and small business organisations, is nothing more or less than a special tax on a limited number of Australian companies in order to finance and enforce a level of training on them and their employees. This legislation discriminates against a select section of our community bearing the financial burden of training, which is, after all, benefiting the whole community.

This Bill, which the Government is ramming down all our throats, is just another tax. The Government is wanting to ensure its passage because it is intended to have it up and running by 1 July this year-little more than 30 days away. The training guarantee levy is a proposal for employers to spend a minimum of one per cent of their payrolls on training, under strict definitions, from 1 July this year. The levy will apply to all employers, and to government departments as well, which have payrolls of more than $200,000 a year. The compulsory scheme will, in fact, mean a new round of tax audits for industry members. After two years, if those companies which have been levied are still in business, the floor price will rise to 1.5 per cent with provision for some industries to face an even higher minimum.

Those companies which are still clinging on and just surviving this Government-caused recession-and a range of other devastating government taxes and charges-will have to submit themselves to a scheme administered by the Australian Taxation Office, after, it appears, the Minister failed to persuade the States to collect the levy via their own payroll taxation systems. What will happen to those companies which are unable to meet the minimum obligation required of them through the legislation? They will have their funds diverted by the Taxation Office to the States for training purposes and, no doubt, will be swallowed up by bureaucratic administration. One might be forgiven for believing that we are actually living in modern-day Australia.

These companies' funds will be diverted by the Australian Taxation Office. It is obvious that this Labor Government is well on its way to taxing business to the brink of extinction. This is how it pursues its reform in the business sector. The Government simply taxes one to death. At least the legislation has been amended to somewhat reduce the role to be played by the Australian Taxation Office. Its role is now, apparently, reduced to that of auditing companies annually to ensure that they comply with the requirements of the legislation.

If smaller businesses are unable to meet this minimum training obligation and are consequently forced to meet the compliance costs of this levy, there is no doubt at all that the small business sector, already undergoing immense and significant cash flow problems, may well cave in under the pressure. It is no secret that bankruptcies throughout Australia are on the rise. Between the 1988-89 and 1989-90 financial years, this country saw a 27 per cent increase in the number of bankruptcies nation-wide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty-four per cent in Western Australia.

—We have a dreadful State Labor Government in Western Australia, as well as a Federal Labor Government, so the figure for Western Australia is 84 per cent, as Senator Knowles says. Daily, numerous stories catch the eye which relate to the collapse of people's livelihoods. The impediment of Government charges, rates and regulations in the business sector is more than crippling-it is humiliating and disgraceful for a nation claiming that it is on its way to being the clever country. Australia's total tax bill now sits at about $91.3. billion a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is claiming that significant disparities exist between the training effort of the private and public sector employers and between large and small businesses. It is suggested that most employers are getting a free ride at the expense of both the larger companies and the public sector.

Let us look at the parameters the Government has set under this legislation. A small business is one which more accurately, could be described as employing up to 20 people in the service sector and up to 100 people in the manufacturing sector-a business which is independently owned and managed and in which the owner or the proprietor is the main decision-maker. The figure of $200,000 has been randomly selected as the payroll threshold below which no company will be required to participate in this industry levy scheme. This in itself is the biggest hoodwink that we have seen all week. No doubt, $200,000 was chosen as the threshold because the Government will lose fewer votes this way. It will not have to ask too many smaller businesses to cough up vast sums of money and join in the training party. There would be many small businesses whose payroll is below $200,000, which, if the scheme has any justification, should be part of the training levy in any fair-minded manner of assessment. They should be asked to contribute to training costs. It is clearly a political decision to exclude that group.

From my own dealings with businesses, both large and small, it is clear that very little consultation has taken place regarding this levy. Whilst most do not oppose the fundamentals of enhanced training, many have questioned the propriety of businesses having the responsibility of training totally foist upon them. The chief executive of the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, Mr Bert Evans, has been extremely vocal about the negative effects which these measures will have on businesses. He said:

Companies burdened with high interest rates and uncertain markets, see the proposed levy as another impost which could further erode their viability. They do not see it as a positive measure aimed at increasing workplace training, so much as an additional tax.

Mr Evans also said that since the proposal to introduce the training levy on employers was first raised, the Association's offices across the country had been inundated with calls from very angry business people concerned about the levy's effects on their businesses. This Bill will, in effect, tax the heart out of every single company which has a payroll of more than $200,000, irrespective of whether it offers any one-on-one training, and irrespective of whether the nature of its business requires it to recruit and to employ untrained people and then to train them. A company's size has become its own beast of burden.

This Bill does nothing at all to promote training designed specifically for the small business person or the needs of that particular industry group. The keystone of the legislation focuses on centralised, large-scale training efforts, whereas the requirements of small business reflect a very different set of needs and circumstances. What this means for the small business arena is greater emphasis on work experience and hands-on training skills which are crucial to this sector's survival. The crux of the matter is: Why is the Government reluctant to treat the needs of small business differently than larger businesses for the purposes of this training levy? Why should small businesses be coerced to contribute towards a levy to help fund a centralised training scheme, which by the Government's very own admission cannot hope to accommodate or cater to the special needs of the small business community?

The Government is simply wedded to its large-scale, centralist approach, consistent with a corporate State mentality. There are specific problems which arise from this legislation: Firstly, it encourages structured training at the cost of dismissing a broad-banded, and perhaps more effective skills formation. The definition of eligible training is too limited.

A one-on-one approach to training is unstructured and relies heavily on the personal interaction between the skilled person and the learner. Further it is tailored to suit the needs of the employer as well as employees to suit the individual business perfectly. Industry and small business have found this to be the preferred form of training. It is usually extremely efficient, especially when the instructor can impart knowledge well. This is completely ignored in this legislation.

Secondly, it would promote an inequitable distribution of the training effort between employers. Those companies not required to participate in the training and the levy could see themselves as being slightly competitively advantaged. Some companies would, no doubt, consider that they will have done well by not having to outlay vast sums of money on staff training; while their larger rivals will be caught in the threshold net. Thirdly, many additional costs will be incurred through the administration of the levy, especially for smaller scale operations. Fourthly, there is no provision for a company to carry forward any of its excess expenditure from one year to the next. Fifthly, companies with a training expenditure far in excess of the required amount cannot off-set the levy shortfall in a sister company.

Finally, there is inadequate lead time allowed for employers and training institutions to assess training requirements resulting from the award restructuring process, which is now under way. As 1 July straddles the academic year, one must surely speculate what effect will this have on mid-year enrolments. Surely 1 January 1991 would reflect a more adequate planning framework.

This Government has made a gross error of judgment if it believes that small business owners, who fall just inside the levy's net, will accept blindly that a great proportion of the training provided by them counts for nothing.

All in all, the impact of this legislation and its administrative detail, is very unclear. For instance, it does not clearly deal with the scheme's impact on the complex structures under which industries and the professions exist. Nor does the scheme precisely identify the reporting procedures which will be required, or the precise roles of the proposed national training board, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Australian Taxation Office.
The President of the Law Council of Australia has expressed great concern about the legislation's vagueness. He said:

The Law Council is concerned that the scheme, as presently drafted, may distort and undermine the very objective which it seeks to achieve . . . The Law Council strongly objects to legislation by guideline. That sort of legislation leads to confusion, avoids proper scrutiny by Parliament, and is not in the public interest.

The outcomes of negotiations within industry restructuring are, because of this confused Government, being regarded with great uncertainty by both commerce and industry in many sectors. The Government thinks that by introducing an industry training levy it can legislate away the problems it has created.

We have many examples within industry of the effects of the new restructuring. To avoid further industrial problems, tradespeople have been upgraded, but in name only, to `tradespeople, special class'. Essentially, industry restructuring means the substantial changing of work structures across an industry through altered industrial awards and agreements which allow new approaches to work organisation to be implemented. These changes should allow for greater worker flexibility, reductions in demarcations between jobs, and the establishment of clear career paths within industries. They require more broadly based training programs with study paths linked to career paths, resulting in multiskilled workers and the possibility of different components of industrial training being connected instead of being in separate boxes.

Restructuring has been forced upon us because, many would argue, Australians have been enjoying the fruits of the lucky country for a little too long. We are told by those who know these things that we as a nation are about to embark on a journey which will lead us to be the so-called clever country.

However, Australia has embraced industry restructuring for a number of reasons: Firstly, as a result of the increased sophistication of world markets; secondly, because of the introduction of new technology; thirdly, because of cheaper costs of labour in nearby, more competitive countries; and, fourthly, because of the need to achieve greater productivity than has been possible under the old structures and regimes.

The new approaches to work organisation which result from restructuring emphasise high quality, increased flexibility and competitive product prices. But restructuring is not just about getting wage increases. It is about job redesign, lifelong training, career opportunities, multiskilling, quality and efficiency, and job satisfaction.

Three crucial areas in which this nation is deeply inadequate are service, quality and our attitude towards exports. Our approaches to quality, can be heard across, the nation with a resounding `She'll be right, mate'. Unfortunately, unless we have a commitment to quality, this will most certainly turn into `She's worse!'.

Unless this industry training levy addresses these and other issues, we will continue to be a nation offering poor service and having a bad reputation as a reliable exporter. This legislation will not solve those problems.

Restructuring presents a fundamental challenge to Australian business and industry. Should the approach be taken in levity, our nation will suffer. Had the Government been realistic about safeguarding small businesses, it should have at least allowed a more realistic exemption level. The Government has displayed its complete heartlessness and insensitivity to the problems this levy will have on the small business sector throughout Australia.

In summary, while the Opposition supports the need for more training and updating of skills in the workplace, we oppose strongly the concept of an enforced level of expenditure for one sector of business, regardless of its own needs for training or ability to pay. This legislation is yet another tax against employment and will make a mockery of this Government's claim it will improve levels of employment.

This tax will cause enormous financial hardship to many businesses already burdened with a large range of government taxes and charges, not to mention high interest rates and an uncertain economy which, thanks to this Government's mismanagement, is fast disappearing down the gurgler. The government already tells businesses who they can hire, what they can pay them and who they may or may not merge with. Now it wants to regulate how a business trains its employees.

In short, this whole thing smacks of the big brother tactics which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his ACTU mates have been employing so assiduously in recent years. The inconsistencies in principle and practice which will arise from this Bill can lead only to the conclusion that it should be thrown out. As I mentioned during Senator Knowles's speech, the Australian Democrats are not here listening to this important debate on this legislation. If they are listening in their rooms, I urge them to join with the Opposition and throw out this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990. Much of the detail of the objections the Opposition has to this Bill has been outlined in a very succinct and eloquent way by my colleagues, so I will restrict myself ever so briefly to some general comments. I think it is a widely held view in Australia that, if we are to become more competitive internationally and be able to compete for the domestic market against import penetration, there is a very real need for Australian industry to become more efficient, and particularly for our work force to become more effective and more skilled. It is my view, and I think it is a correct view, that Australia lags behind the rest of our trading partners in terms of both skills and human resources. We certainly lag behind in terms of loyalty between employer and employee, which in my view is an intrinsic part of natural on-the-job training.

SPEECH.PARA: While we might make much of revitalising the manufacturing sector, of making our tertiary sector more sophisticated, of the need for downstream processing of our natural resources, they will lead to nought if we do not have a more innovative, educated, sophisticated and certainly a more skilled work force. This Bill allegedly seeks to address that problem. It can be argued reasonably that this skill level will inevitably develop and mature as a product of natural market forces and that natural market forces will be the engine room of innovation, change and improvement in skills. But the evidence thus far does not inexorably lead to that conclusion.

There are very compelling reasons for employers not to provide adequate training to their work force under an absolutely voluntary arrangement. Of course, an employer will weigh the benefits to his enterprise against the costs of training his employees. Whereas the costs to the economy as a whole are substantially the same as the costs to the enterprise, the benefits to the economy as a whole are substantially greater than the benefits to individual firms, particularly in Australia where we have such a mobile work force. Perhaps, instead of putting forward this legislation, that is something the Government ought to be looking at. One of the great difficulties of a mobile work force is that there is a very considerable resistance on the part of employers to train employees because inevitably the benefit accrues not to the employer who is doing the training but to an employer elsewhere.

Accordingly, the balance that will be struck by an employer in terms of the level of training he is going to provide to his employees will not be the optimum; in fact, it will be below the optimum. The level of training he will give his employees will be exclusively an economic consideration-what is likely to bring the best benefit for the least dollars, not what is going to provide him with the best skilled work force. So inevitably the level of training will be below the optimum.

Likewise it follows that when individual firms are forced into levels of training that might be optimum for the economy the benefits will not flow to the employer. The levels required are not commensurate with the cost to the individual company.
