Even though all firms, taken collectively, might experience gains from a higher level of training in the community or by skill enhancement, much of the gain to any individual firm will result from the endeavours and the level of training undertaken by other firms' outlays. So it is not an unreasonable proposition to put that at the end of the day a voluntary or market-driven scheme may create some disincentive. However, I quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray):

The Government favours this scheme partly because it will not penalise those companies which have recognised the value of training and invest in it accordingly. For firms that already train above the required minimum level it will have no direct financial impact. The Training Guarantee is in fact a charge on the failure to train.

While that may be so, the economic deficiencies or flaws in this legislation will mean that there will be no incentive for any firm to train staff above the threshold. In other words, no benefit will accrue to any individual firm and there will be no reward or incentive to train above the 1.5 per cent threshold. Once that percentage is arrived at, there is no economic benefit for any company to provide greater outlays.

Perhaps the best example of the economic illiteracy of this proposition is the way that it is so selective and absolutely arbitrary. Those employers with a payroll of $200,000 or less will be required to make no contribution to the skills of the Australian work force. Interestingly enough, and perhaps cynically so, that represents 85 per cent of all of Australia's employers and 25 per cent of all Australia's employees. In other words, 25 per cent of Australia's work force is quarantined from further skill enhancement, further opportunities of acquiring talents, new abilities, new confidences and new levels of skills simply because the Government has made an arbitrary political decision to remove 85 per cent of employers from this scheme.

It is a political decision which does not have a shred of economic integrity whatsoever. Clearly, the decision has been made because this Government is not about offending, upsetting or antagonising 85 per cent of employers. Thus, as a result of a politically expedient decision, the Government has cast 25 per cent of the work force onto the scrapheap leaving those employees no opportunity to compete with employees of companies that come within the scheme.

I am reminded of Hawke's great statement about putting Australia first. He said that he would be making no economically expedient decisions, that he would govern for all Australians, that if the hard decisions had to be made he would make them and that he would not opt for the soft option. He is the great economic rationalist. Does anybody really wonder why Peter Walsh retreated to the back bench?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Please refer to the Prime Minister and other senators by their proper titles.

—I am ever so sorry. Thank you for chiding me, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Peter Walsh retreated to the back bench because somebody he described as Old Jellyback did not have the courage, the fortitude or the commitment to put in place the disciplines in this society and economy that are necessary if we are to lift the standard of living of all people.
—I never thought I would see the day when you would support Senator Walsh.

—My Acting Deputy President, you can be certain that I am not supporting Senator Walsh. I am simply observing that he retreated because, to use his words, this Government did not have the guts to make the hard decisions, he retreated because, to use his words, this Government missed major opportunities for micro-economic reform in its third term. He said that he would have to wait and see whether or not it would have the courage and fortitude to make them in the fourth term. From what we have seen thus far, it does not. The Government has abrogated all the commitments, obligations and imprimatur given to it by the people at the last election. Without question, I know that we are going to have a fourth term of lost opportunities and then, no doubt, this Government will be driven into the wilderness.

SPEECH.PARA: I am no defender of big business, but let me say this: in terms of looking at the economic distortions in this legislation, big business will now be subsidising small business even more than it presently does. I quote from an Australian Bureau of Statistics survey:

Based on a survey of 2000 employers . . . expenditure on training increased as the number of employees increased (e.g. employers with an annual gross wages and salary of $200,000 or more [this is the threshold for liability under the Bill] spent an estimated 2.4% on gross wages and salaries while those with an annual gross wages and salary cost below this level spent an estimated 0.9% on training).

In other words, those to whom this legislation is directed are already spending 2.4 per cent and small business, which is excluded, is spending 0.9 per cent. What will that do? That will lead only to greater poaching. Take the case of two businesses which are opposite each other. Company A will have an obligation to provide a minimum level of funding to train its employees and enhance their skills. Company B in competition across the road will have no obligation to provide training and, therefore, its cost of labour per unit is going to be less. All that company B has to do is wait until company A has trained and skilled its staff, go across the road, offer the employees greater salaries for their greater skills-that cost of which is carried by company A-and put them on its payroll. So company B will be able to poach the skills at not cost to itself. This situation will result from a deliberate decision in this legislation made on the basis of crude political expediency.

In many respects, this legislation is a windfall for some employers because it guarantees a pool of skilled labour paid for by one sector of the community for the benefit of another sector. While there might be some economic justification for deferral on the basis of hardship or longevity, there is no excuse in my mind for not having any even playing field. It could be argued that it is administratively possible to defer payment, on the basis of hardship, for training and the acquisition of a certain level of skills in the long term. But there is absolutely no logical economic explanation-and I beg the Minister to say something about this-for quarantining 25 per cent of the work force from the acquisition of skills.

As I said earlier, there is no incentive for companies to train above the threshold level. I imagine that it is not beyond the wit of this Government, although most other things are, to provide some sort of arrangement for companies to carry over credits. There needs to be a flattening out process. Companies which are going through certain economic circumstances need to be given an opportunity to operate with some continuity so that they can deal with the difficult economic climate with which we are presently confronted.

This Bill should be referred to a committee for all the reasons which have been set out by my colleagues. I shall not retrace their argument but the anomalies have been adequately demonstrated by Senator Knowles, Senator Chapman and ever so many others during this debate. If this Government were serious about ensuring that we have equity, equality, an even playing field and an enhanced and skilled work force for all employers, it would have no reservations about or objections to referring this legislation to a committee that could look at the various anomalies which have been adequately pointed out. We have learned to understand all of this Government's ideological rigorous pursuits. The Government is determined to ensure that this legislation goes through in the face of those anomalies, notwithstanding the enormous economic difficulties that they will impose on a great many companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak at length in response at this particular stage. I think I will leave most of the argument for the committee stage. I will make a couple of points before going on to some of the matters raised by the Opposition. I think it has to be put on the record that the objective of this legislation is to increase skill output in Australia. If we are really dinkum about matching the world, there is obviously a necessity to do that, and the mechanisms provided in this legislation are very much geared towards ensuring that that happens. I think it was only the other day that I gave figures in the Senate about the levels of expenditure in education and research in this country. I noted that, whereas we may be standing in the top three worldwide on higher education expenditure on the public level, on the private level we are very far behind. SPEECH.PARA: Specific problems have been raised by the Opposition. I think it is fair to say that one point was that the guarantee imposes a tax on a very small group of employers. The continuation of that point was that these costs should be borne by the community. As I have indicated, the community already bears a substantial cost for education and training through the public provision of education and training services. With the exemption of small business, of course, we have also made another small group of exemptions. I have no doubt that the new Senate Standing Committee on the Selection of Bills would have clearly identified that this legislation should go to a Senate committee.

I would imagine that this would be the appropriate time for such legislation to be referred to a committee. There has been a very strong division of opinion as to whether this legislation should proceed at all. That had to be resolved before it can usefully be referred to a committee. The Senate has now decided to proceed with the legislation, and it clearly requires very detailed committee consideration.

Unfortunately, the Australian Democrats have made it very clear that they are absolutely hell-bent on getting this legislation through and into place as soon as possible. Because the Opposition has been aware of that likelihood, it has been considering what options would be available to it. Unfortunately, the new Sessional Orders have not come into place and, therefore, we have to move a special motion in order to get this into a committee. Clearly, from the second reading debate, a large number of deficiencies have been identified in this Bill. Many of those deficiencies cannot really be satisfactorily dealt with by amendments. There would probably be-I do not say hundreds of amendments-a large number of amendments which would lead to an endless debate in the Committee of the Whole.

The trouble with this legislation is that it has not been properly thought through. It has not been properly discussed with industry. I know the Government says that is has been discussing it with industry. The fact is that the original Bill was unveiled only at the end of last year. There has been the usual summer sleep that occurs in Australia, and then we got moved into an election mode, and the Bill has been suddenly resurrected and changes made to it as a result of some consultation, but I do not believe anything like the sort of consultation that would normally be required.

Whole areas of this legislation do require a great deal of evidence being given to senators to learn about how training is in fact conducted in Australia. One of the great deficiencies of this Bill is that it has just been assumed that training is desirable for everybody in any circumstances, and clearly there should be some examination of why it is that numbers of employers do not train or do not train as much as others. That really goes to the heart of this legislation, and that is something that a Senate committee would be very well able to look at.

Also, whole major areas of this legislation have yet to be determined. Guidelines by the Minister are having to be brought in before this Bill can be fully brought into operation. Those are the sorts of things that ought to be before a committee for consideration.

Another great weakness of the Bill is the confusion that it creates in the tax position of a lot of these expenditures and a lot of the expenditures on training. This whole scheme seems to be being brought in without any real consideration of the impact and of the increased confusion in the taxation field.

For all those reasons, I strongly support the motion that this Bill should go to a committee-and, of course, the appropriate committee is clearly the one I have mentioned: the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training.

During the previous process-more than one year ago-small businesses were asked to make submissions to the Employment and Skills Formation Council. I am informed that a whole raft of propositions were put to the Council by small businesses on the mailing list. This is a tripartite Council representing business as well as employers and unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they have this document in front of them?

TALK.START.PARA: -The generosity of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is fantastic. TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Legal Aid Amendment Bill 1990 makes technical amendments to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Act 1977. The amendments are necessary as a consequence of an agreement between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory that the proposed Northern Territory Legal Aid Commission take over the operations of the Australian Legal Aid Office in the Northern Territory on 1 July 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: It amends the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act in such a way as to ensure that part IV of the Act applies to officers of the Australian Legal Aid Office who transfer to the proposed Northern Territory Legal Aid Commission. My colleagues have made the point that this is sloppy drafting and there are alternative ways to achieve the same end without simply fiddling around with the definition of a State. I am not sure how far back this practice goes, but at least it is found in the Ombudsman Act 1976, in the Public Works Committee amendments in 1981, in the supported accommodation assistance package in 1989, in the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Amendment Bill in 1989 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill in 1989. In conclusion, the Opposition supports this Bill and underlines the need for technically efficient and clear drafting.

They represent not only people who are well off, but also those who could be called the coppertails of this world, the everyman and the everywoman who need legal aid desperately to vindicate their rights in the community. They have established a legal culture which is to be admired and bring credit to the profession in a way that is unique. The legal profession has been much criticised over the years and is criticised quite vigorously at the moment, in many ways unfairly. This is an occasion to pay proper tribute to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank those members of the Senate who have contributed to the debate on this important Bill, the Commonwealth Legal Aid Amendment Bill. DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Great Barrier Reef is one of those issues on which there is a bipartisan approach by the Government and the Opposition and always has been. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill is therefore supported by the Opposition. It proposes to amend the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 by providing for the inclusion of several definitions which will clarify the operation of the marine park zoning plans which govern how the park may be used or entered.

SPEECH.PARA: These changes are needed because of a decision by a magistrate in December last year involving a ferry operator who was taking tourists to Green Island without a permit. The provision of a tourist program requires permission but the operation and navigation of vessels does not. He said he was operating and navigating a vessel, not running a tourist operation. The decision by the magistrate is subject to appeal, but the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority does not wish to wait for the outcome of the appeal to clarify the matter.

Additional regulations were gazetted in February 1990, but their effect is not certain. The other alternative is to amend the Cairns section zoning plan, but this would require the laying of the proposal before both Federal chambers. There is concern that in the estimated nine months or so that this could take there may be damage to the park from a big increase in visitors to the island using this loophole in the law.

The Queensland Government has no objection to the amendment and the Queensland tourist industry, to my knowledge, does not oppose the Bill and neither do we. However, I would just say in passing that some concerns are being expressed about some aspects of maintenance of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. This related to permission granted by the Government to P &O Australia Ltd, which had been given permission to dump rubbish. To my knowledge it was the only island resort entitled to dump rubbish in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

I understand that P &O have ceased dumping and will dispose of the waste on the mainland for a two-month trial period which is to be monitored by the Marine Park Authority. I stress the importance of this, because this dumping, according to the department, presented significant environmental difficulties. That was contained in advice from the Authority to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It reinforced earlier advice about the effects of the existing sea dumping regime at Heron Island.

The Authority was concerned primarily about the attraction of silver gulls and the predation by these birds on other seabird populations. There was also concern for human safety resulting from the sharks that are attracted to and consume the garbage and concern about the precedent for allowing dumping in other areas of the marine park. I must say I do hope that P &O-which, as I said, is the only organisation allowed to dump in the park-will have a successful program of dumping the waste on the mainland and that after this two-month period dumping rights on the reef will cease. I have no doubt the Opposition and the Government will have a bipartisan view on that matter as well. But we certainly have a bipartisan view on this Bill and we support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Michael Baume's comments which, quite properly, are given in support of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill. That reflects the bipartisan view of all those involved in the national Parliament that the Great Barrier Reef ought to be managed and protected to preserve its beauty, accessibility and the wonder of it for future generations not only of Australians, but also the inhabitants of the planet into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, there is no intention to change any of the zoning plans which are set down in the major Act, but it is intended to clarify the original intention of the Parliament which, quite clearly, was to ensure that certain activities are able to be undertaken only with permissions granted. There is a presumption that permissions are to be granted and regulation might go to the point of forbidding certain activities which may have a detrimental impact on the marine park of the Great Barrier Reef. I appreciate the support given by the Opposition and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of these two Bills relates to the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement, which agreement was the culmination of a landmark decision and negotiations by the Fraser Government. The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to bring certain other bounty Acts in line with that agreement to get rid of the bounty which is paid with regard to goods which are exported to New Zealand, again in accordance with that agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill seeks directly to prohibit the payment of a bounty on equipment or goods produced which will be exported to New Zealand, either directly or indirectly through another country. The Bill amends the Bounty (Books) Act, the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act, the Bounty (Computers) Act, and the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act.

In the House of Representatives Mr Prosser raised a concern as to whether goods which were transshipped through New Zealand, or off-loaded in New Zealand for distribution to other Pacific nations, would be exempt from the bounty. But the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), in his second reading speech, appears to state that the prohibition on the bounty will not extend to goods exported through New Zealand to those other destinations.

The Bill makes some technical changes to the existing bounty Acts to overcome omissions in the initial drafting of the legislation. An example is the amendment to the Bounty (Ships) Act. As the Act currently stands, only those direct material costs incurred by the shipbuilder for goods actually incorporated in the vessel or its modification are eligible for the bounty. This means in turn that there are a number of costs of consumables which are not eligible costs and this Bill corrects the anomaly by allowing bounty eligibility for the costs of consumables such as welding gas, welding rods and grinding discs.

Similarly, with regard to the Bounty (Books) Act currently the full bounty is not payable on the production run of a particular book until all books in that production run have been bound. This is a problem for producers who bind and put on hold and put onto the market only a proportion of the production run and keep the remainder in storage until a later date. This Bill provides for producers to submit bounty claims as each batch is bound. That should discourage the practice of small production runs merely to claim the bounty, where a larger production run would be more appropriate. We support that Bill.

The Trade Practices (Misuse of Trans-Tasman Market Power) Bill relates to the implementation of article 4 of the protocol to the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement on the acceleration of free trade. The Opposition also supports this Bill but has some concerns which I think are worthy of being raised. The Acts which this Bill amends are the Trade Practices Act, the Anti-Dumping Authority Act, the Customs Act, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, the Evidence Act, the Federal Court of Australia Act and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-Vesting) Act. The 1983 agreement originally had a target date of 1995 for the establishment of free trade between the two countries. In 1988 a review of the agreement was conducted and it was decided to bring that date forward to 1 July 1990.

New Zealand is now Australia's third largest export market after Japan and the United States of America, taking some 5.1 per cent of our total exports. Similarly, with Japan and the United States, Australia is one of New Zealand's largest export markets, taking 15 per cent of New Zealand's exports.

This Bill can be seen as an interim step in the harmonisation of the business law. However, there are no provisions in the Bill which seek to establish uniform laws between Australia and New Zealand in the area of competition or anti-monopolistic provisions. Those things will not be considered until 1992. New Zealand is mirroring this legislation. The New Zealand legislation includes the Commerce Law Reform Bill and the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill and the New Zealand Government is also confident of meeting the 1 July target.

The obvious aim of closer economic relations is to allow free trade to exist between Australia and New Zealand. But there are a couple of reservations which are provided for which perhaps mitigate the concept of free trade. We simply raise them so that people are aware of them.

The first reservation is that the relevant goods must originate in Australia or New Zealand. In Australia the test to establish this fact is whether the last process of manufacture is performed in New Zealand and whether or not 50 per cent of the factory or work cost was represented by labour and materials of Australia or New Zealand.

A further reservation contained in the August 1988 protocol on trade and services excludes some sections of activity from the operations of closer economic relations. In Australia those sectors to be excluded represent industries such as the media, telecommunications, banking, airport services, domestic air services and coastal shipping. Many could argue that they are just the sectors which ought to be subject to and could benefit from further competition.

As I said in the beginning, the Opposition does support the Bill and recognises that to implement article 4 of the protocol it is necessary to get rid of the anti-dumping provisions and to deal with the question of market power in another way; in our case it is under the Trade Practices Act. This is the purpose of this Bill. The target date for the Bill of 1 July 1990 has been quite artificially deemed to be an important date. The Government seems to be taking the view that it is less important to achieve harmonised and uniform laws in the narrow context of competition than it is to produce legislation to meet this date. It is curious given that the protocol allows for the date to be altered, and of course 1992 now becomes the date for harmonisation.

There are, however, disparities between our legislation and the equivalent New Zealand legislation. Here, upon the removal of anti-dumping measures, which will be the only sanction against predatory market practices, under our proposed section 46a of the Trade Practices Act and the New Zealand equivalent, section 36a of its Commerce Act, there is a disparity between definitions of what is market power. The difference means that it may be easier to substantiate a breach of competition provisions in Australia than it is in New Zealand. The Australian provision has a test of `substantial degree of market power', which has been held by the Federal Court to mean as little as 30 per cent, whereas in contrast the New Zealand test of `a dominant degree of market power' has been interpreted as meaning something in the vicinity of 80 per cent. In the Australian Bill the proposed section allows the court to determine the question of degree of market power by `inference from the conduct of the Corporation or any other person or from other relevant circumstances', but there is no equivalent provision in the New Zealand Bill. This disparity could well impact on the conduct and presentation of matters before the court.

In the other place the shadow Attorney-General raised concerns about the operation of the existing section 46 of the Trade Practices Act which regulates anti-competitive acts and market power. His concern was with the definition and meaning of `substantial degree of market power'. The section has been the subject of a review by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which has recommended that the section does not need to be amended. The High Court of Australia has given guidance concerning application of the section in the Queensland Wire Industries Pty Ltd case where it was noted that the aim of the section was to protect consumers by protecting the competitive process. Professor Baxt of the Trade Practices Commission has implied that the cost and complexity of proceedings under section 46, and by extension the proposed section 46a, could deter its effective use by private parties. In the House on 17 May the responsible Minister, Mr Duffy, said that Professor Baxt's comments had been superseded by a review of the Trade Practices Commission following the Queensland Wire Industries case. Mr Duffy said:
The result of that review was that provision of a guideline on the workings of section 46, in line with Professor Baxt no longer calling for a review . . .
It will be interesting to monitor the judicial interpretation in light of the comments and the contrary view of the shadow Attorney-General that there is some need for reform.

As concerns the financial impact of the changed arrangements, $146,000 will be provided to the Trade Practices Commission for the employment of two extra staff. It seems a little ironical that, in trying to bring about trade which is freer than hitherto, we are in fact increasing the size of the bureaucracy.

With the replacement of the anti-dumping laws by competition laws comes the transfer in litigation costs. Whereas with anti-dumping laws the state has borne the cost associated with that litigation, under the arrangements which will be the order of the day when this legislation goes through the cost will be transferred to private parties. In his second reading speech the Attorney-General indicated that the Trade Practices Commission would take into account the expense that complainants would incur where necessary as private parties to commence proceedings.

A few other matters are dealt with in the Bill concerning evidence, the admissibility of evidence and the need for amendments to allow for the reciprocal registration and enforcement of interim and final orders made in each court in a trans-Tasman market proceeding, which of course is most important.

Overall we believe that it is important that both the costs and efficiency of the proposed regime being introduced by this Bill against alleged anti-competitive practices should be closely monitored. The Opposition is of the view that it is crucial for the scheme to be scrutinised in the future to ensure that remaining administrative or market impediments to free trade and open competition are identified and then eradicated. It should thus be understood that this Bill is to be an interim measure to be reviewed in the context of the 1992 review on the harmonisation of trans-Tasman business law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I do have a couple of questions arising from the legislation, in particular one that relates to a Bill that went through the other day-the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill-which allowed for capitalisation of the bounty. Where capitalisation has been granted under the new scheme provided for under what will become the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Act, and the manufacturer who has sought and received capitalisation has not been an exporter to New Zealand but subsequently becomes an exporter to New Zealand, will that exporter now comply with the legislation that is before us in the particular and, indeed, with the protocol itself?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that that particular legislation is a one-off measure which will not affect the legislation that is currently going through the chamber.

—I find that does not really answer the problem. People who are presently exporters of yarn and are in receipt of a bounty are eligible for the capitalisation scheme. If such a person, having been eligible for the receipt of a bounty, subsequently becomes an exporter of yarn to New Zealand, is that to be construed in any way as there having been a bounty paid, in respect of the export, albeit in advance, by way of the capitalisation scheme, and therefore does it comply with this legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question is yes. The capitalisation arrangements in fact are in place of any future bounties that the exporter might receive. Exporters will not be receiving any future bounties and therefore that arrangement does not conflict with this legislation.

—I realise that, but the capitalisation is in respect of future bounty payable and the bounty payable is in respect of the existing capacity and that existing capacity, which could have been going to any export market other than New Zealand, and for which the bounty is being paid in advance, if you like, by way of capitalisation, is then exported to New Zealand. One could say that in fact a bounty has been received in respect of that export. I would like to know whether or not the Minister considers that there is a problem in meeting this current legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there will not be.
—I ask the Minister whether it would be possible for another party to see that there was a problem.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of perhaps taking legal action?
—Yes, indeed.

—I am advised that there could be some potential for a person who wished to pursue legal challenge to this to identify that there had been some sort of component of capitalisation provided in the past. But it will not be possible under these future arrangements to identify any particular goods with a bounty paid on them.

—Supposing we take the other side of the coin. Supposing we take an exporter who is exporting to New Zealand at the time of the application for capitalisation: Will the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority (TCFDA) take into account, when it is working out the capitalisation sum, the fact that bounty is not payable upon that part of the production which is exported to New Zealand? If so, what formula, what system, will the TCFDA use in working out the capitalisation sum to be paid?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in fact the calculation will be made on the basis of advice received by the manufacturer, so the capitalisation payment will in fact be based on the manufacturer's own advice.

—The manufacturer will presumably advise that part of his capacity is being exported to New Zealand. It is then up to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to make a recommendation to the Minister in accordance with the information received. As I understand it, it is up to the Authority to work out the capitalisation sum and then recommend it to the Minister. How is the Authority to deal with, firstly, the fact that a manufacturer exports to New Zealand? Secondly, in light of the discourse that we have had today, would the Authority consider, at the time of accepting the application for capitalisation, that it would require some undertaking that the manufacturer is, in fact, not going to export to New Zealand? That then would seem to be a restraint on trade.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, when this matter is being worked out between the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority and the manufacturer, capitalisation in fact can be payable only in respect of bounties that would have been received by those goods if they had, in fact, been exported to New Zealand.

—With respect, that does not quite answer the question. The question I asked was: because at the time of working out the capitalisation the Authority is dependent upon the advice given by the manufacturer, if the manufacturer advises that he is exporting part of his capacity to New Zealand, must that not be taken into account so that no bounty is payable in respect of it in accordance with this legislation?
—That is what I just said.

—However, if somebody is not in fact exporting to New Zealand, will the Authority require a manufacturer to undertake that he will not switch some of his capacity from a different market into New Zealand in which case it would have bounty paid upon it by way of the capitalisation? My point is that that would seem to be a restraint on trade.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; there was a second part to Senator Bishop's question, as she rightly pointed out. Mr Chairman, I am advised that that problem will not, in fact, occur because there cannot be an argument at a future point in time; it can relate only to something that has perhaps happened in the capitalisation process in the past. There will not be an argument at a future point in time about trying to establish a nexus between the export of those goods and any bounty that would have been paid on them.

—So the Minister has just taken a decision that the problem will basically be overlooked and ignored. Quite frankly, if one is entitled to capitalisation only where one is entitled to a bounty which is in fact being paid, and the amount does not change but simply the destination of the goods in respect of which the bounty was being or would have been paid, and that has been capitalised in advance, the Minister is saying that it is all a bit difficult to try to work out whether or not a part of that capitalisation was, in fact, paid in advance for a product which may end up in New Zealand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, what I said was that it would be difficult to establish that nexus at some future time, yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, and follows his answer to a question earlier this month from Senator Jones regarding the 19,000-odd Chinese students in Australia. I ask: How many applications has the Government received to date from People's Republic of China (PRC) students who are here with either refugee status or permanent resident status on humanitarian grounds? What extra resources has the Government made available to process the applications as promised by the former Minister, Senator Ray, who said-I think I can accurately quote what he said on 6 June-that if there were a substantial application rate we would need contingency plans to deal with them. In regard to the Minister's answer that students can apply on humanitarian grounds, is it not a fact that until the Government lists the People's Republic of China in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette as a country for which applications for special humanitarian status can be considered, the applications have no legal status?

—As Senator Hill said, I did answer a question in respect of this matter earlier this month. I indicated then that there had been an exceptionally large number of applications for permanent residency prior to the commencement of the new migration legislation in December. I would have to get specific numbers for Senator Hill. With regard to the extra resources needed in Australia to process them, I will get an answer for Senator Hill as soon as possible. We have put measures in place to allow PRC nationals to remain in Australia for the time being pending longer term decisions on their future. We have made provision for extensions of stay, for instance, granting permission to work until 31 January 1991 to all those students who were here in the period 4 June to 20 June 1989, whether legally or illegally. We have provided welfare grants to community organisations to provide advice and counselling to PRC nationals. Last year we provided $100,000 to the Australian Refugee Advisory Council and a further four special purpose grants totalling $142,200 were provided this year to Chinese welfare and counselling agencies in Sydney and Melbourne. The third part of Senator Hill's question related to the assessment under humanitarian grounds, and I will get some very clear advice on that as well.

—Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware that an American film, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, has been condemned by the International Coalition Against Violent Entertainment for its 194 individual acts of violence, which makes it the most violent United States film to be released this year? Can the Minister request a reconsideration of the Australian Film Censorship Board's parental guidance rating, as it would appear that such an extremely violent film contravenes the spirit of recommendations made by the National Committee on Violence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the film Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles is a live action film version of the popular television cartoon series featuring the characters of Raphael, Leonardo, Michelangelo and Donatello whose mission in life is to assist the triumph of good over evil. The film is classified PG, for parental guidance. The four turtles played by actors in costume are ninja devotees helping a crime reporter clean up a subway gang responsible for a growing crime wave. Although there are many encounters between the turtles and members of the subway gang, as well as other assorted villains, the clashes between them are highly stylised. The Board considered that the ninja-style combat sequences incorporating implied blows to the body and fights with staves and other weapons were relatively discreet, if tonally strong. Injuries sustained did not go beyond occasional bruising.

ANSWER.PARA: By recognising the violent tone of the film, the presentation of violence as a legitimate means to solve problems and its trivialisation of violence through humour, the board considered the impact of the depictions to be reduced by the strong fantasy element through the film, by the recurring comic touches, and finally by the positive resolution of the plot with good triumphing over evil and the delinquent youths seeing the error of their ways.
The decision was made by a majority, as some board members considered that elements of the film were such that it should be recommended as more suitable for those aged 15 years and over.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Ray in both his capacities, as Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and as Minister for Defence. Is the Minister concerned that possible fishing or other violations could be taking place in the Fijian exclusive economic zone because no Royal Australian Air Force or Royal New Zealand Air Force Orion aircraft have conducted surveillance flights there since May 1987? Does this not undermine the effectiveness of the maritime surveillance regime in the South Pacific? Does the recent convention against driftnetting as well as a reported increase in drug trafficking through the South Pacific suggest that there is a need to re-examine Australia's surveillance effort in the region?

—The question of a resumption of that particular activity has certainly been progressed more by New Zealand than Australia, from my recollection of reading some of the cables, et cetera. I am fairly certain the New Zealanders have had discussion on this matter. The Australian Government at this stage, though, has not made a decision to resume those particular surveillance flights. One would have to say that Australia is trying very hard to establish as normal a relationship with Fiji as possible. The big reservation from the Fijian Governments point of view is that we have not resumed any military aid to Fiji and nor do we intend to until the new Fijian constitution is brought down and that constitution is seen to be fair and equitable. Therefore, on some of these matters, relationships between Australia and Fiji on occasion remain tense. It is almost a day to day matter.
—The new constitution is the test, is it? That has not been said before.

—It is one of the tests, one of the clearest indications that the Government will get. That is not to say that military aid or anything else will resume because Fiji produces a constitution. That not necessarily resolves some of the reasons why Australia has taken such a principled stand because of the treatment of certain people in Fiji. If I have anything further to add on that or I find there is any further progress since I last looked at the issue, I will get back to Senator Durack and let him know.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the answer, but in the further consideration he is obviously going to give to this matter, will he and the Government have regard to the special requirement for the surveillance effort as a separate problem on its own, regardless of the full resumption of defence cooperation?

—The resumption of this surveillance would not depend upon defence cooperation; it really is a separate issue. What I was trying to indicate to Senator Durack and the Senate is that from the Fijian point of view a lot of this does relate to the latter rather than the former-that they see it as an overall package. There well could be, I acknowledge, problems for Fiji in terms of fishing, or indeed drug importation, through the current lack of surveillance. It is a matter that at the right time I think will be resolved between the two countries.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL COMMISSION: NOTIONAL DISTRIBUTION OF PREFERENCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to an answer he gave me to a question I asked on Monday relating to the method of assessing the two-party preferred vote on election night. In his reply, the Minister indicated that there appeared to be a great deal of interest-judged by the amount of correspondence he had received-in the conduct of the Federal election, and that the various matters raised there would be looked at through appropriate mechanisms. In order that a thorough inquiry is speedily carried out, I ask the Minister whether he is in a position to indicate how and when such an inquiry will be conducted and how wide its purview will be.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Beahan for his continuing interest in this area. He raised a question the other day concerning the notional distribution of preferences as used in the Western Australian by-election on the weekend. As happened after the last Federal election, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters was given a reference to investigate the conduct of the previous election and to report to the Parliament subsequent to that. That mechanism is very useful and productive and it has led to some quite substantive changes in the way elections are held.

ANSWER.PARA: This is an issue which I have had to address in the last few weeks and I have had discussions with the new Chairman of that Committee. I have decided to give the Committee a reference, in as broad a term as the one given after the last election, so that it can look into the conduct of the election and also matters arising from it. I think the issue that Senator Beahan raised will probably fall within the responsibility of the Committee to scrutinise very closely.

The other matter on which I have had representations-that is, the question of queues at polling booths-will also be one which I am sure, having discussed it with the Chairman of the Committee, will be at the forefront of the Committee's deliberations.

I think that having continual post-election scrutiny by the Parliament is a very effective mechanism. It is one that, in many ways, takes the decision-making out of political hands and puts it into a consensus mechanism within the Parliament. For that reason, I was very pleased today to be able to write to Mr Brereton to inform him of my agreement to a reference given to that Committee so it can investigate the previous election.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to yesterday's press release from the Palestine Liberation Organisation stating that yesterday morning the PLO representative in Australia, Mr Ali Kazak, had met with the Governor-General, Mr Bill Hayden. I ask: Was this meeting sanctioned by the Government and at whose suggestion did the meeting proceed? If authorised by the Government, does this meeting at head of state level signify a major change in direction of Government policy and contradict its earlier pledges to restrict such contact?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Governor-General, Mr Hayden, met the Palestine Liberation Organisation representative in Australia, Mr Ali Kazak, at Government House yesterday. This, of course, was recorded in the Vice-Regal notice in today's major newspapers. The Governor-General had advised the Government beforehand of his intention to meet Mr Kazak, who, of course, is an Australian citizen. Mr Hayden had previously met Mr Kazak in Mr Hayden's former capacity as Foreign Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: This meeting does not signify any change in the Government's policy on the Middle East or its attitude to the PLO and it is entirely consistent with the Government's policy on contacts with the PLO. The Australian Government acknowledges that the PLO represents the opinion of a significant portion of Palestinian people and must be involved in negotiations towards settlement of the Middle East dispute. However, the Government does not recognise the PLO as the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people.

On 15 December 1988, Senator Evans announced that statements made by the PLO Chairman, Yasser Arafat, on the previous day in Geneva had satisfied the Australian Government's three conditions for direct dealings with the PLO. These were, firstly, that the PLO expressly accept Israel's right to exist without any accompanying qualifications; secondly, that it renounce all forms of terrorism; and thirdly, that it accept the United Nations Security Council resolutions 242 and 338 as a basis for negotiation.

The Australian Government does not recognise the state of Palestine, proclaimed by the Palestine National Council in 1988. The Government has made it clear that the question of Australian recognition of a Palestinian state will arise only in the context of an overall peace settlement. As the Government recognises states, not governments, recognition of the PLO is not a relevant consideration.

In 1982 the Palestinian Information Office was established in Australia. In March 1989 Senator Gareth Evans announced that the Government had no objection to this office being called the Palestinian Liberation Organisation Office, thus acknowledging its representative status without conferring diplomatic or consular status. The Australian Government representatives maintain contacts with the PLO up to and including ambassadorial level. Ministers can avail themselves of opportunities for meeting with PLO officials as they arise, as have at least two members on the Opposition front bench over the last two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Further to a South Australian study on parenting, which I launched on Monday, calling for more flexible options for flexitime and part time work and increased parental leave, both maternity and paternity, what steps is the Government taking to address this question either under award restructuring or under International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention No. 156 commitments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under this Government there has already been a significant increase in part time employment. Between April 1983 and April 1990, the number of women in part time employment grew by 52.2 per cent. On 2 March 1990 the Prime Minister announced--
—Well, they had to. How else can they keep their homes?

—I am surprised that there is this sort of break-out of opposition in the chamber. I was saying that on 2 March this year the Prime Minister announced Australia's ratification of ILO Convention No. 156 on workers with family responsibilities, which makes it a fundamental objective of policy to enable people with family responsibilities to work as far as possible without conflict between their employment and those family responsibilities.

ANSWER.PARA: Following ratification, a work and family unit is being established in my Department, the Department of Industrial Relations, to ensure that the interests of workers with family responsibilities are addressed as part of the award restructuring process. Part time and flexible working arrangements will be one of the main issues to be addressed in that unit. While more flexible working time arrangements, including part time work, are desirable, it is most important to ensure that such arrangements introduced as part of the award restructuring process should not cut off part time workers from career paths and industry training. The Government has put it to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission that the introduction of more flexible working patterns should not operate against the interests of particular groups such as women, who are often the predominant users of part time work.

In practice this means that clear distinctions should be made between part time work with pro rata conditions and casual work, and that casual work in particular needs to be addressed in a way that prevents abuse and protects the interests of workers and the long term adaptability of the work force. The Government has also intervened in the hearings of the parental leave test case in support of the Australian Council of Trade Union's claim for unpaid parental leave to be made available for both fathers and mothers. It has argued that current provisions assign family responsibilities primarily to women, reinforcing their traditional role and leaving them at a disadvantage in the labour market.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, to an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review which stated that the number of women appointed to Government boards and authorities has fallen from 27 per cent in 1985 to only 12 per cent in 1989. In view of the Government's commitment during the election campaign to giving a high priority to issues affecting Australia's women, will the Minister confirm, firstly, that if these figures are correct, urgent attention will be given to correcting the situation without waiting for the findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which I understand is currently inquiring into equal opportunity and the status of women; and, secondly, that consideration will be given to allowing women politicians to sit on the inquiry to provide a better balance to that of the all-male Standing Committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report to which Senator Lees refers and also a press report of 21 May, which might be the original source of this story. The first thing to be made clear is that I am informed that we cannot get any accurate information as to the basis of the figures presented in the articles. For instance, the basis for the 1985 figures is unclear. In 1989 the total percentage of women on statutory boards was 19 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has an ongoing commitment, as has just been spelt out by Senator Cook, to increase the number of women in positions on Commonwealth boards and advisory bodies and elsewhere in the workplace. That commitment is being pursued and fulfilled on a number of different levels. In 1988, for instance, the national agenda for women specifically concentrated on the need to increase the number of women appointed to boards. This followed directly from the Government's 1983 commitment to a policy of equitable representation of women on government boards and preceded an August 1988 resolution passed unanimously by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party to set a minimum standard of 25 per cent representation of women on boards and authorities.

This commitment was reinforced by the Prime Minister in February last year when he reminded Ministers and others of this policy and of the fact that the Government had appointed a consultancy, announced last year, to the Office of the Status of Women to look at ways of increasing the appointment of women to government boards.

Pursuing this commitment even further, Cabinet Office has established a monitoring system, tracking all Cabinet appointments. The percentage of women on statutory boards now stands at 19 per cent, compared to 12 per cent 12 months ago. Monitoring is also being set up within Commonwealth departments to allow within those departments an accurate measurement of non-Cabinet appointments to ensure that equitable representation of women is achieved.
The Government is putting in place policy objectives and the appropriate mechanisms to ensure that those policy objectives are achieved. We will pursue that aspect of our policy strenuously.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Do the national account figures released today indicate that the Government's economic strategy is on track? In particular, are exports making a contribution to the economic turnaround?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always difficult to look at one quarter's figures and draw conclusions from them, but I must say that when taken in conjunction with the last quarter's figures, the figures released today are encouraging. Senator Schacht particularly asked about exports. In the recent March quarter national accounts figures, gross domestic product grew by 1.8 per cent. Of this, 0.2 per cent was contributed by net exports. Exports contributed one per cent to the rise, and this was partially offset by a significant growth in imports of 0.7 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The six-monthly figures, that is, the last two quarters put together, show that gross national expenditure-GNE-grew by 0.5 per cent, while gross domestic product, that is, the total output of the economy, grew by 2.2 per cent. There is a very encouraging dichotomy between those two sets of figures. Within that, exports of goods and services were up by 6.5 per cent, while over that period, imports-

TALK.START.PARA: —You know what has fuelled the situation.
—I do not think so. That was yesterday's interjection
—Talk about the capital aspect, not consumption.

—Senator Baume does not know what period we are talking about. I am talking about the six-monthly figures. Imports were down by 2.6 per cent. That is precisely the sort of relationship that is a necessary and desirable part of the Government's economic strategy. I think that, on the basis of the two quarters, the six-monthly figures, it is fair to conclude that in a macro sense the right adjustments are taking place. They show that a modest slowdown in demand is now occurring with production and at the same time employment is holding up. Coming back to the matter which Senator Schacht particularly asked about, as I said earlier, there is a net improvement in the export picture.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It follows his incredible response to Senator Schacht's dorothy dix question. Is the Minister aware that today's national income figures reveal that continuing increases in activity by governments have provided more than 90 per cent of the increase in gross national expenditure over the last 12 months, with the March quarter showing an 11 per cent real rise in governmental capital spending but a 2.4 per cent real fall for the private sector, mostly involving a sharp fall in new equipment purchases, while government consumption expenditure rose by 1.5 per cent, far greater than the 0.9 per cent rise for private sector expenditure, which was despite a 2.1 per cent rise in wages, salaries and supplements which could have been expected to encourage a rise in private sector expenditure. As high levels of Government spending appear to be the reason for the economy's present rate of economic growth at a time when the private sector is being hit harder and harder by the Government's massive high interest rates, what will be the impact on economic growth of promised restraint on government spending if in fact this ever takes place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the first place, Senator Michael Baume asked this question, as he put it, in a follow-up to the answer I have just given to Senator Schacht. It was a good try at a follow-up but Senator Baume cannot have listened to the answer I gave to Senator Schacht. In drawing the dichotomy between the government sector and the private sector, first let me make the point that the government sector is not, as a rule, in the export business; the private sector is, and there has been a growth over the last quarter, and the last two quarters, in export performance. I gave those figures to the Senate in answer to the question directed to me by Senator Schacht.

ANSWER.PARA: It is all very well to huff and puff here in the Senate about government expenditure but let me just make the point that, though I agree with Senator Baume that there has been a 1.5 per cent increase in government consumption expenditure for the March quarter, the Commonwealth government expenditure did not increase. There are a number of factors which go to--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are bleeding the States. What else do you expect?

—I think that is the most dangerous interjection I have ever heard Senator Walters make on behalf of the State of Tasmania. The fact of the matter is that expenditure by State governments has been running much higher than Commonwealth Government expenditure. I would not have thought it was in Senator Walters' interest or those of her Tasmanian constituents to make that interjection before a forthcoming Premiers Conference. Perhaps it will be in the Hansard and it will be very useful to the Commonwealth when that Premiers Conference comes on.

ANSWER.PARA: To go back to the answer, a number of one-off factors are involved, and the particular one is increased spending by State and local governments. That increased spending has largely been on law and order services, which are matters frequently raised with a fair degree of enthusiasm by Opposition senators in this place, and, secondly, expenditure by State governments and local governments on safety matters involving not only roads and motor vehicle safety but a whole range of safety issues. If honourable senators annualise the six-month figures-that is, the last two quarters-they will see that the growth in government consumption is 2.7 per cent annually, which is a very moderate outcome compared with previous years.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about capital spending? Are you going to duck that one?
—No, I am not going to duck that one. I said to Senator Michael Baume a minute ago that the Commonwealth Government expenditure did not increase and that is what we are doing here.
—Capital expenditure? You said `consumption spending'. Make up your mind.

—There is no point in Senator Baume trying to recycle his question about half a dozen times by way of interjection every time he gets an answer he does not like. There will be other opportunities later in the week for him to ask questions, and he will get the same treatment then.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his obfuscating answer and draw to his attention the fact that his answer is in total and direct conflict with the statement by the Australian Statistician, which says:

QUESTION.PARA: The major contributors to this growth were:
* a 2.1 per cent increase in wages, salaries and supplements . . .
* an increase in gross operating surplus of 3.9 per cent for private corporate trading enterprises, mainly attributable to the strong growth in mining industry profits; and
* a 3.1 per cent rise in indirect taxes less subsidies.

There is no mention of export. In light of that total conflict and disagreement by the Statistician with the Minister, I ask: Are these high rates of government spending-including capital spending, which the Minister deliberately avoided mentioning-sustainable? What will happen to economic growth--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This supplementary question is twice as long as the original question and it introduces new matter. Really, it is out of order.
—Senator Baume, I ask you to finalise your question.

—Are these high rates of government spending sustainable and what would happen to economic growth if the Government were to act responsibly by cutting government spending instead of relying entirely on its present destructive high interest rate policy, which has clearly failed?

—Senator Baume reads from one section of the Statistician's report which deals with wage increases and so on and then tries to turn that into a question on exports. Why does he not read to me the section of the national account figures which deals with exports? If he wants to ask a question about exports, that is what he ought to read. So long as Senator Baume is here, I suppose we will have these recycled eristic questions.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Puplick knows what the word means. I am delighted; we will miss him when he goes. Senator Baume probably does not. I do not detract at all from what I said in my answer to Senator Schacht and the first part, as distinct from the eighth part, of Senator Michael Baume's question which dealt with expenditure by governments and where it was occurring.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to comments on the AM radio program last Friday by the United States Secretary of Health, Dr Louis Sullivan, about slashing cigarette sales to children? Has the Minister noticed the explicit US linkage between vending machines and access to cigarettes by children and the US proposal to ban vending machine sales of cigarettes? What steps and actions would be involved in any moves in Australia to cut the linkage between vending machines and access to cigarettes by children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Maguire for his question. I know that he, particularly as a South Australian senator, has taken a great interest in this area. He told me that recently the South Australian Health Commission has revealed that the incidence of lung cancer amongst males in South Australia is declining but amongst females is markedly increasing. We know that there is no safe level of tobacco use. Tobacco is the major preventable cause of death and disease in Australia. In 1987 there were some 18,000 tobacco-related deaths. I know that Senator Peter Baume also takes a keen interest in this matter and assents to those terrible figures.

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Government is very concerned about tobacco consumption and has introduced major initiatives to address this problem, including the banning of smoking in Commonwealth buildings and on domestic airline flights and prohibiting the advertising of tobacco products in the electronic and print media. The Government is currently conducting a $2m national media campaign to reduce smoking by young women across Australia.

I am aware of concerns that have been expressed in the United States that cigarettes are readily available to young children, particularly through cigarette-vending machines, even though this is against the laws of that nation. I understand from various media reports that the United States Secretary of Health is proposing to ban altogether the sale of cigarettes from vending machines. I happened to hear the AM program to which Senator Maguire refers and I managed to get a transcript of it just before Question Time. In the transcript of the AM program some days ago, Martin Devell reported from the United States:
Now President Bush's Secretary of Health, Dr Louis Sullivan, has taken up the crusade-
that is, against smoking/tobacco-
He's proposed a wholesale assault on trying to stop new smokers, mainly teenage children.
The biggest culprit, he said was the cigarette-vending machine, and the Secretary of Health proposed that cigarette sales from vending machines should be banned.
Then there is an extract from a tape-recording of Dr Louis Sullivan's remarks. He stated:

We must put an end to the time when any child with a handful of change can commence the slow motion suicide that has taken the lives of millions of Americans. We must put an end to the sacrifice of our children on the tobacco merchant's altar of profit.
Dr Sullivan also directly attacked the tobacco companies for promoting tobacco addiction amongst groups in society, in particular, women. He had this to say:
These advertisements use appealing images to mask an awful reality, and the reality is that smoking is a killer, and an equal opportunity killer at that.
That is a very telling way of putting the matter.

In Australia regulation of the sale of cigarettes, including through vending machines, is the responsibility of States and Territories. I understand that it is an offence for cigarettes to be sold to children under a certain age, generally 16 years, and that this applies to sales from vending machines. Any moves to limit further the availability in this country of cigarettes through cigarette-vending machines would be matters for the States and Territories, and it will certainly be the subject of discussion at the ministerial council on the drug strategy to be held in Brisbane in a fortnight's time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs will be aware that a former New South Wales policeman, Mr Max Chapman, was initially accepted into the Australian Federal Police and then rejected because of advice from certain New South Wales police which may have been incorrect. Mr Chapman challenged the decision in the court and costs of some $30,000 were awarded against Mr Chapman in favour of the Commonwealth. As there is the possibility that Mr Chapman may have been the victim of a grave injustice, will the Minister suspend the Commonwealth's claim against him for those costs pending further investigations of the matter?
—This matter has been exhaustively considered.
—No, it hasn't.

—I am afraid that it has been exhaustively considered over several years. I believe that as to the actual reasons for Mr Chapman's not securing employment with the Australian Federal Police, the matter has been exhaustively and fairly dealt with. As to the new matter which Senator Reid raises about the question of suspending the claim of the Commonwealth for costs, I believe that that is a matter that I can make some inquiries about and provide the honourable senator with an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Are there any meatworks presently in liquidation which owe inspection fees to the meat inspection service? If so, how many are there and what amount does each owe? Is the Government doing anything, and what, to stop debts of this kind occurring in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this question probably comes more correctly under my title of Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. However, to Senator Cooney's first question: yes, there are meatworks which are in liquidation which currently owe inspection fees to the meat inspection service. On current information available to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, a total of 10 meatworks Australia-wide are understood to be in liquidation. Three are owned by one company with a total debt on inspection fees of $315,644.47. The remaining inspection works owe, in total, $200,644.62 in unpaid inspection fees. When the liquidations are completed, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service expects to recover a significant amount of the money that is owed.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the steps that the Government proposes to take in the future, in so far as newly registering meatworks for export are concerned, the money that is owed for these meatworks will have to be paid before the new owners can actually exercise an export licence. As well as that, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is currently undertaking a major review of its debt recovery procedures. A major issue addressed in the review is the timing of action to be taken when a debt becomes payable. The bills are not sent until 28 days after the debt has been incurred, there is 28 days to pay, and there is a considerable delay before inspection services might be withdrawn. That is to be reviewed. The joint Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service-industry review of the meat fee for service slaughter floor scheme-I am sure all honourable senators know that by name-is currently being conducted. That will play a major role in speeding up the payment of debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. It relates to the credibility of the Australian Electoral Commission, as set out in Electoral Newsfile No. 7 of 25 May 1990, which states, is produced `for the information of persons interested in the 1990 Federal election'. Bjelke-Peterson' shown there-the same as another senator with a name of similar spelling who serves in the Senate? —Will the Leader of the Government in the Senate, in his capacity as Acting Prime Minister, give an assurance that when Federal Cabinet considers the wool floor price issue later today the following matters will be thoroughly taken into account: the adverse impact on the national economy of a reduction of up to $3 billion in export earnings resulting from a reduced floor price; the consequences of a $5 billion reduction in incomes to woolgrowers and the associated impact on all those dependent, directly or indirectly, on the wool industry for their livelihood, which I understand is some 650,000; the impact of a precedent-setting reduction in the wool floor price on the future integrity of the entire floor price scheme; and the impact of a known lower floor price for the 1990-91 season on wool sales between now and 30 June? Further, will the Acting Prime Minister undertake to provide full and public detail of the Government's position with regard to these vital issues when it makes its announcement on the 1990-91 wool price?

—I do not want to reveal any secrets, but I happen to have seen the views of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in written form on a number of these issues. All the issues that Senator Boswell raises will be taken into account. It may be that the Government's judgment about these things will be different from his. It may be that the Government's judgment will be based on the view that one does not have to look just at next year's effect on the wool industry but at a few years effects on the wool industry in determining a lot of the questions which Senator Boswell refers to. —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware that the value of the Government's grants to non-government environment organisations was substantially reduced this financial year because of a failure to provide a consumer price index (CPI) increase? Is the Minister aware that many of these organisations employ staff and must meet normal increases in wages and costs due to inflation? Will the Minister give an undertaking that grants to conservation councils and other recipient organisations in 1990-91 will be increased in accordance with the CPI at least?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I could not give the guarantee Senator Dunn seeks. During the last few years we have maintained the grants to these non-government conservation groups and they have not always kept pace with inflation. Having said that, though, it must also be remembered that the Government has provided considerable funds on top of those grants for other purposes to the same organisations. Does the Minister consider that the two months taken to give his decision was too lengthy? Does the Minister agree that the two approvals should have been made simultaneously to prevent speculation and other premature moves such as Royal Bank executives taking their proceeds and going home, thereby orphaning the Royal Bank?

—Mr President, I cannot comment on whether the time taken to give the decision about the proposed merger between the ANZ Bank and the National Mutual was too lengthy. However, I do know one thing, and that is it was given a tremendous amount of attention and very serious consideration by the Treasurer. He published his reasons in full when he announced that decision and, of course, they have been the subject of some public difference of opinion. —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to his answer to the question asked yesterday about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation by Senator Calvert. Does the Minister's answer indicate that the Government is satisfied with the policy direction being proposed by the ABC's Managing Director? Which aspect satisfies the Government most? Is it the saving of $2m, or is it the reduction of local news content available to Australia's regional viewers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, no, it does not indicate that at all. What it does indicate is the Government's view that if a statutory, independent national broadcaster is set up, it is expected that the broadcaster will operate with its own independent management which is responsible to its own board. I must say that politicians-and this is not a reference to the questioner by any means-over the years have shown a remarkably inconsistent attitude towards this basic premise in calling for political interference in the ABC, particularly on programming issues, when the ABC has reached a decision independently which those politicians do not happen to like at that particular time.

ANSWER.PARA: Personally, I would be very averse indeed to see any government of any political persuasion, as a matter of course, routinely interfering with decisions made by the ABC. As I said yesterday, and I simply reiterate, the ABC Board is considering that particular matter today. It is a case, I would have thought, for all of us-not just the Government-in the first instance, to wait until the Board determines, having considered what management wants to do and all the objections to it, what the programming decision will be.
