TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Does this indicate that the Government has a different attitude towards interfering with the administration of its corporations? I refer to the contrast between what is proposed for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and what is proposed for the Australian Wool Corporation.
—I do not intend to distinguish a woolly question like that with a substantive answer. I have nothing to add to what I have just said.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Acting Prime Minister and is further to the question asked by Senator Boswell. Does the Government realise that a cut in the wool floor price would immediately, firstly, cut $500m off growers' money from the value of wool owned by them in store; secondly, cut $10 billion off the value of wool growing capital invested by growers; and, thirdly, cut $100m off the value of wool held in stock by international processors? How can the Government argue with any justification that such massive reductions are in the national interest?

—Mr President, in some ways the Government is not attempting to argue anything at the moment. No doubt we will be arguing that at a later stage, but that remains to be seen. All I can say to Senator Sheil, in respect of the three figures which he has given, is that I am not prepared to accept them as being accurate. As I said earlier, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, if the Government reaches a decision about this matter in the near future, will make the appropriate announcement and explain the reasons for the Government's decision.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of figures released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics showing strong growth in the profitability of the mining industry? Can the Minister tell the Senate the reasons for this strong growth? Can he also advise the Senate whether this encouraging situation in the mining industry is due substantially to the Hawke Government's correct policies of micro- and macro-economic reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is yes. Today the Australian Bureau of Statistics released catalogue No. 5651.0 headed `Company Profits: Australia March Quarter'. That was a survey of mining industry profits. The main feature of the Statistician's report is that the value of company profits in the mining industry was $1,517m in the March quarter 1990-a rise of 25 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms on the December quarter 1989, and a rise of 89 per cent on the March quarter in 1989. That is to say, the increase in the nine months ended March 1990 was 64 per cent over the same period one year ago. There are several reasons for this strong growth-increased production of petroleum and liquefied natural gas (LNG) and, to a lesser extent, increased production of coal. There was a high growth in exports of these commodities in the March quarter, with coal rising by 20.6 per cent in real terms over the December quarter 1989 and petroleum and LNG rising by 62.7 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The growth in the coal industry is expected to continue as forecast by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE). Its March quarter 1990 report suggests that total coal export revenue is expected to be up by 11 per cent in 1990-91. ABARE has attributed growth in the production of coal in the first half of 1989-90 to the benefits of revised work and management practices being increasingly realised. Honourable senators will be aware that this major reform was undertaken through the Coal Industry Tribunal by this Government and it is now reaping some considerable benefits for the industry.

ABARE has also reported that deregulation of the crude oil market in Australia, coupled with strong overseas demand for the premium local crude oil, has boosted our exports. Exports are expected to be up by 22 per cent this year. LNG exports are expected to record $325m in 1989-90 and a further $500m in the following year.

Does he realise that the increased wool buying forced onto the Australian Wool Corporation as a direct result of the Government's speculation about a lower floor price has already cost growers $300m? Does he appreciate that a cut in the floor price to 700c will mean a further loss to growers of $100m between now and 30 June? How does the Government explain to growers that it has acted responsibly by slashing their incomes by at least $300m since Easter?

—This question has been asked in about five different guises and I have answered it in about five different guises. I have nothing to add to what I said earlier. As to the necessity of explaining any government decision that is made to woolgrowers, that will be done.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I assume from Senator Button's reply that he does not intend to explain to wool growers what he has done; that he does not believe that it is at all necessary.
—Senator O'Chee has made an assumption that he was quite unentitled to make on the basis of what I said a second ago.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR REFUGEES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). I ask the Minister whether it is true that Australia, with other major donor countries, is currently questioning the functions of the High Commissioner's mandate at a time when the UNHCR Executive Committee has a temporary governmental working group under way to oversee the operations of the organisation and to explore ways that the current financial crisis might be resolved. I further ask the Minister whether Australia is now promoting the idea that UNHCR funding should be based on an available resources approach rather than a needs basis, the logic of such an approach being that there is a limited amount of resources, so if the refugee population increases, the per capita amount going to refugees must fall. Finally, I ask the Minister whether the Government's long term aim with this strategy is to whittle away at the mandate of the UNHCR and whether he believes that such a position is worthy of Australia as one of the rich industrialised countries, at a time when over 15 million people in the world are currently refugees and the number is increasing rather than decreasing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard this as a fairly cheap and grubby question because Senator Vallentine tries to answer the first two parts of the question by having an assumption in the third part as though the first two parts are true. I really would urge Senator Vallentine to construct her questions a little more fairly.

ANSWER.PARA: On the general question of UNHCR, there is no doubt that in the last couple of years there was an enormous budget blow-out. Unfortunately, the High Commissioner resigned and for many months people have been travelling without authorisation on first class air fares. It is not a fact that any organisation can always be funded on the basis of `needs'. It is given a budget and it is expected to stick to it. What has happened is that a $38m deficit of last year has had to be rolled over into this year's budget. That is quite a difficult thing for an international organisation.

There is absolutely no substance to Senator Vallentine's allegations that Australia is in any way trying to belittle or undermine the UNHCR. We have historically been very strong supporters of the organisation. We have consistently supported the High Commissioner. The current High Commissioner has the total confidence of the Australian Government.

In case anyone should read into Senator Vallentine's question that this country is not doing enough in terms of refugees, let me remind honourable senators that we have the highest per capita intake of refugees of all countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Let me remind Senator Vallentine that when we went to the Geneva conference last year, as all the other prissy moralistic countries were putting their hands up saying, `Of the 55,000 long term people in the camps we will take 50, aren't we good, we will take 120', the only country that did not put a number on it, naturally, was Switzerland. Everyone else said, `We will take 140'. What did Australia do? We said, `We will take 11,000 in three years'. It looks as though we will be able to almost deliver that amount in two years. I say to Senator Vallentine that the general view in the community that this Government or previous governments have been heartless in the area of refugees is false. We have nothing to be ashamed about at all. When Senator Vallentine talks about there being 15 million refugees around the world she happens to be wrong. There are 15 million displaced people around the world. The definition of refugees is something that must be protected. Senator Vallentine's question does not protect it because her question talks about people who have been displaced from Afghanistan. Not all of those people are refugees-some are, some are not.

The biggest questions that the UNHCR is trying to tackle at the moment is the proper definition of who is a refugee and how we can protect genuine refugees. It does a good job in my view. It is entitled to proper financial support. It does not have an unlimited entitlement to financial support. It must have good management practices. It must manage the resources it is given properly. It is very easy to argue that in part of 1988 and early 1989 it did not do so. This may have led to Senator Vallentine's assumption that in some way the rest of the world is trying to undermine or dismantle UNHCR. They are not; they are just trying to put proper procedures in place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time Senator Hill asked me a question following the tragic murder of two young Australians in Holland, murders for which I understand the Irish Republican Army (IRA) has accepted responsibility. The question was in two parts. One related to the transfer of funds to the IRA and the second related to the processing of visa applications. I am able to advise the Senate that, on the question of funds being transferred to support, for example, the IRA, the Australian law prohibits persons in Australia from giving money for the purposes of supporting hostile activities in other countries such as seeking to overthrow a foreign government or by the use of violence, causing the public in a foreign state to be in fear or suffering, death or injury.

ANSWER.PARA: Terrorist activity of the provisional IRA would clearly fall into this category. Allegations of possible offences under this legislation should, of course, be brought to the attention of the Australian Federal Police. That is to say that the law is in existence so far as those sorts of activities are concerned.

With regard to the processing of visa applications, screening procedures applied to visa applications are under constant review to ensure that they remain both effective and appropriate to the circumstances. The events in the Netherlands illustrate the need for constant vigilance in the evaluation of visa applications. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Puplick proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Hawke-Keating Government to secure real increases in Australian family living standards over their entire period in office as a direct consequence of their failed economic policies.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following matter is a matter of public importance in Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Hawke-Keating Government to secure real increases in Australian family living standards over their entire period in office as a direct consequence of their failed economic policies.

For seven lean years, for seven hard years, the families of Australia have been afflicted by a government which has steadily, remorselessly, relentlessly, heartlessly and deliberately driven their living standards and their prospects into the ground.

In March 1990 a clear and definite majority of Australians voted against, voted to reject, voted to replace the Hawke-Keating Government. A mere 39 per cent of them voted for the Hawke-Keating government on their first preference. Even with the cynical second preference strategy of Senator Richardson-itself based on driving down family living standards by the pursuit of the so-called Green vote at the cost of sustainable economic growth and forgoing projects which could have been achieved in an environmentally acceptable fashion and could have yielded real economic benefits for all Australians-the Hawke-Keating Government still found that fewer than 50 per cent of the Australian people were prepared to support its return. However, given the vicissitudes of our electoral system, the majority of Australians who voted against the Hawke-Keating Government are now sentenced to another three years of continuing economic and social misery.

What lies ahead is not hope; what waits in prospect is not improvement; what stands before us is not relief but, rather, more of the same and then yet more as this Government's economic policies, which have so manifestly failed, remain unchanged and the magnitude of the failure simply grows and grows. Those braver souls who dare to criticise or to suggest a better alternative-the likes of Senator Button-find themselves rounded upon by the Blaxland bully, flayed and castigated, abused and hung out to dry while Labor's nominal leader wimps and snivels, incapable of providing leadership a jellyback in need of a spine transplant, according to Senator Walsh-a man well placed to know, brave enough to speak up, courageous enough to confess and, above all, too honest to put up with it any longer.

The story of the failure of the Hawke-Keating Government, however, is not written in the raw economic statistics alone. Under the Hawke-Keating Government we have a consumer price index increasing by 8.6 per cent annually; a 26 per cent increase in bankruptcies in the March 1990 quarter; a 25 per cent fall in annual dwelling approvals, accompanied by an 11 to 12 per cent fall in housing loans; record interest rates of 16 3/4 to 17 3/4 per cent for home loans, 18 7/8 per cent to 19 7/8 per cent on the prime rate, and up to 24 and 25 per cent for smaller credit facilities; and record foreign debt, which in the last quarter of 1989 hit the staggering figure of $147,734m.

This Government's failure, rather, is written in the record of the lot of Australia's ordinary families, that majority of whom voted for the coalition parties but two months ago. It is told in the hundreds of thousands who cannot afford a house; the young people, of whom Senator O'Chee will speak later in this debate, condemned as the first generation of Australians whose standards of living will be less than the generation which went before them; the elderly, of whom Senator Patterson will speak later in this debate, whose health, security and welfare have been mercilessly ravaged by this Hawke-Keating junta; the small family businesses and farms who are so crippled by the deliberate Hawke-Keating strategy of high interest rates that they are going under in record numbers-in their tens of thousands. The Government's failure is told not in the statistics but in the woe, the misery, the distress of thousands, indeed hundreds of thousands, of Australian individuals.

Let us start by first examining the raw data about family living standards under the Hawke-Keating Government. Let me take housing as my first example. Home loan affordability is, according to the statistics put out by the industry itself, now at record lows. Fewer Australians can now afford to own their own home than has ever been historically the case-certainly in postwar Australia. It is an achievement of the Hawke-Keating Government that fewer Australians can now afford their own homes than has been the case in the lifetime of almost any member of this Federal Parliament. Home loan repayments are up by 30 per cent over the course of the last year.

Indeed, the Australian Financial Review reported on 5 December 1989 a study undertaken by the Research Policy Centre at the University of New South Wales under the heading `Housing Costs Up 50 per cent In Hawke Era, Uni Study Shows'. It points out that the huge increases in housing costs fall primarily upon younger families in Australia. The study calculates that, on average, the increases in house prices and interest rates have led to families with post-1986 mortgages, estimated by the study to be at least 70 per cent of those with mortgages, paying out an additional $48 a week in repayments over the past seven years.
If one looks at the publication by the Real Estate Institute of Australia in October 1989 entitled Australia's Declining Housing Affordability, it says:

Australia has witnessed a decline in housing affordability in recent times which threatens its traditionally high level of home ownership . . . Interest rates are clearly the single most important factor affecting housing affordability.

How can Australian families, however described, be formed, nurtured, developed and turned into the building blocks of the future if people in a family situation simply cannot afford a roof over their heads, simply cannot afford a house, a home, a reference point, some security? We find even today that the May 1990 bulletin of the Australian Housing Industry says:
Unfortunately, the focus of government so far has been on crisis management rather than a coordinated response to the problems of the 1990s.
Nowhere is that more manifest than in this Government's lamentable and indeed almost criminal failure to address the housing situation as it affects young families.

Let us take, for example, a second area-the Government's record in relation to the burden of tax. The Australian Institute of Family Studies, in its publication Families and Tax in 1989, had this to say:

Average tax rates have risen between 1976-77 and 1988-89 for all individuals and families with the exception of those on very high incomes and some low income families with children . . . In 1988-89 dollar terms, the same AWE family is now paying $30.80 per week more tax than they did 12 years ago compared to the twice AWE single person who is paying $18.88 more and the single person on four times AWE who is paying $105.32 less.

What this Government has done again in the words of that Institute of Family Studies publication, is bring about a situation in which `since 1984-85, real disposable incomes have fallen sharply for all income units dependent on one income'. In terms of the immediate situation of the formation and establishment of families in Australia, it will be taking place in a period in which family income will be single income. That is the record of achievement of the Hawke-Keating Government.

I will take a third example, that of the management of debt. In April 1989 the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC), the Government's own advisory body, in its publication Economic and Social Implications of Consumer Debt, had this to say:
The last decade has seen a strong increase in the level of consumer debt relative to household disposable income and a doubling in the debt servicing ratio.

It went on to identify home mortgages as the major component of that problem and at least 100,000 Australian families that may be, in its words, `overcommitted' in the sense that they carry heavy consumer credit and other fixed commitments relative to incomes. It pointed out that some low income families pay 9 per cent or more of their gross income on consumer debt interest alone. EPAC went on to point out the substantial increase in consumer, business and personal bankruptcies which have been the focus of several questions asked in the chamber recently by Senator Boswell and others.

But even if one can get a home and service a loan, one may want one of those other aspects quintessential to life for many Australian families, for example, a family car. Yet we see in today's Australian newspaper vindication of the claims that Senator Button's policies-so-called Button car plan-cost each Australian car buyer at least $4,000 per car. Even in 1992 it will cost $3,200 per car more than it should cost unless this Government takes the steps necessary to manage the Australian economy properly.

That is the record of the Hawke-Keating Government. But what has been the rhetoric of the Hawke-Keating Government and what have been its promises to the people and families of Australia? The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his 1984 policy speech said:
This Government sets the welfare of the Australian family as its top priority.

God help us as to what its bottom priority was, because the betrayal, the devaluation, the dishonouring of that particular statement is absolutely manifest. In the same policy speech, the same man-the man rejected by the majority of the Australian electorate last March-said:

What concerns the ordinary Australian family is that there should be jobs available now for parents and in the future for their children; that they can purchase their own homes at a reasonable cost and not have to face crippling interest payments . . . above all, that every Australian family has the opportunity to maintain and improve its standard of living.
That was the promise made and that was the promise that was devalued and dishonoured. In the same policy speech the same man-the rejected leader-said:
We pledge ourselves to bring home ownership once again within the reach of ordinary Australian families.

That is the third lie in the series-the trifecta of untruths in that particular policy speech. Of course, we all remember that this policy speech was succeeded by yet another-the 1987 policy speech-in which the Prime Minister said:
By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

Not content with having devalued that promise, having failed to fulfil that promise, and having presided over the increasing number of young Australians for whom a home is a park bench, a gutter, a youth refuge, the open air or the beach; by 1989 in his speech to the Australian Council of Social Service the Prime Minister had the temerity, the gall and the hypocrisy to say this in relation to child poverty:
Since our re-election we have acted with determination to reach that goal-and we reached it ahead of target.

There is nobody in this country-other than the resident who shuttles between Kirribilli House and the Lodge and the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) who shuttles between his four-storey terrace in Elizabeth Bay and the front gate of the Lodge to make sure that the building is being kept in good repair for his eventual occupancy-who actually believes that any of the problems of youth homelessness and the family distress which arises from that have been addressed.

The Prime Minister told interviewers in May this year that there was going to be an increase in family living standards under his Government. Senator Button, who once again was seized with a bad attack of honesty-an unusual seizure for members of the Labor Party Ministry to suffer-actually came into this chamber and said, `Well, perhaps that is not going to be achieved. It all depends how you measure family living standards.

I tell the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who will reply to this matter of public importance, that I know how to measure family living standards. I measure them by going out onto the streets in Sydney and seeing what happens to the kids on the streets in Sydney. I measure them by the number of people that come into my office who cannot afford a home. I measure them by the social indicators of distress, family breakdowns, poverty, domestic violence and real personal anguish. I do not need the statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics; I do not know the casuistry; and I do not need the sophistry of the Parliamentary Secretary or his superior. What I know is what I see, and what I see in this country is a less fair, a less equitable, a less just and a less decent society than was the case when this Government came into office.

I see a Prime Minister who told people, when interest rates were 13.5 per cent in April 1985, `There will be, I would expect, a significant lowering of levels of interest rates', but then they went up to 15.5 per cent. In March 1986 the same man said `We will be able to enjoy permanently lower interest rates', but they went up to 16 per cent. In July 1987, he said, `Interest rates are falling and under Labor will continue to fall', but they went up to 16.5 per cent. In January 1989 the Prime Minister said, `Yes, interest rates are going to fall', but they went up to 17 per cent. This is a man whose capacity to tell the truth to the Australian people and whose capacity to provide the sort of leadership that is required in Australia is so flawed that it is no wonder the majority of people in Australia voted against his Government on 24 March.

The unidimensional nature of Labor's economic policies, its excessive-indeed, its almost obsessive-reliance on high interest rates has been a failure. It has applied the tourniquet of high interest rates so tight that, rather than merely slowing the pulse, it has driven the life out of the economy and, indeed, out of the very heart of Australian families. Its failure to curb its own excesses, to stand up to the demands of its powerful mates-its effective controllers-in the Australian Council of Trade Unions, who believe that more and more can be extracted from our economy without real meaningful and sustained increases in productivity, is a national disgrace.

The coalition, in putting forward its family action plan at the last election and in Dr Hewson's National Press Club address given just a few weeks ago on 16 May, has identified the critical areas of necessary reform, such as micro-economic reform. We want more than an offer of Senator Collins' resignation; we actually want to see something achieved. We want to see real micro-economic reform instead of bodgie deals with the television companies or interference with the merger plans of the ANZ Bank and National Mutual. We want to see a real start on tax reform. We want to see real sustained development; not the rhetoric which we have been fed and which has so manifestly failed the people of Australia.

We cannot go on like this and there is no way that Australian families should have to keep putting up with it. Unless the Government changes its ways and its policies and, above all, accepts responsibility for the families of Australia, this country will be neither the lucky country nor even the clever country: we will be, under the Hawke-Keating Government, the hopeless country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to trade insults or unparliamentary language with Senator Puplick. In fact I feel a bit sorry for him.
—Unparliamentary language?

—If Senator Panizza wants me to raise it I will. I just ignored it because I feel rather sorry for Senator Puplick. I am not trying to score a point about whether this is his last speech because that is a matter that history will judge. He will probably come back and perform better than many other people in the Opposition, as he has over the last few years. I am saying that I am sorry because this was a matter of public importance written in the hope that some disastrous national account figures would come out today and the Opposition could dance on, what it hoped would be, the grave of the economy. But the figures were not disastrous.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with what Senator Button said at Question Time. It would be silly to oversell one quarter's figures as it has been consistently silly for the Opposition to make major play about one quarter's adverse statistics. If we stood up today and said, `Today's statistics prove there is no problem', nobody would think that was the way in which the quarter's statistics, out of context, ought to be interpreted. The truth is probably somewhere in between the overly pessimistic December figures and the overly optimistic March figures-somewhere between the minus 0.1 per cent rate of growth of the December figures and the 1.4 per cent or 1.8 per cent, depending on the measure, of the March figures.

I think we need to recognise that the most important statistics published in Australia for three months came out today but because they were not convenient they were not mentioned once. Senator Puplick managed to speak for 20 minutes without acknowledging they had been released. He did say that what he was looking for is not in the statistics. That is absolutely right; it is not. The statistics that Senator Puplick was hoping would come out which would be disastrous, which would have facilitated his speech, actually came out saying that the economy is not performing as badly as the most pessimistic of pundits and the Opposition criers of disaster have been predicting. Not only do the statistics show that the gross domestic product (GDP) grew, variously measured at 1.4 per cent or 1.8 per cent, but there was also a net positive contribution by net exports which is very important in terms of our balance of payment situation. Looked at over the more realistic period of six months, not taking the overly optimistic figure of the last three, these statistics show that gross national expenditure grew by 0.5 per cent while GDP grew by 2.2 per cent. That is exactly the formulation required to be sustained long-term to resolve the fundamental economic problems Australia faces.

I do not want in any way to underestimate the significance of those problems. I simply want to say they will not be resolved by selective quotation of out of date statistics; they will not be resolved by recycling old arguments or by recycling old speeches. That is what we got today. We got a second-hand, second-rate speech quoting figures plucked out of the past. Let met give honourable senators an example. Senator Puplick quoted from Families and Tax in 1989. He conveniently forgot that the body which published that document published a subsequent document, because policy has changed since then, analysing the changed circumstances and coming to much more positive conclusions about the Government's record. Those figures must have escaped Senator Puplick's attention-and he has the gall to talk about sophistry.

The situation is that the figures over the last seven years-one can draw a variety of messages from figures from the last seven years-indicate that quite a number of important economic factors need to be looked at. I will just refer to one. It is the one that I have never heard the Opposition refer to since it went into opposition. Opposition members used to talk about this factor a lot in the early years of their government when it looked all right. Then the situation turned sour and the Opposition stopped using it. It is the most reliable statistic: the measure of household disposable income; that is, the measure of the amount of money after wages, taxes and social security payments that households have to meet the commitments that they have to face. Real households disposable income under this Government have increased by nearly 20 per cent between 1983-84 and 1989-90. Nobody would claim that because that statistic exists, nobody in Australia faces any difficulty. Nobody would claim that Australia has no economic problems. If we are to face up to those problems realistically, an opposition needs one day to have the courage to say, `Some good things are happening; some bad things are happening; I agree with some; I disagree with others'. We do not need an opposition giving thespian performances, histrionics and abuse.

We have had that increase of 20 per cent fundamentally for three reasons. Wage increases and tax cuts have flowed from negotiations under the accord. There has been continued employment growth of about 2 7/8 per cent and social security payments have increased-I refer particularly to those in 1989-90. During the year in which the Australian Labor Party came to office, household disposable income fell by 2 per cent because employment was collapsing. In the subsequent years, figures up to and including 1989-90, as best assessed, show that in 1984 household disposable income per capita was 2.9 per cent; in 1985 it was 1.6 per cent; in 1986 it was 0.5 per cent; in 1987 it was minus 1.7 per cent-that is one bad year and no one should deny it; in 1988 it was 1.9 per cent; in 1989 it was 2.3 per cent and in 1990 it was 2.5 per cent.

I do not cite those figures as the definitive answer to say that there are no problems. I say, `Let us be realistic. A lot of good things are happening out there. Over one million jobs have been created. There are 25 per cent more jobs now than there were when we came to office-the most substantial job creation performance in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development by any measure'. There have been wage improvements as against the wage freeze when the Government came to office. There have been tax cuts such that the level of taxes paid are less than they would have been had the 1983 rates been indexed. There have been substantial improvements in social security payments. There have been changes in tax to make it more equitable. Some of the people who are constituents of the conservatives opposite, who might come in to their offices complaining, are those who now have to pay capital gains tax for whom taxation was optional up until 1985, those who now have to pay fringe benefits tax and superannuation because the income tax base has been broadened, the rorts have been closed off and the rates have been able to be dropped. On balance that is why we can say that household disposable income has gone up by 20 per cent in seven years.

There are other important areas about family living standards that escaped Senator Puplick's attention-the question of superannuation, for example. We have a situation now where superannuation is no longer the preserve of the privileged few. It is being spread rapidly to everybody in paid employment in Australia and being facilitated through other mechanisms for the self-employed. It is very important to Australia long-term that superannuation be extended for three reasons. First, it is important to the families about whom this matter of public importance was supposed to relate, because it talks about income security in retirement. Secondly, it is important because it reduces the burden that will flow onto future generations of taxpayers by the ageing of the Australian population. Thirdly, it is important economically because anybody who faces up to the important economic questions which Australia is facing recognises that an increase in savings is one of our most fundamental requirements. It was not mentioned by Senator Puplick either because the statistic is not convenient-that statistic keeps going up as well. I wish it would go down for the Opposition, it would be much easier. I am sorry, it keeps going up.

The situation is that the Opposition continues to oppose the superannuation increase. The Opposition was opposing it the other day in here, deploring the fact that there is an increased 3 per cent superannuation payment to wage and salary earners. By the end of the term of this Government, 6 per cent superannuation payments will be established for the overwhelming majority of working men and women. The young people who are going into the work force today face a situation where they know that they will be secure for the rest of their lives because of that superannuation. The economy will be better because superannuation savings are being generated.
We have a whole lot of other issues to do with living standards of families that somehow or other were not mentioned.

At this stage I still continue to look only at the question of living standards in a financial and economic sense. I wonder whether I have time to divert to some other matters concerning the standard of living of Australians, as might properly be mentioned. For the moment I want to get back to some other matters to do with the conventionally measured quality of life: the question of availability and affordability of health services; the question about home and community care services and what they provide; the questions about child-care, about education, about the quality of living in the suburbs and about urban regeneration.

Medicare is one of the prime ideological targets of our opponents. They froth at the mouth at its mention, which is a lot of fun to watch. But Medicare is very important to many Australian families. It means that they know what the health insurance situation is for the first time since 1975. Until this Government came to power they did not know what the health situation was from one year to the next. They now have the security of knowing that they have health insurance, which is very important in terms of access to doctors. It is so important to men and women to know that they have medical insurance cover for their children, in particular.

We talk about the opportunity of aged persons in our community to be treated with equity and to have dignity. Everybody would love to be able to promise some big increase in the pension, for example, 30 per cent. We could have an auction to see who could deliver the highest pension. For the first time the pension is 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We have the home and community care scheme, which means that people can continue to live where they want to live-in their own homes-instead of being sent to institutions before it is necessary. Those sorts of benefits are available for the first time.

The living standards of ordinary Australians are affected by the availability of child-care. There are not enough child-care places in Australia, but there is almost immeasurably more than there was. There will be another 78,000 places by the end of this Government's term. Child-care availability is important to the people battling to maintain their jobs and to keep their lifestyles in a difficult economic climate. Governments should give that priority, as this one does. In the forthcoming three-year term another priority for the Government will be in the area of improvements in services for people living in the outer suburbs, what are called the western suburbs by people who live on the east coast. One of the great measures of the living standard of the family-particular working class families-is the capacity of the family to educate its children to a higher level than the level to which the parents were educated, the ability to educate one's kid to his or her maximum potential. The capacity for ordinary men and women to ensure that their children can continue to year 12 and then, if they show the interest and aptitude, go on to tertiary education is very important. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance being debated this afternoon, which was raised by Senator Puplick, concerns the claimed failure of the Hawke-Keating Government to secure real increases in Australian family living standards over its entire period in office. Interestingly, throughout the whole of his speech Senator Puplick did not in any way define what he meant by living standards. As Senator McMullan identified, there are factors related to living standards other than economic indices and the indications which they give of quality of life. I would like to turn to those matters because I think they are far more important than and far more relevant to the material which was put before us by Senator Puplick. I was pleased to hear Senator McMullan at least pay some lip service to those other factors, although he did not clearly give them a very high priority because 90 per cent of his speech dealt with economic factors.

SPEECH.PARA: What is meant by living standards? The inclusion of this commonly used term without any further explanation or qualification by Senator Puplick says a great deal about the mover of this motion and the Party from which he comes. The comments that he made and, as I have indicated, most of the comments which Senator McMullan made in his speech indicate that essentially, at the core, they come from the same philosophical position.

Let me begin by recounting the content and the result of two studies. Many perceptive people-but they are not yet to be found in the ranks of either the Government or the Opposition-have been critical of the use of the present economic indices as measures of human welfare. Other indices which measure human welfare directly have been invented, and when countries have been compared by using those other welfare measures and the conventional economic ones it has been found that there is very often extremely little, if any, correlation between them.

One of these measures which has been gaining some United Nations endorsement-and only today I again picked up an article mentioning this, although the idea has been around for some years now-consists of equal parts of easily objectively measured factors in human welfare. They are longevity, infant mortality and literacy, scaled on a scale of zero to 100 and mixed in equal proportions.

A study several years ago, which I understand has been repeated, indicated that on this scale of human welfare Sri Lanka scored 87 while Saudi Arabia, on the same scale, scored only 27. Yet at the same time the per capital gross national product of Saudi Arabia was 10 times that of Sri Lanka. What honourable senator would claim that `the standard of living of one nation is greater than the other'? If that gross difference between those two indices can be demonstrated between nations, surely also relatively small shifts in the rate of growth of either gross national product or gross domestic product over time give very little indication of what is actually happening to welfare within a country such as Australia.

The second example I would like to mention is that as technology improves more goods and services can be produced with less human labour. Over time several countries have conducted repeated surveys of their people, asking the question, `As productive capacity increases would you rather take this improved productive capacity as increased leisure or increased income?'. In Denmark these surveys showed a gradual increase in the proportion of the population who would prefer to take this increased productivity in terms of increased leisure.

By the early 1980s more than 50 per cent of the Danish community said that they would prefer to take out the increased productivity as increased leisure. This very greatly disturbed the Organisation for Economic-and I stress the word `economic'-Co-operation and Development because the OECD saw that if Denmark were allowed to go down that road, the rate of growth of gross domestic product in Denmark would gradually fall and may even become negative. What did the OECD say to the Danish Government? It said, `What you have to do is to increase inequity in Denmark, to increase the level of discontent and dissatisfaction within the Danish community, so that those who are less well off will then wish to compete more vigorously with their better off compatriots and in this way the growth of gross domestic product will be preserved'. Which honourable senator would argue that the Danes became better off as a result of that overemphasis on an economic index? Yet Senator Puplick included not one single measure of equity in his speech.
If we turn to some of the things that have been said about equity in Australia, we find that a review of a book called Fair Go: Welfare issues in Australia by Ronald Mendelsohn states:

One of the messages of this book is that Australian society is becoming steadily less equal, after a brave start up in 1914 towards an equal society. And the chances are that the gap now created will be irreversible. Nowhere is this more obvious and harder to change than in questions of land, of city planning, of shares in the good things that city living yields, and in housing.
The Australian Institute of Family Studies, speaking of the difficulty Australians at the bottom end of the heap, as it were, face in obtaining housing said:
. . . more than 150,000 families or individuals were on waiting list for government housing,-
this is a 1990 study, incidentally-
and more than a third of these had been on the waiting list for more than three years.
. . . for over 600,000 renters, the main reason for renting was because they could not afford a home of their own. Only one in eight public renters reported that they were saving for their own home.
The Institute of Family Studies also stated:

In the year the present Government announced its intention to end child poverty by introduction of the Family Assistance Package, it also decided to eliminate unemployment benefits for 16 and 17 year olds, abolish Supporting Parents' Benefit when the youngest turned 16, phase out Class B widow's pension and income test Family Allowances.

The economic measures used by economists and adopted by Government and Opposition-and, it should be noted, also by most journalists-without qualification do not include many of the things which are highly valued by people but on which it is difficult or impossible to place a monetary value. Historically there has been a steady progression from the use of initially gross national product as an index-as a simple accounting tool, the uses of which were recognised as needing to be heavily qualified-to the present day, when the qualifications have been largely forgotten and the country goes into a panic when there are three quarters in which the gross domestic product has failed to grow.

I have pointed out on many occasions that most of the costs of growth are counted as additions to gross domestic product. The cost of road accidents, including the cost of the funerals of those who die as a consequence of those road accidents, are added to gross domestic product. Meanwhile there being no national capital account, we can deceive ourselves into believing we have become richer when we deplete the natural resources of this country and turn them into dollar-earning junk. Recent international attempts at formulating an index which would more fairly represent those factors which are of concern to real people, and not just the abstraction from real people usually considered by economists, have suggested that such an index would reveal-and I stress it-a decline in human wellbeing on a global scale since the mid-1970s.

This situation does not reflect on the Hawke-Keating Government in the way suggested by Senator Puplick's matter of public importance. But it does reflect on the Hawke-Keating Government in quite a different way-and it reflects even more severely on the coalition parties and their policies. Both the Government and the Opposition, in their pursuit of isolated and deeply flawed economic goals, have ignored the real welfare of Australians.

Indeed, this morning's Australian newspaper contains two articles on the economics of immigration. Without going into the merits of the conclusions in an article by Professor Glenn Withers, an economist from La Trobe University, it is obvious that he attempts to show an economic benefit from immigration but totally ignores in his analysis the increased inconvenience, the travel times, the isolation imposed on those forced to live on the outskirts of an already large city such as Sydney and many more items because they are hard to measure in dollar terms. Attention was drawn to this by the American economist, Richard Ruggles, in his book which was published in 1983. He said:

There is no well-defined universe of nonmarket activities and imputations to be covered. The set of all possible imputations is unbounded. The only criterion that can be employed is whether the imputations are considered to be useful and necessary for the particular purpose at hand . . .
For all these reasons, an explicit separation of market transactions from imputations in the national accounts would seem highly desirable . . . It would be recognised, however--
and I stress this-

that imputations alone cannot meet the information needs for measuring economic and social performance . . . No amount of imputation can convert a one-dimensional summary measure such as the GNP into an adequate or appropriate measure of social welfare.

Contemporary society values people for what they possess or what they can produce in a material sense. People are believed to relate primarily through market relationships. This view has received reinforcement from both the Government and the Opposition. For this reason, if this were an urgency debate this afternoon rather than a matter of public importance, the Democrats would seek not to vote either with the mover of the motion or with the Government but would absent themselves from the chamber.

Inherent in the wording of the matter of public importance and the presumptions which lie behind it is a lack of understanding on both sides about real people. The market competitive system which attempts to deal with people as economic consuming units to be manipulated to increase material consumption is a parasite on a real human society. A market-oriented and directed society, such as we now have in Australia, does not accumulate moral capital. On the contrary, it depleted and dissipates it. It does the same thing with natural capital and the community must maintain both against the onslaught of the market. Paradoxically, if community outside the economic system did not maintain these factors-that is, the moral capital and the natural capital-the market itself would not long survive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to the presence in the gallery of a group of school students from St Patricks school in New South Wales. SPEECH.PARA: Last night I was reading the report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children-the Burdekin report. Indeed, it is a terrible and sobering document. Is this a future that we wish to give to the next generation of Australians? Is this the future that the Government wishes to give to the people of Australia? Is this the record on which it wishes to be recorded by history?

The Burdekin report said that four major trends cause youth homelessness: the increased rates of unemployment amongst chief wage earners in families; the increased number of single-parent families-I do not know how many children in the gallery have only one parent living with them; the decreased value of Federal income support payments; and increased housing costs. This boils down to one thing: inadequate disposable income. Senator McMullan's description of disposable income is not correct. If one is fortunate enough to earn the average weekly wage-and I am not talking about the median but the average, which is higher than the median-one will receive approximately $540 a week. But what of the problems facing those of my generation who wish to marry and have families of their own? Our future is dependent upon our employment prospects. I do not intend to canvass here the problems with tertiary education, and problems there are, but rather I wish to address the problem of the young unemployed who currently leave school at the age of fifteen-they are not even adults-to commence their travels on the long road to nowhere. These people are our subtertiary youth, those who do not go easily into further education or into the work force. At school they are called the underachievers. I believe, and we on this side of the chamber believe, that the underachievers, the underprivileged and the undercared for constitute the underestimated force in our nation's future. At school they will have the opportunity to learn basic literacy, numeracy and social skills, and in their part time jobs in industry they will learn job skills for the future. This Government may not care about unemployed homeless young people, and it probably does not because they do not have a residence and, therefore, cannot vote and do not count in Keating's Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —They have turned their back on the bush.

—As Senator Boswell has so ably said, they have turned their back on the bush and carried out a systematic attack on primary industry in this country. SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan, in his comments today, seemed to think that in bringing on this matter of public importance we, on this side of the House, were prompted by the people who complained to Senator Puplick about having to pay capital gains tax.
