SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance brought on by Senator Puplick from the Liberal Party of Australia claiming that family living standards have fallen over `the entire period of the Hawke-Keating Government'. I must reject the claim that has been made by Senator Puplick. The history of Liberal government shows that in office the Liberals could not deliver the sorts of things they are talking about today. The Hawke Labor Government came to office in 1983 at a time of deep recession. Under the Liberals, dole queues were swelling, inequality abounded and poverty was rife in Australia. I recall the 1981 Budget, the Budget in which Mr Howard, the Treasurer, increased sales taxes on a number of basic commodities across the board. One commentary on the Budget in 1981 was:

SPEECH.PARA: While the primary aim of this Budget is correct, the burden of its achievement will fall most heavily on those least able to afford it . . .
A further quote from the same commentator:
Families have been hit with higher government taxes and charges.
That was a comment made on the second last Budget of the last Liberal Government. The commentator went on to say:
. . . it should not be beyond the wit of man to come up with schemes more equitable than those we have at present.

Those comments were not made by a member of the Labor Party or by a member of the Opposition at the time; they were, in fact, made by the former leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Peacock, in a speech in the House of Representatives attacking his own Party's policies during its years in office-and rightly so, because the Liberals had a pitiful record on helping families, assisting pensioners and boosting social justice in Australia. That was the record and the reality of seven long years of Liberal government in Australia.

Under the the seven years of coalition government the number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families increased from 380,000 to over 800,000, but only once in that whole period was there an increase in family payments for children. That is the reality of Liberal government in practice. Only once, in 1980, an election year, did payments for pensioners' children rise from a paltry $7.50 per week to $10 per week per child; in fact, children were forced to bear the cost of the coalition's economic bungling in the late 1970s and early 1980s. In fact, child payments declined in real terms, that is, their purchasing power was eroded by a massive 35 per cent over the course of the previous Liberal Government. By contrast, the Hawke Labor Government has increased payments for families every year that it has been in office. As well as the family allowance, we have introduced the family allowance supplement.

I would like to examine in detail the family allowance supplement and payments made to children of pensioners and beneficiaries under the Hawke Labor Government. In 1983 when this Government took office-and Opposition senators, I am sure, will not want to hear this-the payment was $10 per child per week. By 1989 the Hawke Government was not paying $10 a week, $20 a week, or even $30 a week; it was paying over $34 per child aged 13 to 16 years per week and $24 per week for younger children.

I am pleased to note that from January this year there has been a further increase in child payments; for example, for teenage children to $35.25 per week. So in a period of just over seven years, despite all the rhetoric we have heard this afternoon from the other side, the reality is that under a Labor government there has been a 250 per cent increase in weekly child payments.

The family allowance supplement focuses on working families-that is, families whose head is in the work force. It is a targeted scheme; it focuses on the neediest families. It certainly does not support and endorse middle class welfare in Australia. That is the record: family payments have increased every year under Labor, whereas families were ignored by the Liberal Party when it was in government. Let us face it: in reality, the Liberals in government did as much for Australian families as Captain William Bligh did for the working environment on the Bounty. Under Labor, not only has the family allowance supplement increased, but family allowance has also increased.

Last July the family allowance for a two-child family was increased from $12.75 a week to $18 a week. The Government has made a commitment that every year from now on-and for the first time ever-all family payments will be indexed every January according to the cost of living rise. Each January parents will be compensated for cost of living rises, as a result of the policies of the Labor Government. In that situation, households with children will no longer have to rely on ad hoc increases in their payments; they will not have to rely on discretionary payments by governments. They are now guaranteed an adequate income for future years.

The history of family payments is that they began in Australia in 1940. But under the old system of child endowment the Liberals did not give an increase. Not once in a period of decades was child endowment increased to protect parents against inflation. That is the record of the Liberals who come in here today and parade around the place about families. But when in government the reality was that they were mean and they did not provide increases in family based payments. They certainly let family payments slide down in value in relation to the cost of living.

Last year the Labor Government also increased the dependent spouse rebate in the personal income tax system. For the first time ever that rebate will be adjusted in line with inflation, as measured by the consumer price index. That move will benefit about 1.2 million Australians, focusing particularly on single income working families.

I would like to look at the effect of the family based payment increases in the second half of last year, in line with the personal income tax cuts made by this Government, to draw out some of the happenings in the Australian community. For example, a single income family earning $20,000 gross income-a relatively low income by today's standards-with two dependent teenage children will now, as a result of the tax cuts, face a tax liability of about $2,100. As a result of the significant increases in family payments-these calculations were made before the January increases this year which were made due to the cost of living-while that family will pay taxation of just over $2,100 per annum, its family based payments, through the family allowance of $936 per annum, and through the family allowance supplement of $1,658 per annum, mean that it will receive nearly $2,600 per annum from the Federal Government as family payments. In other words, family payments will be in excess of personal income tax payments by almost $500 per annum. It is somewhat like the concept of a negative income tax that has been talked about in social welfare circles around the world for many decades. The reality now is that single income working families whose incomes are in the $20,000 range will now get back from the Federal Government more in child payments than they actually pay in personal income tax. That is a very big achievement; one that has been delivered by a Labor government; one that could only be talked about by the Liberals; and one certainly that a conservative coalition government would be incapable of delivering.

One of the mechanisms for bringing about that negative income tax in Australia for that group has been the restructuring of the income tax brackets in Australia. For example, when the Liberals were in power, the lowest tax bracket rate on the income tax schedule was 30c in the dollar. As a result of Labor's restructuring of the personal income tax scales, the bottom tax rate has been reduced to 21c in the dollar. That is how we can focus assistance and so forth on the lowest income families in the Australian community.

Due to the tax cuts last year the net income gains for a family on about $20,000 per annum, or $380 a week gross, will be over $21 a week, including the increased family payments for dependent children. The family itself is about $1,100 better off per annum due to that restructuring of personal income tax, combined with the significant rises in child payments through the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. Those calculations are on the conservative side; they do not take into account the increase in family payments from 1 January this year. It is important to note that, as part of the Government's incomes policy, by granting those large increases in family payments, by reducing the tax rates, that $21 a week which is the product of those moves would be equivalent to a gross wage rise-that is, an increase in wages, before tax-of over $36 a week.

The reality is that family payments have clearly increased under Labor; they have gone up enormously. The facts I have put before the Senate today clearly indicate that the runs are on the board and certainly raise very severe questions about the claims made by Senator Puplick and Senator O'Chee this afternoon. It is very hard for them to back up their claims when these facts about family payments and the Government's family record are placed on the record.

The same applies in relation to the Australian labour market. How can they claim that persons who have been taken off the unemployment registers in the last seven years are worse off? How can they claim that the people who under this Government have gone into jobs for the first time are worse off? It is nonsense. It is very instructive to look at the unemployment figures. When this Government came to office in March 1983, there were 695,000 unemployed people in Australia-10 per cent of Australia's labour force. In the same month in 1990, seven years later, there were not 695,000 people out of work in Australia; the Government had reduced the figure through its expansionary policies to 510,000 or 6.1 per cent of Australia's labour force. So 185,000 Australians-not a small number, almost the population of the Australian Capital Territory-have been taken off the unemployment registers around Australia. Yet today Opposition senators have come into the Senate and made sweeping claims that Australian families are worse off as a result of the policies of this Government. There, very tangibly, very clearly and on the public record, are 185,000 Australians who did not have jobs when the Liberals last had a go at pulling the economic levers in this country. They do have jobs under Labor. Clearly, they are better off than they ever were when the other lot ran the country seven years ago.

On the other side of the equation is employment, which I know is very close to your heart, Mr Acting Deputy President. The reality is that in March 1983, when the Hawke Government was elected, 6.3 million Australians had jobs. In the very same month of this year, seven years later, 7.8 million Australians have jobs. So very clearly 1.5 million extra jobs have been developed in the Australian economy in that seven-year period. It is an absolute nonsense for the Opposition to bring on a matter of public importance today claiming that families are worse off and ignoring the fact that 1.5 million more Australians have had jobs over that seven-year period.

The Liberals in government showed that they were economically, politically and ideologically incapable of looking after Australian families. A decade ago the Liberals said that they would protect family incomes, and they failed. Today this Labor Government has boosted family assistance enormously. The Hawke Government will continue to make further improvements to create a fairer, more just and more prosperous Australian society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot leave unanswered what Senator Maguire has said. He gave us a history lecture-History 101-and a litany of the Australian Labor Party's so-called achievements. He listed, one after the other, the family payments, but let me tell Senator Maguire that they have been gobbled up and evaporated by high inflation, high mortgage rates, high interest rates. The policies of this Government have gobbled them up and made them almost as nothing. Like fairyfloss, the families have it in their hands and their mouths but it disappears. If I wanted hope, I would rather listen to what Senator O'Chee had to say than to what Senator Maguire had to say. There is no hope in just suggesting that we are going to give more handouts to people. The hope is in a revitalised economy. Hope for the future of Australia comes not from a dwindling government purse but from an expanding purse that results from a revitalised and dynamic economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan, who put in his little Australian Capital Territory's worth, criticised the Greiner Government. Families in New South Wales owe much less in State debt than do families in Victoria. I come from a State where families are facing a State debt about double that in New South Wales. So Senator McMullan should not come in here and tell us about Mr Greiner and his record. Let me tell Senator McMullan about Mr Cain and his record of declining living standards in Victoria.

Today we are discussing the appalling record that this Government has in relation to living standards. The best evidence comes from Senator Walsh, who unashamedly admitted that this Government deliberately engineered a recession. Whether it is technical or not, today or yesterday, is irrelevant. Basically, most people would argue that Australia is in the throes of a recession. The truth of this statement is clear to the people on the street. They do not need today's national accounts to tell them where the economy is headed; they know. The two small business people I talked to over the weekend whose businesses have gone to the wall know where we are headed. Regardless of the figures, the pain is the same for those small businesses and for Australian families.

How long is it since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) asked his constituents-the failed small businesses, the home buyers who have been forced to give up their dream of a home, or the families struggling to make ends meet-about the state of the economy? I do not suppose Mr Keating has met many of those recently. They would no doubt express their anger at this Government's policies in stronger terms than Senator Button's `severe downturn'. They would be more vocal and florid in their description of where this economy is heading.

Who can be blamed for the pain of higher interest rates and high inflation? There is no other answer than that this Government is to blame-we do not need a history lesson from Senator Maguire-and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer are to blame. They lack the courage to take the necessary hard decisions and honestly to tell Australians the truth about the damage they have caused. They did not tell us before the election; they waited until Senator Walsh bled his heart out on the Monday after the election-and more than 50 per cent of the Australian population knew that.

Australian workers are not fooled by the con of the deal between Bill Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Treasurer. The Government's accord mark 6 merely shuffles the inflationary forces; it does nothing to control and reduce them. This must be tackled if Australia is ever to have a hope of once again enjoying rising, let alone sustained, living standards. We are not even at the point where we have sustained living standards. Australian families have never enjoyed any sustained benefits from a succession of these wage deals. Like Senator Maguire's family payments, they have been eaten away by high inflation, high interest rates and bracket creep. The result has been declining living standards.

Real average after-tax incomes reached peaks in 1975-76 and 1984-85. The 1989-90 forecast will restore incomes only to that 1975-76 peak. They will still be substantially below the 1984-85 level. Real incomes have fallen each year from 1985-86 to 1988-89, and the total decline has been about 10 per cent. In the postwar period, significant reductions were recorded in only four other years, and none of these was consecutive. So we had four consecutive years of decline. It is the longest fall in real incomes for over 40 years, probably the longest real fall in the lifetime of most senators in this chamber. That is what we have got. That is the legacy this Government has left us. An analysis of living standards reflects the effects of high interest rates, high taxes and high inflation. They are a damning indictment of the Hawke-Keating economic policies.

Average tax rates have risen in the last 12 years for all individuals and all families, with the exception of those on very high incomes and low income families with children. The figures for 1988-89 show that a family on average weekly earnings is now paying $30.80 per week more in tax that it did 12 years ago. Since the early 1980s real disposable incomes have fallen sharply. Real after-tax earnings have fallen by $2,000. This contrasts strikingly with every other postwar decade, when real after-tax earnings increased substantially-if Senator Maguire wants us to go into history. This is all the more remarkable when our huge overseas debt is taken into account. As Senator Puplick said, for the first time it appears that we may be leaving the next generation with lower living standards than we are currently enjoying. This is the legacy from a government which claimed that no child would live in poverty by 1990. What a joke that was.

The following headlines I have collected from various newspapers make it all too plain how seriously our living standards have deteriorated and I have just picked out a few over the last 12 months: `Debts crisis hits families'; `Family tax higher than 1977, despite cuts'. The Daily Telegraph tells us, `The family is pulling us under'. Why? The newspaper refers to the report of the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC), launched in September last year, which found that for the first time in statistical history the traditional financier role of the Australian household sector had been reversed in the economy; it went from being the lender to being the borrower. Why? Because families do not have any capacity to save. Their disposable income leaves them nothing after they have done what Senator O'Chee talked about. After paying the family bills, there is nothing left to save. For the first time in history the family unit-whatever that unit might be-is the borrower, not the lender, which is an appalling situation.

The headlines continue: the Daily Telegraph, Families rushing charities; again the Daily Telegraph, Broke families rush charities; the Age, Spiralling living costs force more families to seek help; the Australian, Spending power of families dips; the Melbourne Herald, Middle income earners in strife; and the Australian, Economic despair `boosts suicide'. What a lovely record!

Those newspaper headlines I have chosen were based on reports or comments by organisations such as the Royal Australian College of Psychiatrists, the Financial Counsellors Association of Victoria, the child poverty summit of the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Marriage Guidance Council of Victoria, the Family Court of Australia, the Smith Family, EPAC and the Australian Institute of Family Studies. This is not journalists dreaming up headlines. These are reports of study after study by government instrumentalities, charitable organisations and research groups telling us that family living standards are falling.

Family housing and, in particular, the dream of all Australians to own their own home will now only ever be a dream for many Australians. It will only be a dream because of the deliberately engineered, as Senator Walsh reminded us, high interest rate policy that this Government has relentlessly pursued. The national account figures out today only heighten the likelihood of high interest rates remaining at record levels for the foreseeable future.

In November 1988 I asked Senator Cook a question in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. At that time interest rates for housing loans had risen and I asked him whether high interest rates would mean that young Australians were having to make a choice between having a family or a home of their own. The Minister answered me and said:

This is an emotionally charged appeal to the heartstrings which is frankly quite disgusting . . . an emotionally charged ploy to try to pretend that what this Government is doing is discriminating against families.

Yet what happened? Week after week, in weekend magazine after weekend newspaper, we see articles on that very thing-young couples telling us they are making a decision between having a family and trying to make ends meet; they are just managing. They are not necessarily trying to have exorbitant standards of living, but just trying to make ends meet. Yet the Minister told me this was an emotionally charged ploy. What nonsense! Another disturbing aspect of the Government's economic policies has been the number of young families who are now homeless. Senator O'Chee has dealt with that quite extensively.

One group of people that I think we have neglected to talk about this afternoon with regard to families is elderly people-a group of people not made up of parents with young children, but the aged in our society, aged couples, the widowed and single aged people who may be living alone or with family and friends. This is not an amorphous mass of silly old buggers or wrinklies as our Prime Minister and our Minister for the Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) choose to call them. These are human beings who have contributed to this society and the sort of society and upbringing we, in the baby boom, had-a generation that was feted. We owe something to these people. They represent an important and growing part of our society which is too often overlooked. The Governor-General's Speech at the beginning of the last Parliament and the one at the beginning of this Parliament did not mention the aged. I can tell the Senate that Mr Hawke will be out there wooing the greys as well as the greens at the next election, but he does not mention them in his policy speech for the life of this Parliament given by the Governor-General.

In looking at the impact of this Government's economic policies on the aged, I would like to discuss the opportunities that aged families have had under this Government. The Government was moved to look at retirement income policies only when the Opposition produced its retirement incomes policy. The Government has done little to adopt the features of that policy which would directly benefit people over 60 years of age.

The coalition policy includes the banning of a compulsory retirement age. It also allows people to work beyond the standard retirement age, to continue to benefit from superannuation concessions through retirement incomes accounts and to allow them to take an increased benefit of pension as a result of retiring later. This allows people real security in providing for their own retirement and, of course, if people wish to work longer there are economic benefits to this. A study that was recently carried out in 1986 showed that a quarter of Australian men who reached the compulsory retiring age and had no legal recourse to avoid it said that they would rather have worked longer. This is a group of people who can contribute and give us their skills as well.

Some aged people do not have the resources to care for themselves and rely on the age pension. To give credit where credit is due, the Government has increased this to approximately 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, but not at the speed at which it was promised. It took a long time coming. The group that is particularly affected by high inflation is people on fixed incomes, retirees and pensioners.

The last thing I want to mention is health care, which tends to impact on the living standards of the aged more than anyone else. They are the greatest users of our health budget. It is instructive to note that since the introduction of Medicare a greater proportion of the aged has private health cover. What does that tell us? It tells us that aged people have no confidence in Medicare and its ability to deliver free care. The Prime Minister might be able to have his prostate operated on in a private hospital, but not so other people over 60. They wait in long queues to have their prostates operated on. Many of them scrimp and save to pay Medicare benefits-more than before this wonderful Medicare system came in under a Labor Government.

Let me tell the Senate that not only are young people suffering as Senator O'Chee mentioned, and the families that Senator Puplick mentioned, but also older people are suffering. The fall in living standards is a direct consequence of this Government's failed economic policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the alleged failure of the Government to secure real increases in Australian families' living standards, and this, the Opposition alleges, is a sign that our economic policies are not working. I would have thought that this is scarcely the subject for a debate here in the Australian Capital Territory this week. I would have thought that it is an issue that the coalition would wish to avoid on the day after the Liberal ACT Administration has brought down very savage cut backs in public sector expenditure which will have a dramatic impact on all families in the ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: I just mention a couple of examples: rate rises of 16 per cent, bus fare rises of up to eight per cent and, for heavens sake, pre-school fees. I have never heard anywhere else in Australia of children having to pay to go to pre-school. Pre-school is part of basic education, yet here in the ACT, under a Liberal administration, families will have to decide whether they can afford to give their children that very important introduction to education.

I totally reject the proposition that Senator Puplick has put forward today. I would like to quote from a number of government reports to indicate the facts of this matter-facts which I regret have not really been acknowledged by Opposition members in the debate this afternoon. Let us look at household incomes and employment. I am quoting from Economic Notes-1990, dated 22 February 1990:
Real household disposable incomes under this Government have increased by nearly 20 percent between 1983-84 and 1989-90--

This has occurred because of wage rises and tax cuts flowing from negotiations under the accord. The accord is fundamental to the Government's ability to deliver in this regard. We all know the industrial relations nightmare that would exist under a coalition government. Senator O'Chee might like to do a little history of industrial relations in Queensland and suggest what new strategies he would bring in in this regard. The document continues:

Continued employment growth of around 2 7/8 percent. Following on from exceptionally strong growth of 4.6 percent in 1988-89, employment growth will be more moderate this year. The fact that Labor has created over 1.6 million new jobs since coming to office has been the largest single factor underscoring the lift in household disposable incomes.
Increased social security payments in 1989-90 have also added to household disposable incomes.

What guarantees of increased living standards did the coalition offer in the last election campaign? Perhaps we can get some indication of how it managed to present these to the electorate from the results of the last election. First, as we know, the coalition is fundamentally committed to major cutbacks in public sector expenditure. Just this morning Senator Bishop, in discussion, said, `Let's privatise'. Whenever one talks about these issues, the Opposition says, `Let's privatise. Let's get rid of this responsibility'. Of course, this is happening under the Greiner Administration, in New South Wales, and in the Australian Capital Territory.

There was confusion in the Opposition's social security policy. David Connolly announced cutbacks of $1 billion. Does a $1 billion cutback come from a politically alternative government that is committed to a better deal for families?

Secondly, the coalition's policy contained gross discrimination against the poor, Aborigines and migrants. Despite repeated requests in the lead-up to the election, the coalition failed to give any guarantee to index child payments. Of course, we know about its tax policies and its continual reference to a consumption tax-some time in the future. It was wise enough not to make any commitments for the first term. Coalition members really cannot stand up here and talk about family living standards when that is their record.

By contrast, let us look at what the Hawke Government has initiated. Obviously, we have been committed to major economic and social reform, which has benefited Australian families. Employment growth has offered major benefits. For example, in 1983 nearly 270,000 children were dependent on adults receiving unemployment benefits. Yet in August 1989 that number had been reduced to less than 170,000. The Federal Government's employment record has ensured a far more secure and fair future for those Australian families.

There was also the introduction of Medicare, a massive rebuilding of our health and community services, the creation of nearly 70,000 additional child-care places, and major improvements in education and training programs. These reforms have all been initiated in recognition of their importance to the quality of life for all Australians, particularly those most disadvantaged.

There has been unprecedented reform of the taxation system to improve its fairness, to stop tax avoidance and evasion being used by the privileged, and to provide substantial increases in take-home pay for Australian workers. Similarly, the spread of superannuation supported by the Federal Government, in combination with its recently announced retirement income policy, for the first time provides for every Australian, now and in the future, the basis for a decent and dignified standard of living in retirement.

Perhaps one of the least acknowledged Federal Government reforms has been the historic restructuring of family payments. Earlier I indicated that the Opposition had made no commitment to maintain the indexation of family payments. Family allowance payments have been simplified and substantially boosted. This has directly benefited nearly two million families with over 3.8 million children. The lowest income families have also received levels of income support never before delivered by any Australian government through the introduction of the family allowance supplement-FAS. FAS, or its equivalent paid to families receiving social security pension or benefit, provides on average an additional $50 a week tax free to over 500,000 families with over 1.2 million children. Do they sound like policies of neglect?

This Federal Government has been the first in the history of Australia to set standards for family payments, for those most in need and to pay them directly to the mother on a regular basis. The Opposition has never let the Government forget the very historic promise that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made about child poverty. But it is important that the Opposition acknowledge that it never tackled poverty. This Government has tackled poverty. We have established benchmarks. We have greatly reduced the levels of poverty in Australia.

Furthermore, these historic family reforms will mean expenditure of nearly $3.5 billion in 1989-90 compared to barely $1.7 billion when we came to office. Again, does that sound like a Government that has been neglecting the Australian family?

We have overhauled the family allowance system to remove its complexity and the lack of indexation. In July we moved to the two rate structure of $9 and $12 and, having completed the reform of the family allowance supplement for low income families, moved to pay the allowances fortnightly and index the payment according to the consumer price index. By contrast, the Opposition's plan was to reintroduce a child tax rebate, which would not have been available to the mother when she needed the cash most. The Government has found, from research that it has done, that often the mother never sees the benefit of a tax rebate; she wants cash in hand. That is the most equitable way of assisting families-by giving the money to the mother for her to decide the priorities.

The key issue is how the Government pays for family transfer improvements. We have an established record of reducing dependency, including massive improvements in the situation of the poorest women-that is, sole parents. Thirty per cent of them declared income in 1983; 60 per cent do now. So more sole parents are participating in the work force than ever before.

We do not need government statements to attest to our policies that have benefited Australian families over the last seven years. I have a document entitled The Australian Family Income Transfer Project: Families and the Tax Package, which was published late last year by the Australian Institute of Family Studies-the most reputable organisation that concentrates on family needs and policies. On page 12 of the report it states this about the Government's policies:
Indeed, with the implementation of the new package, taxpayers in general will have higher real disposable incomes than applied . . . in 1976-77 and 1979-80.

I wonder where the Opposition has been when information such as this is readily available? Page 13 of this document talks about the distribution of gains from the Hawke Government's families and tax package. It states:
Overall, 49 per cent of the cost of the package goes to the 30 per cent of households which include dependent children.
As can be seen, approximately 60 per cent of the benefits of the package go to low and middle income families, i.e. those receiving less than one and a half times average weekly earnings . . .
The document also talks about other measures that have been introduced:
Other measures which improve the economic wellbeing of low income families include:
* the abolition of the six-week delay in indexation of pensions and benefits;
* the prospective supplementary payments for low paid workers which could benefit an estimated 300 000 families with children;
* improved training and income support for sole parents and the long-term unemployed;
* upgraded child support arrangements; and
* the general improvements in employment referred to . . .
Finally, in rebutting the thrust of the matter of public importance submitted by Senator Puplick, I will quote from the concluding remarks of the same document:
Overall, the Government's tax package redresses substantially all of the deficiencies in the tax-transfer system affecting families and single individuals, as identified in Families and Tax in 1989.

The changes in the tax scale benefit most those families receiving incomes around $20,000 per annum and have restored a significant proportion of income lost over recent years. The changes were certainly more beneficial than the indexing of the tax scale of 1983-84 . . .

I think on that note I would say to honourable senators who have spoken this afternoon that it is one thing to be critical of Government policy-obviously that is the role of an Opposition-but it is another thing entirely to blatantly and totally ignore the very significant reforms that have been made by this Government and not to be prepared to put anything up in its place. We hear much in terms of rhetoric from the Opposition about what is wrong with Government policy, but we have never been able to get from it clear coherent policies, particular when it comes to social policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —That concludes the matter of public importance debate.

That the Senate take note of the report.

That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In considering the very fast train project we must bear in mind that distance is one of Australia's major problems, if not its greatest. Therefore, travel is a subject that has to be addressed, and addressed regularly. We are dealing with this matter in the light of the fact that we are coming up to the twenty-first century. We are not looking for a solution that would have been appropriate in the eighteenth, nineteenth or twentieth centuries. It needs twenty-first century thinking and decision making. Australian transport generally is terrible. I support the very fast train project with enthusiasm and congratulate those far-sighted Australians who have promoted it so far. Clearly, the Melbourne-Sydney base is the logical area to start, but I look forward to preparations to be added in the Brisbane-Adelaide area in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one could possibly argue that rail traffic is anything but the ideal way, all things considered. In the consideration of travel we are looking at matters of time, safety, cost and comfort. Our long distances take much time, are high in cost, and are questionable in comfort and service and there are real safety risks, particularly in road transport, these days.

How do others cope? The Japanese have a very fast train system. My last reading would indicate that it has now carried over 50 billion passengers and never lost one. France now has a well-established fast train system. I now find that Taiwan, a country two-thirds the size of Tasmania, is saying that by the year 2001 it will also have a system.

We do need better transport; there is no doubt about that. Of course we do. Is there a better system than rail? Of course there is not. Let us look at the alternatives. There are only a limited number of even possible alternatives. One is the Hume Highway. Nobody would try to convince any Australian that the Hume Highway was the best way of getting between Melbourne and Sydney. The cost of its redevelopment and maintenance is enormous. The cost in death and destruction is absolutely terrible. It takes a long time and it is certainly not a comfortable way to travel. The Pacific Highway is exactly the same, only far worse.

The rail system we have at present is quite unsatisfactory. It is very slow, expensive and needs vast amounts of money for modernisation, anyway. The other alternative is air. We are talking about extra runways at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, a new airport at Badgerys Creek and we are looking at the time it takes to get in and out, the holding patterns, the congestion and everything else. It just gets worse and worse.

The purveyors of doom and gloom would stop it just for the sake of stopping it, if they got the chance. They want to ignore the time and losses in human terms and the costs in dollars and all the present alternatives that are involved with it, just as they try to prevent population growth, promote the cessation of all growth and development, and have a complete review of immigration and such matters. Whatever they want to do, we can absolutely rest assured that we are looking at a population by the year 2000 of something in the order of 20 million people, and probably 30 million people by the year 2030. We are going to have to provide a reliable transport service for all those people.

What about all those people and their transport? There is no doubt that a large proportion of these people will reside in the south-eastern corridor of Australia. If we are going to transport not only our own people but the increasing tourist traffic which is expected, we are going to have to provide this adequate service. We cannot just send people out to an airport and have them leave the middle of the city two hours before departure time, take an hour to fly and take another hour and a half to get into the city at the other end. We have to do better than that. If we do not, we are heading straight down into the comparative stakes-with all the comparisons between us and other countries-and getting less and less competitive and comparative all the time.

All Australians must be more imaginative. The Government must show a bit of vision and leadership at a time like this. We have to provide a bit of technological demonstration of our capacity to the other countries of the world. I do not know whether many people fully understand that when we are talking about this sort of transport, time wise we are talking about Sydney to Canberra in an hour, from the centre of Sydney to the centre of Canberra. We are talking of two hours from the centre of Canberra to the centre of Melbourne-and doing it in speedy, safe, comfortable and fully-serviced travel. How else could one do that?

I accept that there is disability and disturbance and that these are quite considerable for the new train project, just as they would be for any new road, airport, urban development and just as they would be if there were floods, fires or earthquakes and even, as we are heading for now, climatic change. Of course, this creates problems. I regret the fact that all changes cause problems, but these things must be attended to.

As for the environment, I regard it as extremely important, but it cannot be allowed to stop the project. We should make the commitment to proceed and say that we recognise that such factors are sensitive and that they will need particular attention. But we have the wit and the capacity to say that there are problems and that we can solve the problems. We can get the best experts and top practitioners to conclude the detail, but we must make the commitment now.

I mentioned Taiwan. Taiwan has said that by the year 2001 it will have its system running. If these people have their way in Australia, by 2001 we will still be procrastinating or we will have the proposal in the garbage bin. That sort of attitude is not the Australian way. I have great faith in Australia and in its scientists and engineers. Of course there are problems, and they will be overcome. We can overcome them only if we face them and deal with them with goodwill and commitment.

The sort of people who are involved in this, people such as Alan Castleman and Dr Paul Wild, give me great faith in what can be done. Australia has vast space and mobile people. Providing for their needs and the needs of visitors just has to be done. I repeat: from travel we expect safety, comfort, economy of cost and the best use of time. No other travel could compare with the very fast train in these directions.

There is not one obstacle that cannot be overcome if we put our minds to it. From a country once famous for its initiative we are now identified with what we are trying not to do, what we can put off, how we can stop things and how we can prevent development. That is not good enough. I am still trying to do things. I want to be listed amongst the achievers and I want to be here amongst those who set visions for achievement. The very fast train is the best example currently available in Australia for people to demonstrate that they want to be in that team.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that this is a very important issue. I would agree with Senator Archer that railway transport as an option for the future needs to be looked at seriously. It is very important for us to take the load of movement of people and of large amounts of goods from the Australian roads because they are certainly a disaster area at the moment. I would agree that the way of the future with regard to transport in Australia is railways. But the very fast train (VFT) is a proposal that should be followed by many question marks.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that people in the environment movement are trying to stop progress in every respect at all but certainly they want to ask questions and they want the community to be involved in the decision-making process. What Senator Archer has said largely indicates a Melbourne, Canberra, Sydney access bias which is quite offensive. People from other parts of Australia also need their transport requirements attended to. The whole of Australia does not revolve around Melbourne, Canberra and Sydney access, which I know may come as a surprise to people who live in those areas but I think they need to be reminded of that. Senator Archer made some assumptions about a huge population growth for Australia which I would also challenge. If there is a very large population growth forthcoming, we certainly do not want to put more people in this very crowded south-eastern corner. We need to make come alive the concept and the policy of decentralisation.

The interim report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure presented today certainly raises many very important questions. Two aspects of the report are very striking from the start: firstly, the arguments or objections to the proposals are far greater than the arguments in favour of it-that is already very clear; and, secondly, the widespread demand for a full public inquiry into the idea, referred to in paragraph 1.118.

Frank Stilwell, and associate professor of economics at the University of Sydney, has described the VFT proposal as a private enterprise venture for profit by corporate capital with little role for public scrutiny of information on social costs and benefits. Indeed, looking through the report, virtually every aspect of the proposal is highly questionable, whether it concerns the projected fares to be charged; the speed of the train, which will have to be 33 per cent greater than the current fastest passenger train; the destruction of habitat by the creation of corridors and the use of herbicides; the forcing of farmers off their land; or the noise levels. The real interests of the consortium may perhaps be summed up in the words of Sir Peter Abeles in December 1988 when he described the VFT as:

. . . the catalyst for the major redevelopment of Australia . . . It would be more appropriate if one could call this project the restructuring of our sociological and economic structure of the east coast . . . The train is only a by-product.
I think it is very important to keep it in that perspective. He argued that his concept for south-east Australia was too big for government and the taxpayers, saying that:
Private enterprise can afford to do it on a business basis.
He also said:
. . . it would take two or three generations to compete with the VFT as the catalyst.

The train project has to be evaluated as part of this national plan. Sir Peter said this in a report in the Canberra Times; it should not be seen as a separate entity on its own. Consultation with the public does not seem to be part of either Sir Peter Abeles' or the consortiums' planning process.

The Latrobe Valley Community Forum has argued that the common flaw of both inquiries is that they focus only on the fast train project and do not attempt to address the real issue of the development of transport needs and options. These need to be set in a much wider context. Because of the magnitude of the proposal, and the obvious implications for our lifestyles, development and transport options, it is essential that an independent far-reaching national inquiry constituted under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 be undertaken immediately. One of the key tasks of such an inquiry should be to assess not only the VFT proposal but other options and alternatives to alleviate our current development and transport pressures in the Melbourne-Sydney corridor. Senator Archer completely ignored this in his enthusiastic endorsement of the proposal.

The terms of reference need to be broad enough to consider the social, economic and environmental aspects of a range of options to best assess the costs and benefits to the community. Developers always talk about the financial benefits, but when it comes to costs they narrowly refer only to the infrastructure and building costs, and conveniently omit environmental and social costs-which, admittedly, are difficult to quantify, but they must be part of the equation.

The Australian Railways Union and the Australian Conservation Foundation presented a submission to this Senate Committee inquiry, endorsed by over 60 organisations, which expressed concern over the fragmentation and lack of adequate resourcing for the three VFT reviews under way and called for a single national inquiry. From a conservation perspective, the VFT proposal has two major areas of concern. The first is that the preferred route will effectively cut the forests of East Gippsland in half if the train goes that way and it could result in the extinction of Australia's rarest mammal-the long-footed potaroo. The second environmental concern relates to the longer term issue of Australia needing to develop energy efficient transport systems as an essential element in a national strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

From the indigenous people's perspective there has been little attempt to identify Aboriginal sacred sites which may lie in the path of the VFT, particularly along the coastal route. There must be detailed assessment and protection of sacred sites. Another critic of the VFT proposal is John Nestor, a former Passenger Business Manager with the New South Wales State Rail Authority. He argues that a VFT would serve no socially useful purpose and could survive financially only with hefty government subsidies. Surely we do not want to go down that path again.
