DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Childs:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate my appreciation of the opportunity to make a contribution to this report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology from my background as a trade union official and my very keen observations of what needs to be done in industry in the years to come if we are to be successful in seeing industry make a contribution to the lives of people in this country and to the economy in general.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to note that the current inquiry stemmed from a previous inquiry and report the Committee brought down about manufacturing industry revitalisation called Making It Together. It was very clear when we were looking at the matters talked about in that report that there were certain long held beliefs by management, government and trade unions that needed to be shaken and that attitudes had to be changed. Of course, we could not go across the whole gamut of those matters that needed to be canvassed in that report so we determined we would look at management and new management techniques.

I would also like to say how pleased I was that, even though my attitude to the changes required was a little different from, for instance, Senator Archer's because of his background in management, there were certain unchallengeable facts that we readily accepted. We were able to be educated a little by each other in some matters. Our views were able to be changed and we were able to come up with a report that did not require a dissenting view. So it is a report of the whole Committee.

One of the things we did very early on was to decide that we had better talk about what a successful company was and put on the record a description that would be easily understood by people. I would like to read that into the record:

A world competitive company produces the highest quality products or services which exactly meet customer needs at the lowest possible cost. To achieve this, the enterprise work force, at all levels, will share a common purpose enhanced through consultative and problem solving mechanisms, a commitment to skills training, career structures and access to appropriate technologies.

What we are saying is that new management techniques are not just about leadership at the top of the company. They are not about authoritarianism by employers or by owners or companies. They are about the management structure from the top to the bottom; about consultation, not confrontation; and mutual benefit flowing as a result of those changes.

We talked about the need to produce a report that was not just going to be commented upon in this place and then put away to gather dust. It had to be, in our view, a report that had some value to the community, that would be discussed and acted upon. For that reason we suggested a series of five national conferences and also complementary State conferences on these issues. We were not about re-inventing the wheel, so we suggested that the Australian Manufacturing Council and the National Industry Extension Service in the various States had the expertise and had done a lot of work in this area and should be involved in the organisation of these conferences.
What do we mean by new management techniques? I believe on page 7 it is very clearly set out. It is a very broad term and is used in two senses:

First, in a general sense, the term covers most available advanced management technologies and management systems such as JIT, TQC, VAM, computer-aided Design/Manufacturing (CAD/CAM), Flexible Manufacturing Cells (FMC) and Integrated Manufacturing (IM).

That is one aspect of it and it is the technical aspect. The second sense in which the term is used is to describe the underlying management-work force relationship, which is modern, non-directive, participative, where people are seen as having a worth and a value in the process. It is not the old situation where an employee is told by an employer, `You are here, you are paid to work and not to think. Because I own or I run this factory, I automatically must know more than you and be more intelligent than you'. `Participative', `consultative' and `cooperative management' carry similar meanings. As the report states:

These styles or approaches to management have one feature in common: employee involvement. This is the main sense in which the term new management techniques is used in this report. These techniques do not take away the need for management leadership and direction. However, it is the belief of the committee that decisions made on the basis of employee involvement will have a higher measure of support.

That is true. We do not want a command situation, as I said. It cannot be emphasised too much that there needs to be cooperation, making use of all those talents that are available in the workplace from top to bottom. I close by quoting a description that leads off chapter 3 about new management techniques, which I think are very important. It relates to an integrated approach to skills acquisition:
Multi-skilling of the work force, together with a cooperative approach to award restructuring by unions and employers, will be essential to the successful introduction of new management techniques.

I might point out that there have been some difficulties in that area where restructuring is proceeding fairly slowly. But it is such a worthwhile enterprise, in my view, to make those changes that we must persevere and we will succeed.

The acquisition of new skills will lead to the role modification by employers, managers and employees. Manufacturers will need to recognise this and, together with the college of technical and further education, accept responsibility for the necessary re-education and training to occur. Much of the re-education and training will be on the job and involve integration of theory and practice. There is a real need for employers to see training and skills residing in their employees as an asset, an investment, not as a cost to be avoided.

It also must be recognised that if it is looked upon by the whole of industry as being an asset, then the achievement will be in employees gaining that high level of skill, that degree of confidence in themselves and self-worth that will be useful to other employers and, in addition, those employers who may train at a given time. But the pool of skilled labour will be there for the advantage and the benefit of all industry. The establishment of goals which are understood and shared by all of the work force will ensure a more positive attitude and increased creativity in the workplace as well as requiring employees to assume more responsibility. Such changes will ultimately enable Australian manufacturing firms to look at greater market opportunities in the world economy. That is essential. We are part of the world. We have thrust ourselves into that area. The isolation we once had is gone. We will either rise or fall on the basis of our ability in that area.

That is why the changes that are suggested in this document are so vitally important and why almost total support should be given to the concepts in the report. There may be some aspects which people might argue about, and that debate can go on in a civilised fashion. However, the thrust of this report-what it says and what it intends-is so vital that I believe it is probably one of the most important reports, if not the most important, that will occupy our attention in the years ahead in terms of lifting our ability to create wealth in this country and thus finance all the other programs that governments have to undertake on behalf of the people of this country. As it is such an important report I ask other people to pay the same attention to it and give it the same priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled Report on new management techniques in manufacturing industry-people and technology is about new management techniques in the manufacturing industry. I have just joined the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and I have to say that I have had no hand in the preparation or writing of this report, the collection of data, or the examination of submissions and witnesses. But I join my colleague Senator Burns in saying that I think it is a very succinct and important document and one which the Senate, along with government, is bound to take notice of. It should be read closely.

SPEECH.PARA: The report derives from the previous inquiry and report entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making It Together, which I believe was released in September 1988. As Senator Burns has said, it was decided, following that report, to pick up the idea of looking at new management techniques and to see whether or not they had been introduced, or existed at all, as part of a revitalised Australian manufacturing sector.

It is very interesting to read a spell-out of what people mean by `new management techniques'. It also talks about the importance of educating employers and employees in the philosophy and practice of such techniques in order to commit all of those involved in the production sector to the techniques, the importance of education and training, both on-the-job and through our educational institutions.

As I read this report closely I became more and more interested to try to find anywhere in it the word `women'. It does not appear anywhere. Any examination of new management techniques looking at practices within industry in this country that devotes not one page, chapter or heading to the importance of the specific needs of women in the work force-let alone women in management-I think needs to be chided. While I have spoken to the people involved and they have said that it includes the word `people'-and, of course, that applies to everybody-what I think has to be highlighted is the fact that sometimes the needs of women in industry are very different and very specific. In fact, the contribution of women is different.

In this Parliament the Government has made a number of legislative as well as practice changes in order to specifically address the importance and recognition of women in the work force. One of the most important is the Affirmative Action Agency requiring businesses-and in this last year businesses as small as those employing 100 people or more-to describe, after consultation with management and employees and, where possible and practicable, the union movement, exactly what the status of women is in the company or industry; what the levels of employment are; what the levels of remuneration are; whether or not women are sufficiently distributed over all levels in that company or industry and, if not, why not. This is important to try to address ways in which employment opportunities for women can be advanced.

I find it quite interesting that if one reads about this matter and talks to people involved in affirmative action, one finds that the language used is not too different from what is used in this report under the heading `New Management Techniques'. Particular emphasis is placed on the development of human resources and the importance of education and training-both on-the-job and through our educational institutions.

When we put the award restructuring that is going on in this country alongside the requirements of affirmative action, according to Heather Carmody from the Business Council of Australia-if I can remember her comments correctly-award restructuring needs to address the needs of women in the work force in a very different way from the needs of men in the work force. We are told again and again that the requirement of men in the work force is for multiskilling so that they can extend their range of skills, if you like, laterally.

But the requirements for women under award restructuring are much more to do with developing career paths. Women have job descriptions or award categories that allow them to be multiskilled and to work across a number of job areas, but they do not have anything like the same career opportunities. So the requirements under award restructuring, at least in some places, are significantly different for women.

Again, it is interesting that under the heading `New Management Techniques' this document has not alluded to the very important area of award restructuring, better management of the human resource, better access to training and, in particular, better understanding of what we mean by management.

There is a lot of emphasis in this report on the importance of on-the-job and tertiary training, particularly through the technical and further education (TAFE) sector, because it focuses on the importance of increasing multiskilling in the work force. As I have said, for many women that is not a priority of concern either within their work or within the considerations of award restructuring. It is a shame that those matters not alluded to or highlighted in this report. In personnel management, an area where we often find women-if not at the very top level-the requirements, again, are very different between men and women. I think that this report could have concentrated a little more on not only training for increasing skills through the TAFE sector, but also addressing, very seriously, where managerial skills can best be taught. There is some reference to that, in the report, but I do not believe that it has been developed fully.

Should we be teaching managerial skills, as least in some ways, to our children in secondary school along with subjects such as economics, accountancy and science? Should we be looking at management courses as part of basic undergraduate courses, particularly in our colleges and universities, where many students will go on to work in industry or in companies at a managerial level? At the moment they gain almost no managerial skills in their undergraduate courses. Indeed, people are often required to return to study either full time or part time once they are in the work force in order to address their need for managerial skills. They undertake courses such as masters of business administration.

While I support the thrust of this report, there are two very glaring holes in it-the absence of any mention of women and the failure to specifically address the differing needs that clearly are part of new managerial techniques. It is important for Australia to increase its productivity by becoming smarter, leaner and more efficient. In fact, there are specific references in the report to things such as increasing productivity through decreased absenteeism. One of the best ways to decrease the absenteeism of women in the work force is to take away their concern about adequate child-care.

A parallel commitment by government to increase our efficiency and productivity, economic restructuring, along with the establishment and extension of affordable, quality and available child-care, has made a huge difference to the participation of women in the work force and the opportunities for them to rest easy in their daily work because they know that their children are being adequately cared for. It has been clearly measured in a number of places that that contributes to decreased absenteeism. It also means less requirement for the retraining of skilled workers. I cite just one area worker-that is, the personal private secretary. Very skilled women may retire from the work force temporarily to have a baby. Any number of managers will say that the cost and loss in terms of their productivity and time in trying to prepare another person to assist in this role is another example of a direct cost-a negative one, I suppose-to a successful company. Yet this report, as far as I know, has not mentioned child-care.

These things are closely associated with increased productivity and, indeed, some of the case studies at the back of this report, which I think make very useful reading, directly address the increased productivity that can come from good management before one addresses the matter of new skills, new technologies, new capital investment and so on. I would hope that further deliberation on and consideration of further matters concerning industry, both by government and this Committee, will in future not overlook the importance of women and their contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the privilege to be a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology which drafted the report New Management Techniques in Manufacturing Industry: People and Technology which is before the chamber at this moment. I recently departed from the Committee. In my opening comments on the report, the first thing I would like to do is to pay tribute to the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Childs, who guided us through an extended inquiry which flowed from an earlier inquiry which has been mentioned by previous speakers. Senator Childs did a tremendous job in gathering us from all parts of Australia for the purpose of inspections, of visits and for deliberations in private sessions to bring this report to fruition. I thank him for his assistance and guidance.

SPEECH.PARA: Also worthy of thanks are the staff of the Committee, particularly Ann Stewart who served the Committee as secretary until September last year. She is a bundle of energy. She left the Committee to move on to other things; she has some regret about leaving the report unfinished, but I would lay odds that Ann is reading this report with as much interest as she gave to her work during the very early stages of the inquiry. Also worthy of mention are Peter Hallahan and Sue Morton, the research staff who assisted us during the inquiry, and our adviser, Michael Welbourn. The people who have been named were invaluable to the Committee as we went about finding out what we could do.

I accept the criticisms of the previous speaker, Senator Crowley, that we did not cover each and every angle and that we actually ignored the participation of women in industry. I take that criticism; I accept it. I think it is something for this Committee and for other committees of the Parliament to keep in mind as they are developing further work like this. However, I will make a slight disclaimer. Very early in this inquiry we made a number of decisions as to how we would restrict ourselves. Not only has the question of women and their role in industry been overlooked but a number of other questions have also been overlooked. For example, the state of the economy has an enormous impact on how industry operates within Australia. We felt that we had to restrict ourselves; otherwise we could possibly end up with an inquiry into how the economy operates. We could have picked up elements of economic activity that would have, and do have, immediate and long term impact on how industry operates within Australia. Again, we decided we would have to restrict ourselves in what we did in that area.

Industrial relations represents another key element in this area. The subject is mentioned in very brief terms in the report. Again, we made a conscious determination that we would restrict our inquiry to the matter of new management techniques and not get diverted onto other equally important matters.

The question of training has been alluded to. It was addressed at some length in the previous report of the Committee. Very early in this report the point is made that it has to be read in conjunction with the previous report Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it Together produced in 1988. Whilst I accept Senator Crowley's comments-I am sure they would be accepted by the Committee-I think we have to be careful that we do not go off on one tangent and destroy the report and the recommendations it contains because it left out one essential element-it did not leave out just one essential element; it left out a number of equally important essential elements.

I now refer to the recommendations in the report. There are 18 specific recommendations being brought to the attention of the Government. We trust that the Government will subject each one to a detailed analysis and scrutiny and that the response from the Government and from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce will be in the affirmative and that our suggestions will be picked up. We shall wait and see whether that happens. The Committee believes that the recommendations that are made are important and will be useful in the introduction of new management techniques into Australian industry. We feel they are extremely important.

Rather than reading each and every one of the recommendations into my brief comments this evening, I will just pick up one that has received a degree of publicity and was subject to very deep discussions within the Committee. This recommendation suggests that we hold a series of national conferences to discuss the introduction of new management techniques. Each of us was cynical of the idea of holding conferences because, as we would all know from our work in the Parliament, from conference to conference people can meet up with the same faces, depending on the type of conference that is being attended. We were very much aware of this and of the tremendous value of the interaction that people gain when they meet at a conference when dealing with a matter that is close to them. We were also very clear that we wanted to ensure that we did not at these national conferences-should the Government pick up the Committee's recommendation-just get the professional conference goers. We wanted decision makers to be present at those conferences. We also wanted people who could learn from the interaction of mixing with decision makers.

I commend the idea of those conferences and also another recommendation about international visits. In the report we have mentioned that we have a lot to learn from overseas. We cannot just go overseas and pick up a Japanese, a United States or a British model for the introduction of new management techniques and implement it in Australia. We are a unique society in the same way as Japan, the United States and Britain are unique in their own right. We can certainly learn from them. Experiences from a number of previous international delegations have shown that we have learnt a lot.

We paid many compliments to a joint Commonwealth and State sponsored organisation-the National Industry Extension Service, known as NIES. We felt that that organisation was doing a tremendous job even though in the early stages it had some teething problems. We paid that organisation deserved compliments, we believe. We were also somewhat critical that an organisation as competent as this one obviously is, had some shortcomings. For example, when the Committee research staff tried to contact NIES staff members, the phone rang out on three occasions. We all know how frustrating it can be when we are on the phone and there is no response. The Committee staff also ran into the problem of ringing a transfer station where people take messages and pass them on. But the people taking the messages did not know anything about NIES. If NIES is to service its constituency, as it were, it has to lift its act in this regard. The first point of call is so important. We do not want people who want to move on and get into new innovations with industry switched off because a telephone is not answered. It smacks a little of sloppiness.

NIES has other problems in that it operates somewhat differently within each State because it is a Federal and State organisation. There is enormous competition between the States, as we all know. But there are times when we have to put States issues to one side, look to national benefits and have a lot more cooperation between the States, rather than the competition that greatly exists today. With the earlier comments accepting Senator Crowley's criticisms-I trust the report will not be damaged because of those criticisms-I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Black:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: -I am speaking to this report as a recent member of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, but not one who was deeply involved in the later stages of the inquiry into drugs in sport. The reason for this was partly practical. I was chairing another inquiry with a time limit during much of the period between the interim and final reports of this Committee. The difficulty of travel during the pilots dispute was an added problem. But, taking these factors into consideration, I have to say that I also suffered a lack of motivation to participate more fully, particularly after the hearings which led to the interim report, because of my grave concern about the way this inquiry was conducted.

SPEECH.PARA: The conduct of the inquiry and the hyper-publicity surrounding it have clearly been acceptable to the majority of the Committee, but I believe they are not in the best interests of a balanced inquiry or of the future of the Senate committee system. I point out that this view is not an afterthought. Committee members know that I voiced these concerns from an early stage of the inquiry.

Substantial parts of the inquiry have investigated matters which might be more appropriately investigated in a court, some sort of judicial inquiry, or the ethics body of a profession. Witnesses were probingly, and at time aggressively, questioned about events which might come within the criminal law or allegations which may be defamatory, in a situation which did not allow for the safeguards of legal representation, in most cases, cross-examination or appeal, or the use of the legal rules of evidence.

A number of hearings were conducted before television cameras, often under a blaze of lights and sometimes in the already intimidatory theatre atmosphere of the main committee room in this building. This was not the usual videotaping of short segments for a background to a journalist's report; but full taping of lengthy sections of hearings. Anyone in the television audience watching this show, even when the witness was being questioned in a reasonable way, is likely to think long and hard before offering to appear at a Senate inquiry-unless he or she has their own agenda of blackening a rival or gaining publicity for themselves, as a few witnesses clearly did. For most people it is sufficiently intimidating to appear as a witness before a Senate committee without the added fear of public media scrutiny. Many constituents have expressed these feelings to me and my own reaction has been to think at times of the star chamber atmosphere of some of the United States Senate inquiries.

I was interested to see a lawyer comment on the 7.30 Report in Melbourne last week that the inquiry reminded him of a kangaroo court. He held that such an inquiry should have been held in camera. He pointed out that, because parts of the evidence were in camera and parts in open hearing, witnesses could make allegations which could not readily be answered by those against whom the allegations were made. He also pointed out that much of the evidence related to events of several years ago. I note the comments of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in her press release. She said:

We must be very careful in how we handle this, and ensure there is not undue concentration on what some individuals may, or may not, have done in the past. If we don't, many people will be hurt and ultimately, it will be sport that suffers. It is essential that we look forward rather than backwards.

She also said that `the Government has no intention of implementing a wholesale witch-hunt'. Perhaps of greater importance, though, is the devotion of the time of this Committee to this inquiry, to the neglect of the many very important areas which might be investigated in the portfolio areas of the environment, recreation and the arts. In fact, this inquiry delayed the progress of work on our prior reference on the environmental impact of development aid, which was tabled recently, and which many Australians would regard as of far more real importance than the question of drugs in sport.

I believe there are problems with the slender basis for some of the conclusions in the report, but time does not allow me to go into that matter tonight. I certainly do not agree with some of the Committee members-or perhaps the majority of the Committee-that there should be an ongoing commitment of the Committee to the matter of drugs in sport. If the Senate thought that such an ongoing involvement of the Senate was warranted, it could establish a select committee and allow the Standing Committee to take on other inquiries.

By all means, let us seek to make all sport drug-free, but I would be more concerned about educating young people about the health risks of taking performance-enhancing drugs-or, indeed, any drugs-than whether some adult cheated some years ago or an official erred by inadvertent omission rather than commission. As a letter writer wrote to the Age last week:
If sportspersons resort to drugs in order to gain an unfair advantage and kill themselves in the process, so be it. I won't worry.
I hope that the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts in future sessions of Parliament turns to more socially useful inquiries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to speak about a different aspect of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, but as a deputy chairman of the Committee I cannot stand idly by and listen to tripe of that nature without responding in some way.
—Use proper language.

—That is exactly what it was, and if the Minister had read the report he would know that. The Committee report was adopted unanimously by every political party in this Parliament. I am staggered to hear an Australian Labor Party senator suggest that, if an athlete dies from an overdose of drugs, so be it. The tragedy is that, as evidence given to the Committee demonstrated, children as young as 13 and 14 years of age have been provided with anabolic steroids by their parents. The Committee received evidence of athletes having died of massive heart attacks because of a lack of understanding and a lack of awareness of the effects of the use and abuse of drugs.

SPEECH.PARA: The great tragedy for young people and adolescents who are not yet through puberty taking anabolic steroids is that it closes their bone ends and stunts their growth. They become dwarfs. There is a long record of deaths in sport as a result of the use and abuse of drugs. If there is one thing lacking in the Australian community at all levels of sport and society, it is an education process as to the effects that illegal, performance-enhancing drugs can have on the human body. I am absolutely staggered, but not surprised, I suppose, that Senator Zakharov would think that it is important to have an inquiry into the effects on the environment of our foreign aid to other countries than it is to concern ourselves about the health of our athletes and our children-our future generation. It says something about priorities that we are very much more concerned about whales than we are about human lives. I always thought that that was a rather quaint priority.

The inquiry, in my view, was not an easy one because it involved people's egos and, to some degree, people's reputations. Whenever it was likely that hearsay evidence was going to be introduced by a witness we took it in camera. That can never be proved to the satisfaction of the majority of the Senate, but Senator Zakharov, who sat on the Committee and who has access to in camera evidence, is somebody who would know that.

To criticise the findings of the Committee simply gives succour and comfort to the cheats and the crooks, the pedlars of these illicit, illegal and dangerous drugs. I would have thought that there was nothing more irresponsible than that.

For the duration of the inquiry, each political party in this Parliament had a representative on it. It was conducted in a bipartisan way. The recommendations and the findings that flow from the report are based on substantial evidence and a reasonable reading of that evidence.

Without exception, to my understanding, thus far not one recommendation of the interim report has been rejected by the Government. While the Government has not yet, of course, responded to the second report, I am not aware of its intention to reject any of the findings save for one which calls for the setting up of an independent drug testing appeals tribunal, which is intended to provide a forum for athletes and sporting bodies who judge they have been unfairly and unreasonably treated. I understand the Government's view is that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is adequate for that. It is not our view, but it is intended as a future and further safety mechanism.

The great tragedy is that there is not within the community a greater awareness of the effects that drugs are having upon our athletes or a full awareness of the level and depth of the use of drugs, not only by elite athletes but by athletes at all levels of the sporting community. It is a pity that the findings of the report which have thus far been reported in the media are the more controversial recommendations and that the issues of great moment are those such as whether Jane Flemming ought to be further investigated, the recommendations relating to setting up tribunals or recommendations in terms of the conduct of doctors who prescribe veterinary and human anabolic steroids and the conduct of chemists-in one case 700 prescriptions of animal anabolic steroids were provided in a period of seven months-and whether they ought to be investigated. There are wide-ranging recommendations which, as I say, in my view will be accepted and endorsed by the Government and, I am certain, embraced by each of the political parties.

Of course, there have been officials and athletes who have been unhappy with the report, and that is natural. I think this is probably the first inquiry that has ever investigated in a proper way the use of taxpayers' money in the funding of sport. Had it not been for this inquiry we would be down where we are--

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Clerk-An order relating to details of all provisions of Acts which come into effect on proclamation and which have not been proclaimed, together with a statement of reasons for their non-proclamation and a timetable for their operation, is tabled pursuant to the order of the Senate of 29 November 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The document with regard to unproclaimed legislation is one of a series that the Senate receives twice a year, one which has a relatively recent history in this form but quite a long history, as some honourable senators may know, in another form. It is an important document in terms of the way that we do our business and this one has some interesting further items in it. Thirty-four items that appeared on the previous document that we got six months ago are still in here, and there are 16 new items. Some of our old favourites, unfortunately, have disappeared. Our early 1920s unproclaimed legislation had dropped off, unfortunately; however, an old chestnut of the Naval Properties Transfer Act 1925 is still with us and we are still beavering away to endeavour to get something done on this particular interesting piece of legislation. If honourable senators can but hold their breath, we are informed that in the autumn session of 1990 we will at last dispose of this rather interesting piece of legislation which some parliament in 1925, in the full flush of its vigour, managed to pass and which we have never done anything with. So it is very nice that this Parliament in 1990 will finally put the kybosh on something from 1925.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they proclaim that particular Act.

—If the Government can manage to proclaim that particular Act, yes. I will acknowledge in this regard Senator Puplick's endearing and long term interest in this matter. He undoubtedly will follow me in speaking. I am not sure who is going to take up this rather esoteric piece after we both leave, but I hope someone does.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to page 2 of the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Act of 1989. This is one of the new items and it is noted that its provisions will come into effect on 30 September 1990. The reason for that is that, as a result of the Senate insisting on this particular document, the drafting instructions which have been given have been altered so that new legislation coming into this chamber either has a date or comes into operation six months from the date of royal assent. Indeed, if we look on the following page, we find that the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 says:

This Act received Royal Assent on 17 January 1990 and will automatically come into operation six months and one day after Royal Assent, unless proclaimed before that date. Proclamation before 18 July 1990 is unlikely.

In other words, people have not managed to get around to following the new operation. Whether they like it or not, this will happen automatically on 18 July. I think that is a very important move for this chamber and the Parliament in general, and I hope that in coming years honourable senators will concentrate at least on this item to make sure that the departments of state are kept up to that particular proposal and that they will take the opportunity, when these debates come around every six months, to go through these documents to make sure that the departments are keeping up on this.

This document contains the normal long list of parliamentary time wasting that we have come to accept. Unfortunately, the Attorney-General's Department is the worst. It has wasted more time and not done anything with it than any other department. Considering the very small amount of time we have in this chamber-I know that the Minister at the table, Senator Tate, has often complained about how little legislative time we get in the ordinary course of a day-it would be nice if we dealt with Bills which did something rather than Bills that are left to languish in a bureaucrat's drawer for days, months, and, in fact, years on end.

In 1986 we all gathered our collective wisdom to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Bill. I remember it because I spoke in the debate about the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). We deliberated at great length and, in our wisdom, changed the legislation. ASIO had in fact employed people on a statutory basis. We thought that this was no good. So the Parliament had the collective wit to pass a piece of legislation to put it on a contractual basis. However, it has now been decided that that is no good at all and that we might as well stay with the statutory basis. So we are going to repeal that piece of legislation. That must be a prime example of parliamentary time wasting. But it also reflects on both the Attorney-General's Department, which brought it in, the Parliament for passing it and, now, the bureaucrats for even suggesting it. Now that they have changed their minds, they want to change the Parliament's mind. I must admit that if I were here to deal with this matter, I have a sneaking suspicion that the repeal Bill should be defeated. But that would probably be somewhat churlish with regard to this matter.

The Cash Transaction Reports Act is interesting, not because it is a new addition to the list-it is not; it has been there before-but because we are given a whole new reason why nothing is happening. An interesting feature in respect of this Act is that different reasons are given for its being unproclaimed. Some reasons run out in the fullness of time and cannot be used any more or new people write them. What I like about this document is that the job of creating it seems to have been given to someone who knows what he is doing as distinct from the person who wrote the previous document. It is evident that that document had been given to someone a long way down the line who had not the faintest idea what the legislation was about or what possible reasons could be given to the Parliament for wasting its time. However, in the current document we are getting a lot of better reasons from some departments. Again, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has managed to find someone in the Department who actually knows what the pieces of legislation are about. In the case of the Cash Transaction Reports Act, we have a reason which actually makes some sense. I hope that in future the departments will continue to give this job to somebody who knows what he is going.

I would like to draw attention to some of the other Acts from a different viewpoint. When the Circuit Layouts Act and the Copyright Amendment Act were dealt with in this place-I think Senator Puplick was involved in this exercise-they were considered to be of the utmost urgency. We were brought together in a rush. We had to get these things through and really move them along. We were told that there was time wasting during the committee stage. Now we see that this legislation is still languishing around. The following comments are made in respect of the Circuit Layouts Act:
It now appears that early enactment of these amendments will not be possible.

The Department was not organised in that it did not get the timetable right. We dealt with the Circuit Layouts Act before the Government signed the Washington Treaty on Intellectual Property in Respect of Integrated Circuits. The Department then found that it had to change the Act which had been passed a month or two earlier. At that stage we were told that we were holding up the legislation. Having held it up, we are now told:
It now appears that early enactment of the amendments will not be possible.

Accordingly, we are to go ahead with the piece of legislation we passed in the first place. It would be nice if people could get their acts together, but I suppose that that is a bit too much to ask. But if they cannot, I wonder whether the Government would look at its general timetable and see what treaties or major conferences are coming up which are likely to impact on the legislation which we are called together hurriedly to consider, to vote on with a great deal of urgency and flurry, and which is allowed to languish.

The Crimes (Hostages) Act has received a new reason-a far better reason than last time. Seemingly, the same person from the Attorney-General's Department has managed to find out a lot about these Acts. This is rather nice to see. One of the nice things about some of these reasons is that they tell us what is going to happen and why. The intent of this Parliament's motion was to try to find out what was going on and not be subject to a little bit of Yes, Minister treatment.
Unfortunately, the Department of Community Services and Health should get a special medal this time. It has found a new phrase which undoubtedly will occur again and again-that is:
It is intended to repeal these provisions as soon as the priorities of the Government's legislation program will allow.
As this Department is not the only department that uses this phrase, obviously somebody has actually thought it up over a drink in a bar somewhere. This has now become the accepted phrase to pop in.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't go to the bar, surely.

—Well, it is a nice one. However, it falls rather flat in the case of Community Services and health because it was around last time. In fact, it is one of our chestnuts. This phrase could have been tacked on to three pieces of legislation from that Department. `As soon as the priorities of the Government's legislation program will allow' probably means the same thing as saying `as soon as possible'. But `possible' does not seem to be when the Parliament will make it possible, but when somebody else gets around actually to putting the things into the legislation. Can I suggest that that phrase could be tacked onto other Bills which are coming through with regard to health legislation. I am quite sure that no-one in the Senate would object to this in the slightest. The Senate Clerks and others have to keep these matters in some order for the courts, lawyers and advisers, and members of the community need to know what laws they are supposed to observe. That being so, it would make everybody else's job a lot easier if we got rid of most of these Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: We are having another `hasten slowly' exercise in respect of the Health Legislation Amendment Act 1986. We are going to do it again `as soon as the priorities will allow'. I have commented before on the Control of Naval Waters Amendment Act. I am very glad to see that this is the last time we are going to see this Act around because these long extended debates that the Commonwealth has been having, presumably since 1978, with the States have finally come to fruition. We are breathlessly informed that an agreement has been reached. I am sure that all of those people who have been hanging on for the Control of Naval Waters Amendment Act can now rest easy. Agreement has been reached and it is going to be out of the way on 1 August. So vale to the control of the Naval Waters Amendment Act.

I can remember discussing the Laying Chicken Levy Act. This may strike honourable senators as odd, but it was actually debated with legislation dealing with booze and muesli at the end of the session. The Laying Chicken Levy Collection Act is another staggering Bill. It is nice to know that these Acts will be proclaimed on 1 July. I am sure that the chooks will be delighted.

I would like to make one last comment with regard to an absolutely irresistible favourite of mine: the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act. This is a gem. In 1947, the Parliament, in its wisdom, passed a piece of legislation which, among other things, required that pensioners and beneficiaries had to notify the Department of Social Security of certain changed circumstances. In 1983 we actually got around to taking out section 163, and thereby hangs a tale. Between 1947 and 1983 we were moving pretty rapidly. We had to hold everything in suspended animation because, as the statement of reasons says, `a small group of clients had not yet received forms requiring notification under section 163'. The commencement of those provisions would have excused those clients from notifying changed circumstances. As honourable senators doubtless will be aware, all social security clients have now received that notice. I remind honourable senators that the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill went through in 1983; it is now 1990, so I am glad that we have managed it at last. The statement of reasons says that the fact that all social security clients had now received a notice makes it possible to repeal the 1983 provisions; I think the 1947 provisions, rather than the 1983 provisions, are meant.

I did a little calculation which leads me to hope that the particular pensioners we are referring to were not old age pensioners in 1947, because they would now be 103. I really think we could have left the poor old dears alone and not harassed them with requirement of notification under section 163, no matter how assiduous we were. I really believe we should have let them live the twilight of their lives without giving them this onerous paperwork.

Nevertheless, having read the statement of reasons, honourable senators will now know that this is all about to end on 1 June 1990. Because I will not be around I would have been upset if I had not been able to comment on this matter yet again, but it is nice to know that it has all been settled and those 103-year-olds can now rest easy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were going to say rest in peace.

—They can rest easy, watching television; although to watch the Senate must be an even worse fate than that mentioned by Senator Tate. They can rest easy and not have to fill out forms under section 163. Although I said that in a somewhat joking fashion, it is a serious matter; it is an important matter. As I have said in passing, the reason for that is this: We have a principle in law that says that you have to obey the laws and that ignorance of the law is not an excuse.

SPEECH.PARA: Until the Senate insisted on this particular item, the difficulty was in actually finding out what was the law. The passage though this Parliament does not make it the law; the royal assent does not make it the law; it is not law until it is proclaimed. Yet the courts have been guessing, legal practitioners certainly have been guessing, and almost everybody in the community has been guessing at what precisely the law is. At least now twice a year we are able to go through this tidying up exercise. I want to say to the people in the departments who engaged in this exercise that we are making progress, I value the work that they have put in, and I hope that every department will be just that little bit more assiduous. I am quite sure we can get down this number quite considerably by looking at any legislation that is coming through to see whether it might be a suitable vehicle to do the repealing work that is necessary. Once we get this in order-and I think it probably ought to be able to be done within the next 12 months-we will then have a slender document. It will be dealing only with quite recent pieces of legislation. In that regard, it will make the certainty of the law in everybody's mind a much more obtainable goal.

I make one last appeal. Not many senators have shown an interest in this particular matter. Senator Puplick is one, and he is leaving at the same time as I am. I hope that other honourable senators will see this as an important item that should be drawn attention to and will, in fact, draw such attention to it over the next two to three years when I think it will be crucial to embed this as a feature of the Senate's work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to start off by echoing the concluding remarks of Senator Macklin. He is correct in saying that he and I will be leaving this place at the end of this session and that by and large we have been, I think, the only senators to follow and pursue the question of unproclaimed legislation. I believe that other people have a responsibility now to take up this particular challenge because we are in a situation in which we are given these reports only because of the original insistence of this chamber to know what the status of legislation was. This is the fourth report which we have had.

SPEECH.PARA: I start off by commending whoever is responsible for the cover page-I presume it is likely to be officers of the Senate rather than officers of any department-which does actually have a date on it. Honourable senators will recall that on the last occasion we complained about the fact that we had a very lengthy document, at that stage of some 25 pages, which had no date on it. It was virtually impossible to work out whether it was the first, second or third in the series. This is now the fourth and, as Senator Macklin says, it contains some golden oldies including the Naval Properties Transfer Act of 1925, and it includes some additions.

I want to take a moment just to mention one or two of the matters which remain on the list. It is interesting that in relation to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Act 1987 in the previous report the following comment was made:
It is not intended that paragraph 23 (1) (ea) be proclaimed at present pending further consideration of the effects of the provision.

In other words, the Department was actually saying, `Now that we have passed this Act we will actually think about what it means and, until we have thought about what it means, we are not going to proclaim it'. We are presumably to accept the wonderful argument that when the Department actually presented the legislation to us it decided that it ought to come clean and ought to confess. It did not actually know what the effect of the legislation was going to be when it brought the legislation to the Parliament and, because it has now actually had a couple of thoughts about what the effect of the legislation might be, it will eventually get round to its proclamation in due course.

I am vaguely sorry to see the end of the Naval Properties Transfer Act 1925. It is an old and familiar friend. We are told that the intention of the Government is that in the Administrative Services Legislation Amendment Bill, introduced during the autumn session 1990, there are provisions for the repeal of this Act. As I said by way of interjection, it will be interesting to see whether the sections which repeal the 1925 Act are themselves proclaimed in good time.

I will come to the question of what I might call, I guess, subsidiary unproclaimed legislation just to test whether this document is entirely accurate. Senator Macklin has mentioned the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1989. I find it passing strange that the Government introduces amendments to electoral law and then has the capacity to determine which parts of electoral law that the Parliament has approved that it will cause to be put in place prior to an election. This is a most extraordinary principle, because there could be a situation in which, theoretically, the Parliament decided to abolish compulsory voting but an election was imminent and the Government decided, after it had done a bit of research, that for the next election it might like to hang on to compulsory voting and abolish compulsory voting only after the election was over. Yet this is what has happened with the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Act-the Government selectively decided, prior to the March election, which parts of the new electoral legislation, which had been passed by the Parliament in expectation that they would govern the conduct of a forthcoming election, were to be introduced, proclaimed and operative for the election which then came upon us.

Frankly, I think that that is a most dangerous principle, and I think that when the Senate in future looks at electoral legislation in particular it should have careful mind as to whether, when it is a Bill as complicated as the 1989 amendment Act was-many of the parts and clauses related to each other-there should be any capacity for the Act to be proclaimed in part. It should be a requirement of that sort of legislation that it is a take it or leave it, one in all in provision. The capacity to proclaim parts but leave other parts swinging in the wind until after an election has been concluded is not a legitimate tool to leave in the hands of government, particularly since no government with the capacity to influence electoral law, over and above the way in which the Parliament has influenced electoral law, should be allowed potentially to advantage itself by deciding what is to be given effect and what is not.

I mention the Koongarra Project Area Act. We are told that section 3 will not be proclaimed until the current review of the Australian Labor Party's uranium policy is completed and the Government decides on the future of mining at Koongarra. That was not the understanding of the Parliament. When it passed the Act, it had a clear understanding of what that policy was supposed to be. Here again is a piece of legislation which, we are told, having been passed by the Parliament, must now wait upon ratification by the ALP's National Conference. What a scandal it is to be told that an Act of Parliament will be frustrated, and part of it will not be proclaimed, until such time as the executive, or the policy making body of one of the political parties, decides whether or not that part of the legislation of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia should be brought into effect. That is equally scandalous. It is a contempt of the Parliament, in my view, for that sort of situation to occur.

I mention next the Hazardous Waste Regulation of Exports and Imports Act 1989. I note that the important thing about that is that it is one of the pieces of legislation-again, Senator Macklin has mentioned this-that comes into operation six months and one day after royal assent, unless proclaimed before that date. That is a very important trigger mechanism-that there will be automatic effect of certain pieces of legislation if proclamation is delayed.

I look at the Copyright Amendment Act 1989. I see that some of the sections cannot be brought into operation until the collecting societies, which are required to be established under the Act, have been approved and formed, with the authority of the Attorney-General, under subsection 135zzb (1). Again, I believe that an excessive delay has occurred here. The collecting societies could well have been put in place, could well have been authorised by the Attorney-General, prior to this date if the Attorney-General had not been so dilatory in his responsibilities in this regard.

I will not refer to the community services and health area. Senator Macklin has adequately covered that area. I mention the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989. We are told that the delay here is the need to prepare supporting regulations. I think the Parliament has a right, from time to time, to insist on seeing the regulations before it actually allows other things to proceed. You will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we created a precedent in relation to the Therapeutic Goods Act by requiring a new method of dealing with regulations. We said that until the regulations had been approved by the Parliament, the primary Act was of no effect. Again, I hope that departments of state will come to understand that in the Senate our determination to see regulatory instruments prior to giving assent in the normal fashion is something which is proceeding apace.

I mention two other very brief matters. I refer honourable senators to the comments that Senator Macklin made in relation to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Act 1986. Parliament undertook reforms because it was told they were necessary. We took some time to debate those reforms. Once we passed those reforms some bureaucrat decided that they were not necessary. We are now to wait for another piece of legislation or regulatory arrangement to unscramble the situation about which we got ourselves into knots trying to establish in the first place.

Unnecessary delays are again taking place in respect of the Circuit Layouts Act. One would have thought that consultations with industry would have taken place before the Health Legislation Amendment Act 1986. Here is a 1986 Act-and we are still waiting on extensive consultations with industry before we can get into that particular matter. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Act 1983 was held up so that a small group of clients could be accommodated, whatever that particularly means. The Satellite Communications Amendment Act, in respect of which we are now told that we have to wait until Aussat's satellite footprint is properly reviewed before it can be brought into effect, was a major piece of legislation in which the role of Aussat in providing services to what were called neighbouring regions was going to be an important element in the telecommunications strategy in Australia.

At least we are better off than some of our colleagues in places like the United Kingdom, where the proclamation of various schedules to Acts of Parliament is an absolute nightmare. The Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch, was good enough to provide me with a copy of statutory instrument 1985 No. 70(C.2), which has a schedule of the arrangements by which the Control of Pollution Act 1974 is to be brought into effect. Frankly, the thing is an absolute nightmare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think you should tell anyone about it? They might use it.

—I would like to, but I am anxious not to unnecessarily delay the Senate on this particular matter. I simply say that at least they have the quaint problem that some parts of the Act have effect in England and Wales but do not have effect in Scotland, or vice versa.
—What about Northern Ireland?

—I do not think the rule of law runs to Northern Ireland, actually. The dates of commencement just demonstrate how difficult it is for Parliament to play a proper role in ensuring that legislation which it has passed is then properly given effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point I make is that there do appear to be some questions about the accuracy of this particular document. The first matter I raise is that the unproclaimed sections of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1985 were apparently repealed by the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act (No. 4) 1989. That may not be entirely accurate in its reflection in this document.

Finally, as to the corporations legislation, it appears that some of the items on the previous list are tied by their commencement clauses to the proclamation of another Act, namely, the Corporations Act 1989, the relevant chapters of which have still not been proclaimed. However, the Corporations (Fees) Act 1989 itself is dependent on proclamation and is also missing from the list. In any case, it would appear to me that, as a general principle, Acts which are dependent for their starting date on another Act which relies on proclamation should properly be included on the list, as indeed was the case on previous lists.

I, therefore, conclude by saying that I am very pleased to have played some small role in bringing into the Senate a new procedure and a new scrutiny of executive behaviour in this regard. I do hope that honourable senators who will be remaining in this place will take some interest in this question of proclamation of legislation, because it has become a real eye-opener to me to follow this over the course of the last two years and to see the extent to which the Parliament, having acted in good faith in that it has passed legislation which it expects to come into effect, finds that by executive fiat or bureaucratic inertia its clear intentions are frustrated. I do not believe that Parliament should allow that to pass without comment. I do not believe that Parliament, as a principle, should allow it to continue the way in which it has in the last couple of years.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: TRAINING GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1990
Clause 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Minister could outline to us at least some of the detail of what the Government expects to spend money on-what sorts of courses the Government has in mind for the funds which will accumulate under this Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has indicated on a number of occasions that the general direction of this Bill is in uplifting training in the community. It is intended that revenues net of administration and monitoring costs will be distributed to State and Territory governments on the basis of their agreement to certain conditions. Those conditions include that they support the training guarantee, undertake to spend the revenue on additional training activities and disburse the revenue on the advice of a designated tripartite body.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators can see, State governments will be required to apply the same discipline to what they spend money on as is required of private employees. They will need to direct funds given by the Commonwealth to eligible training programs and activities. Training programs will need to be structured and provide employment-related skills. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we were going to take the Bill as a whole. This is probably the appropriate clause under which to raise again a number of questions that I raised during the second reading debate.

—I think that is in order. There are four amendments, which is why I am taking the Bill clause by clause. Clause 1, which is the title, is the extent of the Bill, so it is proper to ask general questions under that heading-but not too general.

—Some of these matters refer quite specifically to various clauses. I would be happy to try to sort them out, but it may be simpler to ask them here. One follows on from the question about how the State governments will disburse the moneys that they receive. My problem with that is that undoubtedly the moneys will be paid in by certain firms which have failed to reach the level of training.

SPEECH.PARA: My first concern relates to a particular industry which is geographically situated. The car industry is a geographically situated industry. I do not think the car industry will be prominent in this, but we can use it as an example. It may fall below the level and may pay in a significant amount of money. If the money is disbursed on the basis of payroll-I understand that is the proposal-undoubtedly Queensland will receive some of that; although Queensland has a Volvo assembly plant it does not produce as many cars as does South Australia or Victoria. My concern relates to the inequitable distribution using that particular method.

My second concern is about the industries which have under trained. The Technical and Further Education (TAFE) colleges are very active in this area. TAFE perhaps does not offer a particular course. The reason for that would be that those industries have not sought training, hence TAFE has not introduced a course. Why should TAFE put a course on even now, despite the fact that this particular industry has under trained. The only way I can see around that is by identifying where we are falling down and seeking to compensate that deficiency in a pro-active way. SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, line 9, leave out ``1 July 1990''; insert ``1 January 1991''.

The amendment proposed by the Opposition is to change the date of commencement of the Act from 1 July 1990 to 1 January 1991. The Opposition has already made it very clear in the second reading debate, and through my attempts on its behalf, to refer this Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill to a Senate standing committee. The Opposition is by no means satisfied that this Bill has been available for long enough for all those affected by it to come to grips with it. The answer that the Minister has given to that is `Oh well, the whole proposal has been around for a long time. We did have a Bill out at the end of last year and people should have dropped everything that they were doing, all their other responsibilities and concerns, and concentrate on our proposal'. That is typical of the attitude of this Government on numerous matters, namely, the whole community is supposed to wait on it rather than it trying to consult with the community and give it the opportunity to make its contribution.

The fact is that this Bill was introduced into the Parliament on only 10 May. For Senator Macklin's benefit I assure him that this is the Bill that I, and other Opposition senators, have been working on in this debate. It is not the old Bill. There are many difficulties with this piece of legislation which we have sought, in the course of the debate, to point out. At this stage we would hope that if this Bill is going to be passed more or less in its present form, which seems to be the case in view of the attitude of the Australian Democrats, at least people will be given a reasonable opportunity to be properly instructed on it. They will also have the opportunity to study it and get advice about it.

In fact, there are a number of very important things that the Government still has to do to bring this Bill into a state in which it can be brought into effect. Part 10 of the Bill, which deals with the registration of industrial training agents, and section 43, which deals with the granting of training advisory certificates, do not need to come into operation until 1 January 1991. It certainly seems very likely that that date will be the effective date.

People have got to have these industrial training agents appointed. Indeed, the Bill contemplates that guidelines will be passed in regard to the appointment of such persons. Again, part 10 of the Bill deals with this, and it does not have to come into operation until 1 January next year. As I have said, guidelines may well be made by the Minister in relation to the appointment of these people.

In addition to that, clause 30 of the Bill provides that the Minister may make guidelines in relation to eligible training programs. We have already pointed out the very great difficulties there are in giving effect to the provisions of clause 27 about eligible training programs. There are major difficulties that are going to arise there. Guidelines certainly will be required and hopefully will be of some help. This is going to be one of the key sections of the Act and is going to give rise to some of the most difficult decisions. Clearly, the appointment of industrial training agents is going to be a very important part of that process, yet they may not be able to be appointed until the end of the year.

So there are some very clear reasons within the terms of the Bill itself why 1 July is an inappropriate date to choose. Also, a lot of the more formal training courses do not commence in the middle of the year. I understand that they are more likely to be commencing at the beginning of a year.

Broadly, the Opposition's case in relation to this amendment is that further time is desperately going to be needed by people who are going to be affected by this legislation. In order for them to really understand it, they will need to get professional advice. They will need to get the advice of industrial training agents and other industry advisory councils who will have a role to play in this.

Generally speaking, this whole exercise is likely to get off the ground in a much more satisfactory way if the commencement of the legislation is postponed to 1 January 1991. When all is said and done, much legislation-in many cases, difficult and new legislation-is given a reasonable time after it passes through the Parliament before it is proclaimed, or the date on which it is to take effect is a time considerably in the future, or it waits until the Government has got its act ready and can proclaim it.

As I said, much legislation has been postponed for a longer period than that. Here there are many things that the Government itself has got to do before people can reasonably be expected to know how the legislation affects them. Again, I emphasise that we are not talking about the fact that it has been discussed, in general terms, for some period. We are talking about this particular legislation having been rushed through.
