SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay honourable senators any longer than I need to but I wish to raise two matters briefly in the chamber this evening. The first one concerns the standard of protection given to members of the public who enter into residential building contracts.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been approached by an association, known as the Building Action Review Group, to take up its concerns at the unsatisfactory level of protection given to home builders. When I looked at the specific case drawn to my attention-that of Mrs Irene and Mr Joseph Onorati of Drummoyne, New South Wales-unfortunately I found there was not a lot of practical assistance I could give them, largely because the matters they raised with me were State issues and of a legal nature. Nevertheless, I felt that if I could draw attention to their plight it might at least give them some comfort as well as warn others of the pitfalls of entering into such residential building contracts.

The Onoratis entered into a contract with Phillips Constructions Pty Ltd in August 1984. This company undertook to build for them five home units on their land at Drummoyne under what is known as a standard BC3 contract. On completion, the building was found to be defective in many respects. This was confirmed by the advice received by the Onoratis from independent architects, engineers, the New South Wales Builders Licensing Board and others. The Onoratis withheld the final payment, I think reasonably, to Phillips Constructions of $120,000 until the defects, some of which were quite serious, were rectified.

The builder exercised his right under the contract to take the matter to arbitration. Mr Donald Bruce Maxwell was appointed arbitrator in this case. Despite the evidence brought by the Onoratis from independent architects, engineers and the Builders Licensing Board as to the building's defects and the estimated cost of rectifying them of $500,000, the arbitrator ordered that the builder pay them only $84,000. He also ordered that the Onoratis pay the builder's costs of the arbitration totalling $280,000 and the arbitrator's costs of $19,000. As well, they were left to pay their own legal costs of $300,000.

The Onoratis then availed themselves of such avenues as were available to them to get justice in the courts but found these were too limited for their circumstances. The contract which they had signed made arbitration mandatory as the method of settling disputes, and the arbitrator's decision had, despite the evidence, gone substantially against them. They are now left with a defective building, liabilities for its rectification and other costs totalling about $1m. Phillips Constructions lost its builder's licence, and the company went into liquidation. However, I have been told that the principal of that company has set up in business since under a new company structure.

The Onoratis are facing financial ruin and, understandably, are suspicious about the process of arbitration, which is made mandatory under the terms of building contracts. They feel that too often appointed arbitrators, who are often former builders, are biased. That is an understandable concern. They did not understand when they entered into this contract that arbitration could be so protracted and expensive a process. Neither did they realise that they would be giving up their rights to seek justice in the courts.

The New South Wales Government has taken some steps to improve consumer protection with its Building Services Corporation Act. The Onoratis and the Building Action Review Group, of which Mrs Onorati is the chairperson, feel that further reform is needed. In particular, they would like to see an end to mandatory arbitration clauses in building contracts.

The NSW Housing Minister, Mr Joe Schipp, has had a report from the Building Services Corporation before him since about July 1989 which makes just this recommendation. The report also recommends that a mediation process be required to explore whether a dispute can be resolved without the need for arbitration and legal proceedings, which can be ruinously expensive to home builders who are often fully committed financially in meeting the basic contract price.

The Onoratis would also like to see an end to the practice whereby the building industry is, in their own words, both judge and jury in disputes with building services consumers. I am aware that the Australian Standards Association is preparing a new form of standard residential building contract which could be fairer to the consumer. The draft was circulated last year for comment and Mrs Onorati's group has criticised it as inadequate in a number of respects.

Among the reforms they would like to see are: an end to mandatory arbitration clauses in residential building contracts; an end to the practice of builders being appointed as arbitrators because of the possibility of bias toward the builder party in a dispute; the establishment of a national consumers' advisory body; a standard form residential building contract that is adopted nationally and which offers much more protection to often unsuspecting consumers of building services than is afforded by the forms presently in use; and an inquiry into past arbitrations to expose unjust and unfair decisions and offer some form of redress to the victims.

I support the Onorati's claims and I note that for a number of them a Commonwealth role is evident. In addition, I would also support a review of relevant Commonwealth law, including the Trade Practices Act, to determine what additional protection can be given to Australian home builders.

Irene and Joseph Onorati have worked very hard all their lives. They accumulated sufficient capital to invest in a substantial property and expected the income from it to support them in their latter years. Instead they are facing a doubtful old age. A few weeks ago they were served with an order to pay many thousands of dollars of costs arising out of unsuccessful legal proceedings which they commenced in the hope of overturning the arbitration that left them with a liability of about $1m and a building that would be difficult to dispose of in its present condition. I have been told that Mr Onorati's health has declined under the stress of their ordeal, and that does not surprise me. I sincerely hope that the New South Wales Government will find some means to assist them.

Secondly, I wish to make some observations on the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Unfortunately formal comment to the Government's response was not possible last session and since that time there have been some very interesting developments-indeed alarming, one might say. The first of these is the very recently revealed sequel to the explosion on the USS Iowa which was mentioned during the debate after the tabling of the Senate Committee's report. The United States Navy has attempted to attribute the disaster on board the USS Iowa to deliberate sabotage, and that is alarming enough, but the Navy's official explanation has been completely undermined by recent tests that have produced an explosion by simulating ordinary gun loading procedure. We can add this evidence of design or materials failure to the long list of recent similar and unfortunate accidents aboard United States warships. Secondly, there is the much more serious evidence that many United States nuclear weapons have serious design faults. This was raised in the Sydney Morning Herald on 24 May this year in an article which was taken from the Washington Post. It was also raised on several television channels. To quote from the article:

In a series of secret moves, the United States Government discovered-and is repairing-defective nuclear artillery shells that could have exploded accidentally while stored in Europe, and has started urgent studies of the designs of two other atomic warheads whose safety is suspect
Urgent orders were issued not to move the warheads, and repair teams hurried to the nuclear ammunition depots to disable the several hundred shells so they could not be accidentally detonated . . .

It is interesting that officials have not denied that such an accidental detonation could result in a nuclear yield. Faults have also been found in an air launch missile, the Short-Range Attack Missile-A-or SRAM-A-and special restrictions have been placed on it. To quote again from this article:

. . . Joint Chiefs of Staff, in a separate nuclear weapons safety incident, last year secretly imposed special restrictions on the handling and deployment of a short-range missile carried by US strategic aircraft, (the Short-Range Attack Missile-A or SRAM-A) in order to avoid accidental explosions that could disperse cancer-causing radioactive plutonium from the missile warhead.

Faults that could lead to a similar accident were also found in one of the newest and shiniest of the United States Navy's weapons, the Trident missile, just now being deployed aboard strategic submarines. I read again from this article:

The Department of Energy . . . last week agreed to a secret congressional request for an independent scientific inquiry into the possibility that a nuclear warhead now being deployed aboard Trident strategic submarines, the W-88, could be detonated in a possible missile-handling accident in port . . .

Chapter 11 of the Senate Committee report makes it clear that the Committee accepts that formal safety assessments of United States nuclear weapons had been done. Interestingly enough, from the same documents I concluded that they had not been done. I quote very briefly from the dissent in that report:

Even the Committee cannot produce `calculations' of any substance on nuclear weapons accident probability and the only overseas figures appear to be a few vague U.S. estimates. One is of the probability of accidental nuclear detonation; less than one in a billion for normal environmental conditions and less than one in a million for extreme cases like a fire. There is a no indication that these are calculations rather than guesses and the plump roundness of the figures rather suggests the latter.

The risk assessments like these which are accepted by the Committee are nothing but a fiction. Indeed, now we find out that the risk assessments for any United States nuclear weapons had not been done at the time that the Committee was considering its conclusions. In fact, that process is being commenced only now. The Lawrence Livermore laboratory did computer simulations of the probability of a nuclear weapons accident. All these are highly secret, of course, and certainly not available to the Senate Committee. The Secretary of Energy, Mr James Watkins, is quoted in the article previously referred to. It states:

. . . ``we're not all that comfortable'' with the Government's past approach to several safety issues, and ``we need to focus a lot more'' on measures to diminish the risk of accidentally dispersing plutonium in warheads.
The article continues:

Mr Watkins has ordered what other officials say is the first comprehensive assessment of the probability of an accident involving any of the more than 20,000 nuclear warheads deployed with US force around the globe.

These recent revelations cast new light on some of the sanguine conclusions of the Senate Committee report, but as we know Senate committee reports sink without a trace-this one perhaps like a discarded nuclear reactor. I encourage fellow members of that Committee of which I was a member and where I prepared a dissent to take a continuing responsibility for that report, to take note of the developments that cast a serious doubt on the validity of the majority report's conclusions. To save the time of the Senate I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a two and a half page formal response to the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SENATOR IRINA DUNN'S COMMENTS ON THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE ON CONTINGENCY PLANS FOR VISITING NUCLEAR WARSHIPS

The official Government response to the Senate Committee report is in marked contrast to the somewhat surly and intemperate remarks made by Defence Minister Beazley at the time of the tabling of the report in the Senate.

The unctuous commendations of the Committee are quite unlike the unconcealed Beazley opinion that the whole endeavour of the Committee enquiry was a waste of time and an intrusion into his private principality.

The prefatory remarks in this paper do deny that there was ever anything to worry about and imply that the only useful function of the Committee was to provide a means of publicising the extremely rigorous and thorough safety provisions already provided by the Government. Later in the general remarks reference is made to ``an already well-functioning safety regime''. It is rather hard to see how the author of the Government's response can assert this in view of the many deficiencies in the existing plans and their implementation exposed during the conduct of the Committee's enquiry and reflected in the number of corrective recommendations. The self-justifying observations in this part of the government response about the benefits of allowing warship visits so that we can enjoy the privilege of playing war-games with US forces I regard as absolute rubbish. The only contingency these very expensive exercises prepares Australian Defence forces for is an invasion by US forces; we could prepare for more likely contingencies with less expensive and more appropriate exercises. And I notice with disquiet the reference to combined Australian/US operations. This is not usually mentioned in the current self-reliance rhetoric; which tacitly recognises the practical uselessness to Australia's defence of the ANZUS/Western Alliance arrangements. I can only suppose that this reference to combined operations means, despite the hard lessons of history, that our Government continues to countenance the possibility of foreign adventures in the service of our principal ally. However, at least the absurd nuclear umbrella argument for accepting nuclear warship visits is noticeable by its absence from the Government's justifications.

The preambulatory comments continue by restating the official conviction that the probability of any nuclear accident is low and the probability of a nuclear weapons accident is ``virtually nil''. The document quotes selectively from the report but I am not surprised that it does not refer to the numerous anomalies in the Committee's report on this subject, or to recommendation 38 on the desirability of having a nuclear weapons accident plan, or, for that matter, to the facts and arguments presented in my dissenting report.

Towards the end of these remarks the report recommendations are categorised in terms of their intent. Basically the Government has agreed in principle with the recommendations in the first three categories and in most cases has promised to put them into effect. However, the most interesting category is the fourth. The Government has rejected these recommendations.
These recommendations are those that suggest a suspension of visits if a particular safety measure is not in place.

The Government response is stated thus: ``The Government does not agree, given the very low risks involved, that individually these concerns are sufficient reasons to prohibit a particular ship visit''.

This spurious argument negates all the pretended rigour and safety-consciousness of the Committee report and reveals the essentially cosmetic nature of the whole safety plan regime. If we need safety plans-and the Government, the previous Coalition Government and the Committee have all agreed that we do-the Government cannot argue that incomplete plans will do for a ``particular ship visit''. It must be complete plans for all ship visits.
I don't have time to deal with the Government responses to each recommendation but I would like to comment on two aspects of these responses.

The first is the rejection of any measure that requires that a request for information or assurance-no matter how trivial-be made to the operators of nuclear-powered vessels. Of course this means the US Navy and I am reminded of the total lack of cooperation the Committee experienced when it sought information from US authorities and the US Navy; the US Navy's dismissal of any need for Australian safety plans is partially reproduced in the response to recommendation 13.

Our Government is clearly reluctant to ask the US Navy anything; either because it fears annoying the navy or because it fears the embarrassment of being told to go away and soak its collective head. This servile attitude is exhibited in the response to recommendations 13 and 14, and I believe it is the real reason for the rejection of recommendation 34 (see 34 (a)). The same motive is probably paramount in the rejection of recommendation 37 which deals with dry-docking; an issue which in 1983 revealed the true nature of our alliance relationship.

I feel that the Committee recommendations that ask for information or assurance from the US Navy actually reflect a degree of naivety on the part of members of the Committee. Despite their lengthy deliberations on the subject of this inquiry they have not realised that Australia just does not ask questions of the US Navy. Expressions of servile gratitude are all we are permitted.

The second matter that I wish to highlight is the response to recommendation 38 which refers to the draft nuclear weapon accident plan prepared by the VSP(N). I discovered the existence of this plan in Brisbane but Mr Beazley refused to show it to the Committee.

It seems very likely that this embarrassing plan will be quietly ignored. The wording of the response is worthy of Sir Humphrey Appleby; ``the Department of Defence is continuing to develop draft guidelines which might form the basis for discussion.''

After this nebulous process is completed discussions with State and Territory governments would begin. It would not be too optimistic to predict that the world will be largely rid of nuclear weapons before this plan is released to the Australian public.

The response document says that ``the basic thrust of the report and the overwhelming majority of its recommendations represent an endorsement of the Government's actions in this area'' and despite the logical contradictions this is essentially accurate.

The major party members of the Committee who endorsed the majority report set out to achieve just this while seeming to be safety-conscious. It is appropriate that the Government should say ``well done my good and faithful servants'', but the Australian people are ill-served by bi-partisan committees that rubber-stamp Government policy while essentially ignoring the dreadful consequences that could follow a serious accident on any of these unnecessary and unwelcome warships.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address an issue raised in an editorial on page 10 of the Sydney Morning Herald on 25 May 1990, which is headed: `Hawke's uneasy stand on crime'. I will just read the first paragraph, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has miscalculated badly by its cool response to the call for a royal commission into links between police, the Mafia and the murder of the Federal Police Assistant Commissioner, Colin Winchester. Had the Government agreed with the idea but deferred the actual appointment of a royal commission until the Winchester inquest was concluded, few would have demurred. But by refusing to consider the possibility of such a royal commission until after the Winchester inquest-leaving open the real prospect that the idea will be rejected-the Federal Government has invited the most adverse speculation about its motives.

The editorial goes on to say that this royal commission is supported by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner, and by the Opposition leader, Mr Carr. It arises out of a call by Mr Hatton, a courageous independent member of parliament in New South Wales. What they are seeking to do deserves nothing but praise; that is, to find whether crime and corruption exists in the circumstances that the editorial discusses, and to root out that crime and corruption. It would seem that there is absolutely no reason why the Federal Government should not go along with such a suggestion. The editorial takes up that very point.

The difficulty is that royal commissions tend to be in vogue at present. They are being called for in your State of Western Australia, Mr Acting Deputy President. Indeed, they have been in vogue throughout the 1980s. It always seems that when they are called for it is a reasonable proposition. There are problems with royal commissions and, indeed, with any commission. In this context, it is worth quoting some words spoken by Mr Vincent, as he then was-Mr Justice Vincent, as he now is, of the Supreme Court of Victoria-in the Senate chamber of the old Parliament House on 28 and 29 July 1983. He said:

One of the more pernicious consequences of the various Commissions which have been conducted in this country over recent years has been the amount of damage suffered by individuals against whom no criminal charges are ever laid, by the kind of public identification which we have seen exampled in the last few weeks.
He was speaking, of course, in July 1983. Later in his speech he said:

Above all, we must be extraordinarily careful that the kind of publicity that attaches to such Commissions, the kind of damage which is occasioned by mention in the course of such Commissions, is not extended, is not carried beyond the shameful limits which we have observed over recent times.

Throughout the last decade there has been a call for all sorts of measures outside the traditional ones-by traditional ones I mean the police forces of the Commonwealth and the various States. There have been calls for extraordinary bodies and extraordinary instruments to offset the perceived spread of crime, particularly at an official level.

I give some examples of what I mean by this extraordinary growth. There was the National Crimes Commission Act 1982 which set up the National Crimes Commission; in 1984 we had the National Crime Authority Act which set up the National Crime Authority; there was the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act 1986, which was made specific to a named person, specifically, Mr Justice Murphy; in New South Wales there was the Independent Commission Against Corruption Act 1988. If one looks at the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, one sees amendments to that Act-in 1983 it was amended on two occasions; in 1984 it was also amended on two occasions; and in 1985 it was amended on two occasions. The Crimes Legislation Amendment Act 1988 extended the powers given to the various policing authorities under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 to those authorities in respect of telegrams.

In spite of all those additional powers and the new bodies that have been set up, apparently there is an inability to chase down the sources of crime and what crime has been committed and to find a solution for it. So the suggestion is that a royal commission be set up. It is to be set up apparently without any concluded terms for what it is to do. It is suggested in the editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald that the commission ought to be set up now and brought into operation at a later date. The editorial-and I think correctly-says:
There are reasonable concerns about the possible adverse effect any parallel inquiry-
of course, the Sydney Morning Herald is talking here about the royal commission it wants set up-

-whether by the Senate or royal commissioner-would have on the inquest into Mr Winchester's death. It is hard to see, however, how an immediate commitment in principle to one or the other would make the task of the ACT coroner, Ron Cahill, more difficult than it has been.

Of course, this makes all sorts of presumptions. I would have thought that Mr Cahill would be concerned if the facts that he is investigating are to be reinvestigated by a royal commission, because that royal commission would in effect be sitting in judgment upon his findings. Since it is an inquest that Mr Cahill is conducting, that could cause some difficulties and, indeed, problems with proceedings that may subsequently take place. There are real problems in that, and that was adverted to by the Chief Justice of the High Court in 1940, Sir John Latham, in the case of McGuinness v. Attorney-General (Victoria), the judgment being set out at 63 Commonwealth Law Reports, page 73. His Honour, talking about royal commissions and how they may affect the proper course of justice, has this to say, at page 85:

If, for example, a prosecution for an offence were taking place, the establishment of a Royal Commission to inquire into the same matter would almost certainly be held to be an interference with the course of justice and consequently to constitute a contempt of court. There are other circumstances in which such an inquiry might prejudice proceedings in the civil or the criminal courts.
It is perhaps worth reading this, though not completely on the point at the moment:

But it is important, I think, that there should be no doubt with respect to two propositions-(1) the executive government cannot by the exercise of the prerogative create new courts; and (2) the executive government cannot by any exercise of the prerogative interfere with the due course of the administration of justice.

A royal commission is a body appointed by the Executive and is an executive's instrument, and has been since the first one was set up, as I understand it, in 1086, and produced the Domesday Book. The instrument of a royal commission has been with us for a very long time and has at times, perhaps on most occasions, been a most effective instrument. Nonetheless, there is a danger that if a commission is appointed justice will be prejudiced specifically in the terms that the Chief Justice, Sir John Latham, was talking about and, more broadly, in the terms that Mr Justice Vincent, as he now is, spoke about in his outstanding speech in 1983.

Sir John Latham talked specifically about how a royal commission may interfere with the process of justice. Certainly the conduct of an inquest is part of the process of justice. It can determine whether a person is to stand trial. More broadly, of course, as Mr Justice Vincent pointed out, royal commissions can cause tremendous injustice by throwing into suspicion people who are later not charged and who have no effective means of defending themselves.

I am saying that the call for a royal commission is a call which I accept as nothing but a genuine and heartfelt call to remedy what is seen as a very serious situation. It appears, as far as one can see, to be a very serious situation. But to react in a knee-jerk way, which I do not suggest has happened here, and call for a royal commission would be wrong. Secondly, to call for it after proper consideration-and that is what I take to have happened here with Mr Greiner, Mr Carr and Mr Hatton-does not necessarily mean that that call is a correct call. I have considerable concern that the call on this occasion is certainly premature because there is an inquest being conducted by Mr Cahill. He should not be subject to the threat, if you like, of a royal commission sitting in judgment on what he is now deciding.

There is concern in the community that, after a decade of a series of instruments, a series of parliamentary enactments setting up bodies and new means of investigating crime, none of those instruments or bodies are sufficient to handle what, on the face of it, they should be able to handle.

I conclude by saying that the setting up of those bodies and the passing of the Acts giving more power to policing authorities has lessened the liberties we had in 1980. A balance has always to be struck between the necessity of rooting out crime and corruption in the community and the preservation of those liberties which we as Australians are entitled to and which we have enjoyed. I am simply concerned that the balance between those two has been tilted too much in favour of rooting out crime and corruption, which, though done for the most worthy of motives, has the effect of lessening the liberties and freedoms, as we understand them, of the vast majority of Australian citizens.

The vast majority of Australian citizens are not concerned in crime and corruption-indeed, the eradication of crime and corruption would bring great relief to them. If the community used all the means that might be available to it to eradicate crime and corruption-if it simply locked up people on suspicion, reverted to torture to extort confessions, or labelled people and drove them from decent society on the merest suspicion-certainly a lot of crime might be eliminated. But what sort of society would we be living in?
